input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROSURGERY <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> headache past ten days <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Image guided right craniotomy for tumor resection <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male who was in good health until 10 days ago, when he began having gradually worsening headaches. These were right-sided and throbbing and initially controlled with over the counter analgesics, but are now refractory to these. He has had no visual changes in association, no N/V or drowsiness. He does not appreciate worsening with cough/strain or sneezing. The patient denies other difficulties, such as weakness, numbness/tingling, visual loss or diplopia, speech abnormalities, gait difficulties, vertigo, dysarthria or dysphagia. He was taken to an outside hospital today, where head CT revealed an intracranial mass lesion. He was given decadron and sent to ___ ER. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> renal cell carcinoma s/p L nephrectomy in ___, no xrt/chemo <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> negative for past malignancies <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS 97.9 60 150/100 12 97% Gen Awake, cooperative, NAD HEENT NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity Lungs CTA bilaterally CV RRR, nl S1S2, no M/R/G noted Abd soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no masses or organomegaly noted Ext No C/C/E b/l Skin no rashes or lesions noted NEURO EXAM MS ___, alert and oriented x 3. Speech fluent, with normal naming, reading, comprehension and repetition. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. No apraxia. No dysarthria. CN I: not tested CN II: Visual fields were full to confrontation, but with extinction on the left to double simultaneous stimulation. Pupils 4->2 b/l. CN III, IV, VI: EOMI no nystagmus or diplopia CN V: intact to LT throughout; CN VII: slight L NLF flattening and asymmetry CN VIII: hearing intact to FR b/l CN IX, X: palate rises symmetrically CN XI: shrug ___ and symmetric CN XII: tongue midline and agile Motor Normal bulk and tone. No pronator drift D B T WE FE FF IP Q H DF PF TE L ___ ___ Sensory intact to light touch, pinprick, joint position sense, vibration throughout. No extinction to double simultaneous stimulation. Reflexes Br Bi Tri Pat Ach Toes L ___ 2 1 down R ___ 2 1 down Coordination Fine finger movements, rapid alternating movements, finger-to-nose, and heel-to-shin were all normal <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 04: 30PM ___ PTT-26.8 ___ ___ 04: 30PM PLT COUNT-156 ___ 04: 30PM NEUTS-87.7* LYMPHS-10.9* MONOS-1.0* EOS-0.3 BASOS-0.1 ___ 04: 30PM WBC-6.7 RBC-5.41 HGB-15.8 HCT-47.0 MCV-87 MCH-29.2 MCHC-33.7 RDW-13.2 ___ 04: 30PM estGFR-Using this ___ 04: 30PM GLUCOSE-107* UREA N-19 CREAT-1.4* SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-106 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-13 MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST ___ 5: 37 AM MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST Reason: evaluate lesion Contrast: MAGNEVIST UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION: ___ year old man with intracranial mass lesion REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: evaluate lesion CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None. INDICATION: ___ mid patient, with endocranial mass lesion, to evaluate lesion. PRIOR STUDIES: CT of the head done on ___. TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted imaging of the head was performed without and with IV contrast. FINDINGS: There is a large heterogeneous mass lesion, in the right temporoparietal lobes, with areas of hemorrhage, cystic change, necrosis and large solid enhancing component. The solid competent measures 5.0 x 4.3 cm. There is entrapment of the right temporal horn. There is surrounding significant vasogenic edema, with a leftward shift of subfalcine herniation; measuring approximately 1 cm is unchanged, allowing for technical differences, compared to the prior CT. Mass effect on the right lateral ventricle, is unchanged. There is a 1.7 x 1.6 cm round focus of increased signal on the FLAIR, with enhancement on the post-contrast images in the left parapharyngeal space, which corresponds to an abnormally enlarged lymph node, on correlation with the CT angiogram performed on the same day (series 9, image 1), however, this is not completely included on our present study. IMPRESSION: 1. Large heterogeneous mass lesion in the right parietal and temporal lobes, with cystic, necrotic, hemorrhagic and solid components, the solid competent measuring 5.0 cm, with significant surrounding edema, mass effect and subfalcine herniation, and entrapment of the right temporal horn without significant change since the CT head done the day before. 2. 1.7-cm enhancing focus in the left parapharyngeal region, representing an abnormally enlarged lymph node, representing metastatic involvement. However, this is not completely included on our present study. MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST ___ 2: 41 ___ MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST Reason: residual mass? Contrast: MAGNEVIST UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION: ___ year old man with parietal mass s/p resection REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: residual mass? CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None. GADOLINIUM-ENHANCED MR SCAN OF THE BRAIN HISTORY: Status post resection of right parietal mass. Assess for residual tumor. TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted brain imaging was obtained pre- and post-gadolinium administration. COMPARISON STUDY: MR scan of the brain from ___. FINDINGS: There is a lace-like pattern of enhancement along the anteromedial aspect of the right temporal lobe, apparently surrounding the right temporal horn body. There is persistent mild dilatation of the right temporal horn tip, but substantially reduced in extent compared to the prior preoperative study. Additionally, there is presumed hemorrhage along the operative tract, more peripherally situated within the posterior aspect of the right temporal lobe. The extensive edema surrounding the formerly very large tumor appears unaltered in extent. However, overall, there is somewhat less mass effect, though there is still leftward subfalcine herniation present. Numerous tiny areas of elevated T2 signal are seen within the white matter of both cerebral hemispheres, presumably representing chronic small vessel infarctions or post- inflammatory residua. There is soft tissue swelling, subgaleal in locale at the craniotomy site and there is a possible fluid collection or surgical material within the crescent- shaped space between the dura spanning the craniotomy flap and the inner table of the flap itself. There is redemonstration of the well- defined, rounded 21 mm area of contrast enhancement in the left parapharyngeal fat area. Its sharp margination seems most consistent with a benign neoplastic process (question neurogenic tumor). This location would be very unusual for a lymph node or metastatic disease, as was suggested on the previous report. CONCLUSION: Findings suggest that there is residual tumor in the region of the right temporal lobe surrounding the right temporal horn, with mild residual entrapment of this portion of the right lateral ventricle, as described above. Pathology pending at time of discharge <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> None <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain or fever. 2. Atenolol 25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 3. Phenytoin Sodium Extended 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times a day). Disp: *90 Capsule(s)* Refills: *0* 4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Capsule(s)* Refills: *0* 5. Dexamethasone 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO tid (). Disp: *90 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Brain tumor <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOR CRANIOTOMY/HEAD INJURY -Have a family member check your incision daily for signs of infection -Take your pain medicine as prescribed -Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, excessive bending -You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have been removed -You may shower before this time with assistance and use of a shower cap -Increase your intake of fluids and fiber as pain medicine (narcotics) can cause constipation -Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, aspirin, Advil, Ibuprofen etc. -If you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing as ordered -Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE FOLLOWING: -New onset of tremors or seizures -Any confusion or change in mental status -Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities -Pain or headache that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain medication -Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, tenderness, drainage -Fever greater than or equal to 101 F

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> UROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> BENIGN PROSTATIC HYPERTROPHY, LOWER URINARY TRACT SYMPTOMS <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> 1. Cystoscopy. 2. Transurethral resection of the prostate. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ w/ longstanding obstructive uropathy at level of bladder/prostate/ureter managed with indwelling SPT and bilateral ureteric stents. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> END STAGE RENAL DISEASE BLADDER STONES HISTORY OF COCAINE USE BENIGN PROSTATIC HYPERTROPHY URINARY RETENTION HYPERLIPIDEMIA DIABETES MELLITUS BLADDER OUTLET OBSTRUCTION REQUIRING SP CATH NEUROGENIC BLADDER HYPERTENSION ANEMIA VITAMIN D DEFICIENCY ATTENTION DEFICIT DISORDER WITHOUT HYPERACTIVITY URINARY TRACT INFECTION INGUINAL HERNIA DEPRESSION PSH: UMBILICAL HERNIORRHAPHY Bilateral ureteric stent placement Suprapubic tube <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> He is of ___ heritage. There is no bleeding in his extended family. <PHYSICAL EXAM> wdwn male, nad, avss abd soft nt/nd extremities w/out edema, pitting, pain foley secured to left medial thigh uop yellowing from tea; faint pink color <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 12: 35 pm URINE Site: CYSTOSCOPY URINE CULTURE (Pending): <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 2. Methylphenidate SR 54 mg PO QAM 3. Calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY 4. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO BID <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 2. Methylphenidate SR 54 mg PO QAM 3. Calcitriol 0.25 mcg PO DAILY 4. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *oxycodone 5 mg one tablet(s) by mouth Q4HRS Disp #*15 Tablet Refills: *0 5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg one capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills: *0 6. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Mild 7. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO BID COMPLETE THIS COURSE OF ABX AS WRITTEN <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Benign prostatic hypertrophy. 2. Chronic kidney disease. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Benign prostatic hypertrophy. 2. Chronic kidney disease. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> These steps can help you recover after your procedure. -Drink plenty of water to flush out the bladder. -Avoid straining during a bowel movement. Eat fiber-containing foods and avoid foods that can cause constipation. Ask your doctor if you should take a laxative if you do become constipated. -Don't take blood-thinning medications until your doctor says it's OK. -Don't do any strenuous activity, such as heavy lifting, for four to six weeks or until your doctor says it's OK. -Don't have sex. You'll likely be able to resume sexual activity in about four to six weeks. Don't drive until your doctor says it's OK. ___, you can drive once your catheter is removed and you're no longer taking prescription pain medications. -You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve -Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. You should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor. Should you HOLD ASPIRIN? Unless otherwise advised; If the urine is still pink, hold the aspirin until it has been clear/yellow for at least three days. -If prescribed; complete the full course of antibiotics. -You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange. -Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool softener, NOT a laxative - AVOID STRAINING for bowel movements as this may stir up bleeding. -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids to keep hydrated -No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until otherwise advised -Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or participate in high intensity physical activity for a minimum of four weeks or until you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up -Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. -Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains Tylenol -Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger). WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER: -Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on routine care and hygiene -Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon. -DO NOT have anyone else other than your Surgeon or your surgeon's representative remove your Foley for any reason. -Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only for short-term periods for when leaving the house. -Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your safety)

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Augmentin / lisinopril / ciprofloxacin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Dysuria, Fever <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with PMH notable for hx of left ICA aneurysm rupture in ___ s/p clipping, complicated by residual aneurysm. s/p pipeline coiling on ___, BPH, HTN, HLD, and known Plavix resistance who presents with dysuria. Of note, pt. was recently admitted from ___ to ___ for an elective embolization of a LICA aneurysm. Pt. underwent pipeline embolization L ICA on ___ without difficulty. Post-op course complicated by acute urinary retention (pt. had bladder scan which showed 1 liter of retained urine). Pt. had a straight cath, continued to retain and required foley catheter placement on ___. Pt. was discharged with the foley in place with plan to have foley removed as an outpatient and to have a voiding trial. Pt's foley was removed on ___ without difficulty, Dr. ___ (___). Pt. voided without issue after removal of foley. Since this time, pt. notes dysuria, specifically tenderness to the urethra region when urinating since the time of removal. He also notes increased urinary urgency. He typically urinates once overnight, however over the last several days has urinated ___ / night. Fevers/chills began on the morning of presentation. Pt. woke up in the afternoon, felt ongoing chills, temperature was noted to be 102.1. Pt. denies any blood in his urine when foley was placed or since removal, noted normal colored urine. ___ RN was contacted and recommended referral to the ED. Pt. otherwise denies lightheadedness, dizziness, CP, SOB, cough, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or changes in bowel habits. In the ED, initial vital signs were: 101.3, 126, 149/84, 16, 98% on RA - Exam was notable for: well healed R groin angio site, no other significant findings - Labs were notable for: WBC 18.3, H/H stable (possibly contracted), INR 1.2, Creatinine 1.3, Bun 23, Mg 1.7, Phos 2.5, INR 1.2, lactate 1.6, UA notable for positive nitrites, positive leuks, >182 WBC, 12 RBC - Imaging: CXR unremarkable - Bladder scan with only 60cc PVR, as such no foley was inserted - The patient was given: 2L NS, Tylenol, and Cipro. During the cipro infusion, pt. had a local skin reaction (phlebitis) with itching and redness that moved into the elbow. Cipro was stopped. Pt. tolerated ceftriaxone 1G IV x1 without difficulty. - BCx/UCx pending - Consults: Neurosurgery was consulted as an FYI given recent procedure. They recommend that if blood cultures are positive to consult ID given that recently surgically implanted hardware cannot be removed. Vitals prior to transfer were: 98.2, 91, 126/75, 18, 96% on RA Upon arrival to the floor, pt. feels improved although he does note ongoing tenderness in the urethra. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> # Hx of left ICA aneurysm rupture in ___ s/p clipping (residual metal clip in place), complicated by residual aneurysm. s/p pipeline coiling on ___ complicated by acute urinary retention requiring foley # BPH with hx. of urinary obstruction # HLD # HTN # Known Plavix resistance (platelet aggregation testing done on ___ showed clopidogrel resistance) # Hx. of Nephrolithiasis # Hx. of vocal cord paralysis # Hyperacusis # Hx. of hyperplastic colon polyps <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father with ___ and ___. Mother with ___ Disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> ON ADMISSION: VITALS: 97.9, 139/70, 89, 16, 99% on RA GENERAL: Pleasant, well-appearing, in no apparent distress. HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic, no conjunctival pallor or scleral icterus, PERRLA, EOMI, OP clear. NECK: Supple, no LAD, no thyromegaly, JVP flat. CARDIAC: RRR, normal S1/S2, no murmurs rubs or gallops. PULMONARY: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, without wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Normal bowel sounds, soft, non-tender, non-distended, no organomegaly, no suprapubic tenderness EXTREMITIES: Warm, well-perfused, no cyanosis, clubbing or edema. SKIN: Without rash. NEUROLOGIC: A&Ox3, CN II-XII grossly normal, normal sensation, with strength ___ throughout. ON DISCHARGE: VITALS: 98.5, 110s-140s/70s-80s, 80s-90s, ___, 96-98% on RA GENERAL: Pleasant, well-appearing, in no apparent distress. HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic, no conjunctival pallor or scleral icterus, PERRLA, EOMI, OP clear. NECK: Supple, no LAD, no thyromegaly, JVP flat. You were treated with an IV antibiotic with improvement in your symptoms. You will need to complete a course of oral antibiotics, please see your medication list for instructions. Your follow-up appointments with your PCP and neurosurgery are scheduled below. We wish you the best, Your ___ Care Team

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Aortic Abdominal Aneurysm <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Fenestrated endovascular aneurysm repair <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HPI: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a known AAA from over ___ years ago initially followed by his PCP with care now handed over to Dr. ___. The patient has had vascular abdominal ultrasounds every 6 months, and the last US showed that it was <5.5cm. However, he was most recently surveyed with a CTA, which showed that the AAA was 6.2cm in diameter. The patient has a history of sigmoid colectomy for diverticulitis c/b anastomotic breakdown requiring open abdomen and end colostomy. Due to his complicated abdominal anatomy, the patient was referred to Dr. ___ potential endovascular intervention. The patient has been asymptomatic. He denies chest pain, abdominal pain, back pain, fatigue in his thighs, claudication, rest pain, or "blue toe syndrome." The patient currently works approximately 5 hours a day. He is able to walk any distance and is able to climb stairs without having to stop. The patient is A current active smoker. He does report that he is attempting to quit smoking. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: HTN, arthritis, chronic back pain, diverticulitis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> FH: Mother - HLD, macular degeneration, HTN Father - MI, heart failure Brother - lung cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 24 HR Data (last updated ___ @ 803) Temp: 98.8 (Tm 99.3), BP: 144/75 (103-144/58-77), HR: 93 (78-98), RR: 19 (___), O2 sat: 100% (94-100), O2 delivery: RA, Wt: 201.1 lb/91.22 kg GENERAL: [X]NAD [X]A/O x 3 []intubated/sedated []abnormal CV: []RRR [] irregularly irregular []no MRG []Nl S1S2 []abnormal PULM: []CTA b/l [X]no respiratory distress []abnormal ABD: []soft []Nontender []appropriately tender []nondistended []no rebound/guarding []abnormal WOUND: [X]CD&I []no erythema/induration []abnormal EXTREMITIES: []no CCE []abnormal PULSES: R: / /P/P/ L: / /P/P/ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 57PM GLUCOSE-143* UREA N-13 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-12 ___ 07: 57PM estGFR-Using this ___ 07: 57PM CALCIUM-8.4 PHOSPHATE-3.8 MAGNESIUM-1.6 ___ 07: 57PM WBC-11.4* RBC-3.89* HGB-12.0* HCT-36.3* MCV-93 MCH-30.8 MCHC-33.1 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-45.1 ___ 07: 57PM PLT COUNT-147* ___ 07: 57PM ___ PTT-88.3* ___ <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Meclizine 20 mg as needed, lisinopril 20 mg daily, Lipitor 40 mg daily, Nexium 40 mg as needed, aspirin 81 mg daily, metoprolol XL 25 mg daily, multivitamin daily, vitamin B complex daily, vitamin C 500 mg daily, vitamin E 100 international unit daily, vitamin D ___ international units daily, fish oil 1200 mg daily, omega-3 360 mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin EC 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 3. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 4. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 5. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Aortic Abdominal Aneurysm <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ and underwent endovascular aneurysm repair. You have now recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please follow the instructions below to continue your recovery: MEDICATIONS: - Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily - Do not stop Aspirin unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs you to do so. - Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed - You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any post procedure pain or discomfort WHAT TO EXPECT AT HOME: It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs: - Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at night - Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your legs elevated It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time - Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals - It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing - To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool softener while taking pain medication ACTIVITIES: - When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs - You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, rinse and pat dry) - Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or band aid over the area that is draining, as needed - No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) - After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity - After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance walked as you can tolerate - No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ - Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities - Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours - New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or green drainage from incisions - Bleeding from groin puncture site FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or incision) - Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call vascular office. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

F MEDICINE Gold Salts / Penicillins / Remicade / Erythromycin Base ___. shortness of breath None Ms. ___ is a ___ yoF with a PMHx of HTN, RA (on prednisone/methotrexate/orencia) who presented with 1 day hx of shortness of breath. She as in her usual state of health until the morning of ___ when she awoke for no known reason at 4AM. After moving to the couch, she noted dyspnea, which progressively worsened throughout the day. Her SOB was associated with a dry cough and malaise. In addition to SOB, she noted a sharp and pleuritic shoulder pain at the R AC joint, which lasted for several hours and resolved spontaneously. The pain was ___, non-radiating, not worsened with motion, exacerbated by deep breathing and occurred and not limiting her range of motion. She reported a feeling of dizziness on ambulating to and from the cough and one episode of vomiting (non-bloody, non-bilious). She Her measured temp at home was 97. She denies fevers, chills, myalgias, recent trauma, night sweats, headache, vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, or hematuria. She presented to ___ where VS were T98.3, HR 79, 117/60, 13, SpO2 96% on RA, 93% with ambulation. CXR demonstrated a diffuse pulmonary infiltrate with RUL and RLL areas of consolidation, and Ms. ___ was given 750mg IV levofloxacin for presumed CAP. She was transferred to ___ for admission given lack of bed availability at ___. PAST MEDICAL & SURGICAL HISTORY: Community Acquired Pneumonia in ___ (RUL, sp cefpodoxime and azithro) Rheumatoid arthritis (dx'd ___ prior) Osteoarthritis Depression Cataracts Cerebral aneurysm, s/p removal ___ yrs ago Surg Hx: Cerebral aneurism removal ___ yrs ago s/p R THR s/p L shoulder arthroplasty s/p cerical facet injection ___ Father died of pneumonia in ___ Mother died of Lung Cancer at age ___. Admission Physical: VITALS: 97.8 BP 127/63, 70, 20, 96% 2L NC, No orthostasis GENERAL: NAD, well-composed, talkative and pleasant HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, dry MM, no conj injection, no oropharyngeal erythema, swelling or lesions NECK: No JVD, LAD, thyromegally, or carotid bruits LUNGS: Crackles diffuse in b/l lung fields HEART: RRR, normal S1 S2, ___ systolic ejection murmur in RUSB ABDOMEN: Soft, NT, NABS, no organomegaly EXTREMITIES: ulnar deviation, swan deformity c/w RA, no ___ edema NEUROLOGIC: A+OX3, CNII-XII intact, Romberg negative, gait normal, strength ___ diffusely, sensation intactto LT throughout. Discharge Physical: O: VS: 98.4/97.5, 138/75 (116-134/56-75), 66 (66-78), 96% on RA; ___ 2500/2975 GENERAL: NAD, well-composed, talkative and pleasant HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, MMM, no conj injection, no oropharyngeal erythema, swelling or lesions NECK: No JVD, LAD, thyromegally, or carotid bruits LUNGS: Crackles diffuse in b/l lung fields - persistent HEART: RRR, normal S1 S2, ___ systolic ejection murmur in RUSB ABDOMEN: Soft, NT, NABS, no organomegaly EXTREMITIES: ulnar deviation, swan deformity c/w RA, very trace ___ edema (ankle) NEUROLOGIC: A+OX3, CNII-XII intact, strength ___ diffusely, sensation intactto LT throughout. As per BI-N: WBC 20.2 with leukocytic predominance (PMN 91%) and hyponatremia with Na of 132. H/H was 11.5/35 Admissions Labs: ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD WBC-16.3*# RBC-3.45* Hgb-10.9* Hct-34.2*# MCV-99*# MCH-31.7 MCHC-32.0 RDW-15.1 Plt ___ ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD Neuts-90.4* Lymphs-5.3* Monos-2.2 Eos-1.6 Baso-0.4 ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD Glucose-84 UreaN-10 Creat-0.5 Na-144 K-4.6 Cl-112* HCO3-27 AnGap-10 ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD LD(LDH)-169 ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD Calcium-7.9* Phos-2.1* Mg-1.9 ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD VitB12-366 Folate-15.6 Discharge Labs: ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD WBC-9.5 RBC-3.73* Hgb-11.8* Hct-36.9 MCV-99* MCH-31.5 MCHC-31.9 RDW-14.8 Plt ___ ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD Neuts-75.0* Lymphs-17.2* Monos-3.8 Eos-3.2 Baso-0.8 ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-84 UreaN-13 Creat-0.7 Na-140 K-4.5 Cl-100 HCO3-31 AnGap-14 ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD ALT-15 AST-16 AlkPhos-54 ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD Calcium-9.2 Phos-3.1 Mg-1.9 ___ 07: 35AM BLOOD TSH-2.8 Microbiology: ___: Urine Legionella Ag: NEGATIVE FOR LEGIONELLA SEROGROUP 1 ANTIGEN. Blood cultures: ___: Pending Echo ___: The left atrium is elongated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). Doppler parameters are indeterminate for left ventricular diastolic function. There is no left ventricular outflow obstruction at rest or with Valsalva. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function. Borderline elevated pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. EKG ___: Sinus rhythm. Borderline left axis deviation. Compared to the previous tracing of ___ no significant change. CXR from OSH ___ - ___: There is an ill-defined parenchymal infiltrate involving the posterior aspects of both the right upper lobe and the right lower lobe. There is also slight increased density centrally in the left lung. The pulmonary vasculature, which was difficult to evaluate because of the widespread parenchymal changes, is prominent compatible with acute congestive failure. The cardiac size and configuration are within normal limits. There is a hiatal hernia present, as before. IMPRESSION: CHANGES COMPATIBLE WITH EXTENSIVE BRONCHOPNEUMONIC INFILTRATES POSTERIORLY IN THE RIGHT LUNG WITH ACCOMPANYING CHANGES OF ACUTE CONGESTIVE FAILURE. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Aspirin / Motrin / Tylenol / clindamycin / doxycycline / erythromycin base / Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / azithromycin / NSAIDS (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug) / hydromorphone / nicotine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> shortness of breath, hip pain s/p fall, headache <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Patient is a ___ year old woman with history of paradoxical vocal cord dysfunction, asthma/COPD (reportedly intubated 14 times but no verified), severe HTN, cocaine abuse, DVT/PE (on xarelto), question of somatization disorder, who presents to the ED c/o dyspnea x 1 week. She states that she has had worsening shortness of breath and wheezing for the past week and is now taking Duonebs 4x/day and Albuterol nebs 12x/day with minor relief. States that she had her most recent exacerbation 6 months ago. Associated sx are chest tightness and lightheadedness. Reports dry cough and sxs of chest congestion which she usually gets during change of sesaons. Otherwise denies fever, chills. Per chart review patient has longstanding history of asthma but also had questionable historical components including history of 14 intubations that could not be verified. Paradoxical vocal cord movement (PVCM) was deemed to be a realistic possibility given the patient's history of psychiatric disorders and refractory asthma and has been suggested in the past. Also reports she has had increased swelling in left leg, for which she presented to ___ last week. Per her report she had a ___ which showed DVT (not accurate) ROS also positive for headache. Patient states that 5 days ago, she also developed L retro-orbital headache radiating to the L upper cheek w photophobia consistent w previous headaches that she gets when bp is elevated. States that today she woke up with a headache and checked her bp, which was in the 200s. Reports her BPs are usually quite high (SBP 170-200). Also states that today she was walking up her steps when she fell. Per witness report, she "lost consciousness" for seconds. Denies head and neck injury. States that she developed L groin pain that radiates to her mid-thigh s/p fall, aggravated by movement. States that she has not taken any meds for pain because she is allergic to many ___ pain meds. Denies chest pain, palpitations, lightheadedness prior to the episode. In the ED, initial VS were: 98.1 ___ 24 ED labs were normal Imaging showed normal hip films. CXR with no infiltrates. Patient was given: duonebs, solumedrol, azithro REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: A ten point ROS was conducted and was negative except as above in the HPI. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Question of somatization disorder vs factitious disorder: Patient has history of reporting symptoms or health problems which were not confirmed (see psych note ___ - Psychotic Disorder NOS: patient reports she has "bipolar schizophrenia" but per previous psych notes no psychosis outside of active substance abuse, followed by Mass Mental Health - History of self injury - Asthma: reportedly intubated 14 times (not verified) - Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus since age ___ - Hypertension - Diverticulosis - Obstructive Sleep Apnea, on CPAP . The following diagnosis are ones that she reports, but have not been medically corroborated: - Seizure disorder - Psychotic disorder NOS - DVT - PE - CVA <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father: ___, diabetes, psychiatric disorders (died at age ___ of MI) Mother: HTN, asthma, seizure disorders Per OMR patient's sister died of intracerebral aneurysmal bleed <PHYSICAL EXAM> Gen: NAD, morbidly obese, sitting up comfortably, not using accessory muscles Eyes: EOMI, sclerae anicteric ENT: MMM, OP clear Cardiovasc: JVD difficult to assess, RRR, no MRG, full pulses Resp: normal effort, no accessory muscle use, prolonged expiratory phase but no wheezing or crackles or rhonchii. GI: obese, soft, NT, ND, BS+ MSK: No significant kyphosis. No palpable synovitis. LLE calf tender to palpation Skin: No visible rash. No jaundice. Neuro: AAOx3. No facial droop. Psych: Anxious, tangential speech Exam on discharge: itals: 98.4 117/79 94 16 96 RA Gen: NAD, sitting in chair in NAD, morbidly obese Eyes: EOMI, sclerae anicteric ENT: MMM, OP clear ___: RRR, no MRG, full pulses, no edema Resp: normal effort, no accessory muscle use, lungs CTA ___. No wheezing. GI: soft, NT, ND, BS+ Skin: No visible rash. No jaundice. Neuro: AAOx3. No facial droop. Psych: Flat affect <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 04: 45PM URINE UCG-NEGATIVE ___ 04: 45PM URINE UCG-NEGATIVE ___ 04: 45PM URINE bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG opiates-NEG cocaine-NEG amphetmn-NEG oxycodn-NEG mthdone-NEG ___ 04: 45PM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-2* PH-6.5 LEUK-MOD ___ 04: 45PM URINE RBC-1 WBC-3 BACTERIA-NONE YEAST-NONE EPI-4 TRANS EPI-<1 ___ 03: 18PM LACTATE-1.1 ___ 02: 55PM GLUCOSE-146* UREA N-10 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-138 POTASSIUM-3.9 CHLORIDE-99 TOTAL CO2-29 ANION GAP-14 ___: 55PM ALT(SGPT)-16 AST(SGOT)-13 ALK PHOS-78 TOT BILI-0.2 ___ 02: 55PM ALBUMIN-3.9 CALCIUM-8.7 PHOSPHATE-2.6* MAGNESIUM-1.8 ___ 02: 55PM WBC-7.6 RBC-4.54 HGB-12.5 HCT-39.4 MCV-87 MCH-27.5 MCHC-31.7* RDW-14.9 RDWSD-47.6* ___ 02: 55PM NEUTS-50.6 ___ MONOS-7.4 EOS-0.9* BASOS-0.1 NUC RBCS-0.3* IM ___ AbsNeut-3.83 AbsLymp-3.08 AbsMono-0.56 AbsEos-0.07 AbsBaso-0.01 CTA: The exam is limited due to technical factors, such as patient body habitus. No evidence of central pulmonary embolism, and evaluation of the pulmonary arteries to the segmental and subsegmental level is limited. Bibasilar atelectasis; otherwise, no acute cardiopulmonary process. ___ (___- reviewed via partners gateway) Negative for DVT <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU DAILY 2. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 3. Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus (500/50) 1 INH IH BID 4. Ipratropium-Albuterol Neb 1 NEB NEB Q6H 5. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 6. Montelukast 10 mg PO DAILY 7. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY 8. Phenytoin Sodium Extended 300 mg PO DAILY 9. QUEtiapine Fumarate 100 mg PO DAILY 10. ZIPRASidone Hydrochloride 80 mg PO BID 11. FLUoxetine 60 mg PO DAILY 12. NPH 26 Units Breakfast NPH 26 Units Bedtime 13. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID: PRN constipation <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. NPH 35 Units Breakfast NPH 35 Units Bedtime Regular 10 Units Breakfast Regular 10 Units Bedtime 2. Albuterol 0.083% Neb Soln 1 NEB IH Q6H: PRN sob 3. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 4. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 2 SPRY NU DAILY 5. Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus (500/50) 1 INH IH BID 6. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 7. Ipratropium-Albuterol Neb 1 NEB NEB Q6H 8. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 9. Montelukast 10 mg PO DAILY 10. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY 11. QUEtiapine Fumarate 300. mg PO QHS 12. QUEtiapine Fumarate 50 mg PO DAILY 13. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID: PRN constipation <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Asthma/Dyspnea <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Ms. ___, You were admitted with shortness of breath, likely due to asthma. You had a CT scan of your chest which did not show a blood clot or other signs of infection. You were treated with nebulizers and your symptoms improved. It is important that you take your medications every day. Please follow up with your PCP. When you see your PCP, please make sure to bring all of your medications to make sure we have an updated list in our system. We wish you the best, Your ___ care team

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Tegretol / Spironolactone <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Fever Reason for MICU transfer: AMS <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> CVVHD <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year-old male with PMH of diastolic heart failure with an EF=65%, AS s/p mechanical AVR, AF on coumadin, CAD s/p CABG, pulmonary hypertension, 3rd degree heart block s/p PPM, severe COPD, with recent prolonged hospitalization for MRSA bacteremia who was sent in from ___ clinic with fevers. His most recent medical course dates back to ___ when the patient was admitted with MRSA bacteremia secondary to a PICC line. Hospital course complicated by left prostethic hip seeding requiring OR washout and prolonged post-op course of intubation that was complicated by several infections: Pseudomonal pneumonia +/- upper resp tract infection; Prevotella bacteremia; and tunneling sacral wound. Hospital course also c/b ARF with Cr peaking at 3.9. Eventually the patient was extubated and d/ced to LTAC with plan to continue vancomycin IV x 6weeks and then a prolonged oral course of antibiotics. Rehab course was c/b worsening L hip pain with evidence of dislocation on an X-ray taken at his LTAC. He was hospitalized again briefly for relocation of hip with recommendations to continue an abduction pillow between his legs until his follow up appointment on ___. The patient was at a routine follow up appointment at ___ when found to have fever, tachypnea and AMS. Per ID fellow, vancomycin should be changed to linezolid with addition of colisitin and Doripenem. In the ED, initial VS 100.5 HR: 88 BP: 115/44 Resp: 24 O(2)Sat: 98. CXR showed volume overload and worsening b/l patchy infiltrates c/w volume overload vs. infection. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -CAD s/p 2V CABG -HTN -HLD -Severe diastolic CHF (EF >60% ___ -Pulmonary Hypertension -A fib on coumadin -Hx of 3rd degree block s/p PPM, currently V-paced -Hx of AS s/p AVR with St ___ Mechanical Valve (___) -COPD -Hx of CVA c/b seizure DO, on lamictal -Diet-controlled DM -Chronic Kidney Injury -Chronic lethargy and confusion with concern for Dementia -Focal disection of abd aorta - noted CT abdomen ___- unchanged from ___ -BPH (no difficulty voiding) -s/p L ORIF and THR ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Per OMR. There is a family history of CAD. All sisters and brothers are deceased. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Exam on Arrival to ___ VS: Temp: 98.9 BP: 102/44 HR: 81 RR: 29 O2sat 99% GEN: cachectic, HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, anicteric, very dryMM, poor dentition, no supraclavicular or cervical lymphadenopathy, neck vein engorged but flatten with inspiration, RESP: no accessory muscle use, mildly tachypneic, good air movement throughout, rhonchi laterally at R base CV: mechanical heart sounds, regular rate, no m/r/g ABD: nd, +b/s, soft, nt, no masses or hepatosplenomegaly EXT: warm, no clubbing or edema SKIN: tunneling sacral ulcer, venous stasis changes on bilateral distal legs NEURO: Drowsy, arousable to verbal stimuli, follows commands slowly, inattentive, is oriented to person and hospital, Cn II-XII intact. ___ strength throughout. No sensory deficits to light touch appreciated. reduced_text: <|begin_of_text|><SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Tegretol / Spironolactone <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Fever Reason for MICU transfer: AMS <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> CVVHD <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year-old male with PMH of diastolic heart failure with an EF=65%, AS s/p mechanical AVR, AF on coumadin, CAD s/p CABG, pulmonary hypertension, 3rd degree heart block s/p PPM, severe COPD, with recent prolonged hospitalization for MRSA bacteremia who was sent in from ___ clinic with fevers. His most recent medical course dates back to ___ when the patient was admitted with MRSA bacteremia secondary to a PICC line. Hospital course complicated by left prostethic hip seeding requiring OR washout and prolonged post-op course of intubation that was complicated by several infections: Pseudomonal pneumonia +/- upper resp tract infection; Prevotella bacteremia; and tunneling sacral wound. Hospital course also c/b ARF with Cr peaking at 3.9. Eventually the patient was extubated and d/ced to LTAC with plan to continue vancomycin IV x 6weeks and then a prolonged oral course of antibiotics. Rehab course was c/b worsening L hip pain with evidence of dislocation on an X-ray taken at his LTAC. He was hospitalized again briefly for relocation of hip with recommendations to continue an abduction pillow between his legs until his follow up appointment on ___. The patient was at a routine follow up appointment at ___ when found to have fever, tachypnea and AMS. Per ID fellow, vancomycin should be changed to linezolid with addition of colisitin and Doripenem. In the ED, initial VS 100.5 HR: 88 BP: 115/44 Resp: 24 O(2)Sat: 98. CXR showed volume overload and worsening b/l patchy infiltrates c/w volume overload vs. infection. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -CAD s/p 2V CABG -HTN -HLD -Severe diastolic CHF (EF >60% ___ -Pulmonary Hypertension -A fib on coumadin -Hx of 3rd degree block s/p PPM, currently V-paced -Hx of AS s/p AVR with St ___ Mechanical Valve (___) -COPD -Hx of CVA c/b seizure DO, on lamictal -Diet-controlled DM -Chronic Kidney Injury -Chronic lethargy and confusion with concern for Dementia -Focal disection of abd aorta - noted CT abdomen ___- unchanged from ___ -BPH (no difficulty voiding) -s/p L ORIF and THR ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Per OMR. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Drug Allergy Information on File <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Dizziness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The pt is a ___ year-old right-handed woman with a remote history of migraine and head trauma who presents with a 2-hour history of acute onset "dizziness" in the setting of neck "stretching" to a fully extended position. The patient explains she was in her usual state of health one day prior to admission, and enjoyed a "long" swim on ___. Following her swim she recalls napping for two hours and awakening feeling well. However, she thereafter noted the gradual onset of "discomfort" limited to the "skull" behind her right ear. She describes the discomfort as "dull" and rating ___ on a 10-point pain scale at its worst. She denies radiation of the discomfort. She denies identifiable triggers and exacerbating factors. She denies associated symptoms including phono- and photophobia, nausea, vomiting, neck discomfort, changes in vision, and ear discomfort. She did not treat the HA or mention alleviating factors. She recalls going to bed as usual and falling to sleep without difficulty. She indicates her headache must have "disappeared" in the course of her sleep because she awakened feeling her usual self at a customary time between ___. The pt describes enjoying a "lazy" holiday morning. She recalls preparing breakfast while standing upright between 10: 30 and 11am. At that time, she describes "stretching" by fully extending her neck. In the midst of the maneuver, she states she developed an acute sense of "severe sea-sickness," requiring her to hold on to the nearby oven for support. She says she had diarrhea within about three minutes of the symptom, and had to crawl to the bathroom because attempts to walk resulted in the persistent feeling that she would fall to the right. Other associated symptoms included nausea, although the pt denies vomiting. Following the episode of diarrhea, she assumed a supine position. She says that lying still "with no movement" seemed to decrease the intensity of the feeling of sea-sickness. She denies similar episodes in the past. The sx prompted her to call her PCP, who recommended she go to the ED for evaluation. The pt initially presented to the ___ by ambulance. The pt recalls the persistence of sea-sickness and nausea for about ___ hours until she was given an IV (which she thinks provided NS). This examiner could not elucidate from the available notes what treatment was given. The pt recalls a transient (~30 minute episode) of "blurred vision" while at ___ which she said spontaneously resolved. Notes suggest that the physicians at the OSH noted "faint fatiguing nystagmus to the right" and inferior visual field cuts. Reportedly, the laboratory studies, EKG, and CT performed at the outside hospital were normal or negative. She was subsequently transferred to the ___ for evaluation. En route by ambulance, the pt developed a headache in the occipital regions bilaterally. She recalls a gradual onset of non-radiating discomfort that rated ___ at its worst; she could not define the time from onset to peak discomfort. Since that time, she notes that the headache has moved to the temporal regions bilaterally and is much improved; she rates the discomfort as ___. She attributes the discomfort to "not eating" all day. At the time of evaluation, the pt reports feeling herself. She denies a sense of sea-sickness and nausea. She indicates her vision has completely normalized. Although she continues to experience slight bi-temporal "dull" discomfort, she indicates the sx is unlike her prior migraines. She denies any migraines for the ___ yrs PTA. On neurological review of systems, the pt specifically denies experiencing the "room spinning around" her and the sense that she might lose consciousness. Rather, she volunteers having felt as though she "might fall" from lack of balance. She denies neck pain. Of note, the pt recalls recent redecoration activities and describes herself as a ___. While she does recall assuming a position in which she extended her neck to paint the ceiling, she notes in was a "long time ago." She does note a ~1month hx of second-long episodes of left ___ discomfort. She indicates it feels as though she is "punched in the eye." She recalls 1 episode every ___ days. She denies associated tearing, congestion, and HA; the sx spontaneously resolves. General review of systems is positive for an URI in the 2 weeks prior to admission that included "sinus sx," maximum temperature of ___ F, and sore throat. She denies associated ear discomfort and hearing difficulty. She treated the URI with "homeopathic" remedies and states she was feeling better by one week PTA. NEUROLOGICAL REVIEW OF SYSTEMS - Positive for: headache, recent blurring of vision, ?tinnitus (pt cannot identify which ear or when the ringing might have occurred but says she had the sense the sx was present recently) - Negative for: lightheadedness, vision loss, double vision, difficulty hearing, trouble speaking, trouble swallowing, difficulty producing or understanding speech, focal weakness, numbness, tingling, neck discomfort, and bowel incontinence. GENERAL REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: - Positive for: recent chills, nausea (as above), easy brusing (baseline per pt), generalized fatigue - Negative for: recent changes in weight, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough, abdominal pain, vomiting, and dysuria PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - Remote h/o migraine (last episode ___ yrs PTA) - GERD - Diverticulosis - Depression (not currently treated) - transient episodes in which her "neck [feels] out of alignment" for which she last visited a chiropractor ___ yrs PTA and now does yoga; she says the chiropractor diagnosed her with a "twisted spine" - remote h/o "concussion" in setting of physical abuse <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Negative for neurological conditions <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: 98 P: 68 RR: 16 BP: 137/87 SaO2: 100% on RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. Speaks fluently without evidence of dysarthria or hoarseness. HEENT: Normocepahlic, atruamatic, no scleral icterus noted. ___ intact. Mucus membranes moist, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck: Supple with full ROM. No evidence of nuchal rigidity Cardiac: Regular rate, normal S1 and S2. No carotid bruits appreciated Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen: Obese. Normoactive bowel sounds. Soft. Non-tender, non-distended. Extremities: warm Skin: no rashes or concerning lesions noted. NEUROLOGIC EXAMINATION: Mental Status: * Degree of Alertness: Alert. Able to relate history without difficulty. * Orientation: Oriented to person, place, day, month, year, situation * Attention: Attentive. Able to name the days of the week forwards and backwards without difficulty. * Memory: Pt able to repeat 3 words immediately and recall ___ unassisted at 5-minute interval, recalled third word easily from verbal list. * Language: Language is fluent without evidence of paraphasic errors. Repetition is intact. Comprehension appears intact; pt able to correctly follow midline and appendicular commands. Prosody is normal. Pt able to name high and low frequency objects without difficulty. Reading and writing abilities intact. * Calculation: Pt able to calculate number of quarters in $1.50 Cranial Nerves: * I: Olfaction not evaluated. * II: PERRL 3 to 2mm and brisk. Visual fields full to confrontation. Visual acuity ___ bilat (but please note that chart was less than ___ue to exam room space constraints). Funduscopic exam sub-optimal. * III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus. * V: Facial sensation intact to light touch in the V1, V2, V3 distributions. * VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric. * VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. * IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. * XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. * XII: Tongue protrudes in midline. Motor: * Bulk: No evidence of atrophy. * Tone: Normal. No evidence of cogwheel rigidity or paratonia. * Drift: No pronator drift bilaterally. * Adventitious Movements: No tremor noted. Strength: * Left Upper Extremity: Delt ___, Biceps ___, Triceps ___, Wrist Ext ___, Wrist Flex ___, Finger Ext ___, Finger Flex ___ * Right Upper Extremity: Delt ___, Biceps ___, Triceps ___, Wrist Ext ___, Wrist Flex ___, Finger Ext ___, Finger Flex ___ * Left Lower Extremity: Iliopsoas ___, Quad ___, Ham ___, Tib Ant ___, Gastroc ___ * Right Lower Extremity: Iliopsoas ___, Quad ___, Ham ___, Tib Ant ___, Gastroc ___ Reflexes: * Left: Biceps 2+, Triceps difficult to obtain, Bracheoradialis 2+, Patellar 2+, Achilles 2+ * Right: Biceps 2+, Triceps difficult to obtain, Brachiradialis 2+, Patellar 2+, Achilles 2+ * Babinski: flexor bilaterally Sensation: * Light Touch: intact bilaterally * Pinprick: intact bilaterally * Temperature: intact to cold sensation bilaterally * Vibration: intact bilaterally Coordination * Tremor: No evidence of resting or intention tremors. * Dysmetria: No evidence bilaterally * Finger-to-nose: normal bilaterally * Heel-to-shin: normal bilaterally * Rapid Alternating Movements: slightly slower on left than right (although pt is right-handed). Gait: * Description: Good initiation. Narrow-based with normal stride and arm-swing * Tandem: Able to tandem walk without difficulty * Romberg: Negative * Unterberger: Negative MANEUVERS: * ___: Negative <PERTINENT RESULTS> CT CNS: No acute intracranial process. Mild mucosal sinus disease as described above. MRI/ MRA: Normal except for hyperdensity in right head of the caudate: old hemorrhage vs. microcalcification vs. iron deposits. No other abnormalitites. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> None <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for r/o TIA. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Labyrinthitis. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Normal at discharge. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You have had an episode of dizziness. You did not have a stroke. Probably you have experienced an episode of laberintitis in the context of your previous URI. You will take aspirin 325 mg per day.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Bactrim <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Menorrhagia <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Diagnostic laparoscopy, total vaginal hysterectomy, cystoscopy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms ___ is a ___ yo presented with menorrhagia. Since about ___ ___ has had increasingly erratic and heavy bleeding. Underwent HSC, D&C, and Mirena placement in ___ which initially was well tolerated. HSC and US showed normal uterus, no fibroids or polyps. Pattern seemingly perimenopausal. Unfortuantely she resumed heavy irregular bleeding and found the side effects of Mirena intolerable, including mood change and terrible bloating and breast tenderness. Discussed other medical options and ablation and she prefers definitive surgical management. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Anxiety states panic disorder - Murmur nl echo, no SBE prophylaxis - Anemia, vitamin B12 deficiency - Headache, migraine occasional aura, N/V - Irritable bowel syndrome - Hypercholesterolemia Past Surgical History: - Tonsillectomy - Delivery - cesarean sect, delivery only C Sect, Delivery Only - Past surgical history of: ___ sinus surgery - Past surgical history of: ___ right toe surgery - Hysteroscopy - endomet bx &/or polypectomy ___ - Insert - iud ___ OB history: ___ Para Term Preterm Abortions TAB SAB Ect Mult Living ___ 3 CS x 1, VBAC x 2. Largest was 7.5 lbs. GYN History Menses irregular and Heavy Bleeding: dysfunctional uterine bleeding Contraception: tubal ligation ___: unknown STDs: no past history Pap history normal paps. Last was ___ Incontinence symptoms urge only. No stress incontinence. Prolapse symptoms none Menopause none <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - Breast Cancer Mother dx'___ in ___; reoccurred in ___, died age ___ - Seizures/Convulsions Brother died week after ___ birthday <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Examination on Discharge: VSS Gen: NAD, comfortable CV: RRR Pulm: CTAB Abd: soft, nondistended, nontender, + BS Ext: warm well pefused, nontender <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Paroxetine 40 mg PO DAILY 2. ClonazePAM 0.5 mg PO DAILY 3. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg IM/SC QWEEK X 4 WEEKS THEN QMONTH 4. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 5. Ibuprofen Dose is Unknown PO Frequency is Unknown <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H: PRN pain RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Paroxetine 40 mg PO DAILY 3. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H: PRN pain 4. ClonazePAM 0.5 mg PO DAILY 5. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg IM/SC QWEEK X 4 WEEKS THEN QMONTH 6. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 7. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-500mg) ___ TAB PO Q6H: PRN pain RX *hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5 mg-500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q6 hours Disp #*50 Tablet Refills: *0 8. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID: PRN constipation RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills: *2 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Menorrhagia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Ms. ___, You were admitted to the GYN service after undergoing the procedures listed below. The team feels that you have recovered well and are ready for discharge. Please follow the below instructions: General instructions: * Take your medications as prescribed. * Do not drive while taking narcotics. * Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to prevent constipation * Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol * Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs * No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment * Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 weeks * No heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 weeks. * You may eat a regular diet Incision care: * You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks. * If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on their own or be removed during your followup visit. To reach medical records to get the records from this hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

Heart remains moderately enlarged. While there is no frank edema, the hila appear slightly congested. Tiny pleural effusions are suspected. No convincing evidence for pneumonia. No pneumothorax. Mediastinal contour is stable. Bony structures are intact. IMPRESSION: Moderate cardiomegaly with mild hilar congestion. Tiny pleural effusions. ECHO ___: The left atrial volume index is moderately increased. The estimated right atrial pressure is at least 15 mmHg. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated. There is an inferobasal left ventricular aneurysm. There is severe global left ventricular hypokinesis with regional variation (inferior free wall is frankly akinetic) (LVEF = 15 %) secondary to global contractile dysfunction and, to a lesser extent, dyssynchrony. A left ventricular apical mass/thrombus cannot be excluded. The right ventricular free wall thickness is normal. The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests a restrictive filling abnormality, with elevated left atrial pressure. The tricuspid regurgitation jet is eccentric and may be underestimated. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. If clinically indicated, a transthoracic study with transpulmonic microbubble contrast is recommended to better define the endocardium of the left ventricle. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, left ventricular contractile function is now severely impaired. B/l ___ VENOUS ULTRASOUND ___: FINDINGS: There is normal compressibility, flow, and augmentation of the bilateral common femoral, femoral, and popliteal veins. Normal color flow and compressibility are demonstrated in the posterior tibial and peroneal veins. There is normal respiratory variation in the common femoral veins bilaterally. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY RX *furosemide 20 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 3. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY RX *lisinopril 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 4. Metoprolol Succinate XL 12.5 mg PO DAILY RX *metoprolol succinate 25 mg 0.5 (One half) tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 5. Warfarin 5 mg PO DAILY16 RX *warfarin 1 mg 5 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*150 Tablet Refills: *0 6. Albuterol Inhaler 1 PUFF IH Q6H: PRN sob, wheezing 7. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 8. Guaifenesin-CODEINE Phosphate ___ mL PO Q8H: PRN COUGH 9. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> 1) Acute systolic heart failure # Left ventricular thrombus # Dyslipidemia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear ___, You were admitted to the hospital because you had been feeling short of breath and you were found to have fluid on your lungs. This was due to a condition called heart failure, where your heart does not pump hard enough and fluid backs up into your lungs. The cause of this is still unclear. Many tests were sent but did not show a clear cause. You were given a diuretic medication through the IV to help get the fluid out. You were also found to have a blood clot in your heart. This was treated with blood thinners. You will continue injections of enoxaparin (Lovenox) until your warfarin (Coumadin) levels come up. When you were ready to leave the hospital, you were set up with a device to monitor your heart. You will follow up closely with our heart failure specialists to continue to manage this issue. WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? - Take all of your medications as prescribed (listed below) - Follow up with your doctors as listed below - Weigh yourself every morning, seek medical attention if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs. - Seek medical attention if you have new or concerning symptoms or you develop swelling in your legs, abdominal distention, or shortness of breath at night. It was a pleasure participating in your care. We wish you the best! -Your ___ Care Team

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> perineal numbness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo RHW recently diagnosed with MS, presents with groin numbness for 4 days. The patient was admitted to ___ ___ for R sided numbness and weakness. The sensation began ___ in the R axilla, on ___ pread to medial arm and down her right torso, on ___ to R leg above the knee, and on ___ involved the entire R leg circumferentially. The numbness was like novacaine, but also with tingling and burning, which was worse in a hot shower. She had some dizziness and weakness in the knees, which may have been related to a panic attack. She was found to also have R arm and leg weakness at ___. She has been ambulating without difficulty since discharge. The most disturbing residual effect is bilateral foot tingling in the soles, which has not improved since discharge. This sensation makes it difficult to walk because it feels like her feet are not her own. Per ___ discharge paperwork, patient was diagnosed with MS. ___ was 5 day course of IV steroids and was prescribed Copaxone, which she has not started because of insurance issues. Discharge exam describes ___ ___ and ___ mild numbness RLE, no other deficits. CSF had 4 WBC, protein 24, glucose 54. MRI spine showed abnormal signal changes C2-3 and C3-4, and T12-L1. MRI brain showed multifocal white matter lesions and ill-defined enhancing focus in L periatrial white matter. The patient now presents with groin numbness for 4 days. On ___, she noticed groin numbness while washing herself in the shower. She noticed that she could not feel herself urinating or defecating, though she had the appropriate urge. No incontinence. She also reports an episode of "vertigo" ___. She was standing and suddenly got the sensation of swaying, then on turning nearly fell over. A similar episode occurred this morning, she felt a sensation of vertical motion while seated. She has also been more fatigued with exertion and diaphoretic. On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending speech. On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or chills. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -liomyoma s/p myomectomy -anxiety attacks -migraines- associated with photophobia, 3x/month, resolves with sleep, takes Aleve <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> negative for MS, autoimmune or thryoid disease, negative for stroke, MI, seizure. Uncle has prostate cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: 97.6 P: 71 R: 16 BP: 149/87 SaO2: 100/RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck: Supple. No nuchal rigidity Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted Abdomen: soft, NT/ND Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP pulses bilaterally. Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. GU: rectal exam demonstrated normal tone Neurologic: -Mental Status: Alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attentive, able to name ___ backward without difficulty. Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension. Normal prosody. There were no paraphasic errors. Pt. was able to name both high and low frequency objects. Able to read without difficulty. Speech was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Pt. was able to register 3 objects and recall ___ at 5 minutes. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: PERRL 4 to 2mm and brisk. No RAPD or red desaturation. VFF to confrontation. Funduscopic exam revealed no papilledema, exudates, or hemorrhages. III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus. Normal saccades. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch. VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric. VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes in midline. -Motor: Normal bulk. Increased tone in bilateral lower extremities. No pronator drift bilaterally. No adventitious movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis noted. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ L 5 ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 R 5- ___ ___ 5 5 5- 5 5 5 -Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick, cold sensation, proprioception throughout extremities torso/back. No extinction to DSS. Decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in S5 dermatome (able to distinguish sharp vs dull). -DTRs: Bi Tri ___ Pat Ach L 2 2 3 3 2 R 2 2 3 3 2 +Hoffmans sign bilaterally, no crossed adduction. Plantar response was flexor bilaterally. -Coordination: No intention tremor, no dysdiadochokinesia noted. No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally. -Gait: Good initiation. Narrow-based, normal stride and arm swing, but hesitant and appears clumsy due to abnormal sensation in soles. Able to walk in tandem without difficulty. Romberg absent. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 04: 15PM GLUCOSE-92 UREA N-15 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-138 POTASSIUM-4.1 CHLORIDE-104 TOTAL CO2-26 ANION GAP-12 ___ 04: 15PM estGFR-Using this ___ 04: 15PM ALT(SGPT)-45* AST(SGOT)-19 ALK PHOS-38 TOT BILI-0.1 ___ 04: 15PM ALBUMIN-4.5 ___ 04: 15PM URINE HOURS-RANDOM ___ 04: 15PM URINE UCG-NEGATIVE ___ 04: 15PM WBC-6.5 RBC-3.69* HGB-10.6* HCT-31.3* MCV-85 MCH-28.8 MCHC-34.0 RDW-13.5 ___ 04: 15PM NEUTS-63.6 ___ MONOS-4.6 EOS-2.4 BASOS-0.3 ___ 04: 15PM PLT COUNT-211 ___ 04: 15PM URINE COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 04: 15PM URINE BLOOD-LG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.5 LEUK-NEG ___ 04: 15PM URINE RBC-15* WBC-<1 BACTERIA-NONE YEAST-NONE EPI-1 ___ 04: 15PM URINE MUCOUS-RARE MRI L spine (preliminary report): IMPRESSION: 1. Multiple focal areas of abnormal signal intensity and a single focus of abnormal enhancement in the visualized lower thoracic cord likely represent demyelinating lesions consistent with known MS. ___ dedicated cervical and thoracic spine MRI may be obtained for further evaluation. 2. Disc herniation at L5-S1 contacting traversing right S1 nerve root as described above. No significant spinal canal or neural foraminal narrowing is seen. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Copaxone <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> Copaxone <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Multiple sclerosis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, ___ were admitted to ___ on ___ for numbness in ___ perineal area. An MRI of your lumbar spine showed a small area of abnormality that was previously seen on your last MRI from ___. There were no new abnormalities to explain your symptoms. Your numbness is likely related to your previously diagnosed MS. ___ should start treatment with Copaxone as planned and follow up with Dr. ___ in clinic. We made no changes to your medications. If ___ experience any of the below listed danger signs, please call your doctor or go to the nearest Emergency Department. It was a pleasure taking care of ___ during your hospital stay.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> DKA <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old female with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with DKA secondary to mechanical failure of her insulin pump. She awoke around 3: 00 this morning with kinking of the tubing of her insulin pump. She has had problems before with her pump and she thought she had resolved it. Her glucometer measured a blood sugar>600 (the limits of her monitor). She also had some confusion and was persistently thirsty despite drinking large amounts of water. Mild nausea without vomiting or abdominal pain. She came to the ED. In the ED, initial vs were: T98.6, ___, BP 119/86, RR 18, O2 Sat 100% on RA. She had a 28 point gap. She was started on an insulin drip improvement in her sugars, started on fluids, and admitted. Review of systems: (+) Per HPI (-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain. Denies rhinorrhea or congestion (had last week). Denied cough, shortness of breath. Denied chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denied diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denied arthralgias or myalgias. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 -Allergic Rhinitis/Asthma -Depression/Anxiety <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Notable for DM, Depression, CAD, Alzheimer's Disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals T 98.4, BP 104/64, HR 58, RR 21, O2 sat 98% Gnl: NAD, Alert and oriented x 3 HEENT: Anicteric, Mucous membranes dry, no JVD CV: RRR, Normal S1 + S2, No murmurs, rubs or gallops Resp: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, No wheezes or crackles Abd: Soft, Nontender, NABS, No hepatosplenomegaly Extremities: No cyanosis, clubbing or edema Skin/nails: No rashes/no jaundice Neuro: AAOx3. Cn II-XII intact. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 10: 15AM GLUCOSE-684* UREA N-24* CREAT-1.2* SODIUM-126* POTASSIUM-5.7* CHLORIDE-90* TOTAL CO2-17* ANION GAP-25* ___ 10: 30AM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-1000 KETONE-50 BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-5.0 LEUK-NEG CXR: AP radiograph of the chest is reviewed without previous studies for comparison. There is no consolidation, pulmonary edema, or pleural fluid. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> -ALBUTEROL Inhaler PRN -CITALOPRAM 60 mg daily -Insulin Lispro by pump -NORGESTREL-ETHINYL ESTRADIOL daily -OMEPRAZOLE - 40 mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Lantus Solostar 300 unit/3 mL Insulin Pen Sig: Fifteen (15) units Subcutaneous at bedtime. Disp: *1 pen* Refills: *2* 2. Humalog KwikPen 100 unit/mL Insulin Pen Sig: Based on carbohydrate counting (1 to 12 ratio) Subcutaneous Before breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Disp: *1 pen* Refills: *2* 3. BD Insulin Pen Needle UF Mini 31 x ___ Needle Sig: N/A Miscellaneous N/A. Disp: *100 needles* Refills: *2* 4. Citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 5. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: Two (2) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 6. Norgestrel-Ethinyl Estradiol 0.3-30 mg-mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO daily (). <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: - Diabetic ketoacidosis Secondary: - Diabetes mellitus, type I <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Hemodynamically stable. Anion gap closed. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ on ___ with DKA due to high blood glucose. You improved quickly in the intensive care unit, and on transfer to the medical floor. Your medication regimen has changed. We ask that you stop using the insulin pump. Instead, you will take Lantus and a Humalog sliding scale based on carbohydrate counting. Please be sure to follow-up with your providers as listed below. Please return to the emergency department or call your physician for blood glucose>400, lightheadedness, nausea, inability to tolerate food or fluids, or for any other symptoms which are concerning to you.
