input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> UROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Tetanus Vaccines & Toxoid / Cipro / prednisone <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Bladder cancer <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Open radical cystectomy, bilateral salpingo-oopherectomy, partial vaginectomy, ileal conduit urinary diversion <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a very pleasant ___ year old Female with a long history of bladder cancer, managed by Dr. ___ at ___. She has had a diagnosis of bladder cancer since at least ___, and has underwent multiple courses of BCG, multiple cystoscopies, and TURBTs. Most recent TURBT was performed on ___, and pathology showed muscle invasive small cell carcinoma of the bladder. Dr. ___ the tumor is relatively small, but the mucosal component was not very significant. It was in the posterior aspect of the bladder. A subsequent CT scan was performed after the TURBT. CT chest did not show any metastases. CT of the abdomen showed a subtle superior bladder plaque, and minimal adjacent extravesical fat, but this was after TURBT. The patient was advised to see me for consideration of radical cystectomy. She is currently asymptomatic. Indeed, she has a bit of of a hard time remembering that she underwent recent surgery. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Bladder cancer Hypothyroidism Hyperlipidemia <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of GU malignancy <PHYSICAL EXAM> WdWn, NAD, AVSS Abdomen soft, appropriately tender along incision Incision is c/d/I Stoma is well perfused; Urine color is yellow Ureteral stents x2 within stoma JP drain has been removed Bilateral lower extremities are warm, dry, well perfused. There is no reported calf pain to deep palpation. No edema or pitting <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD WBC-14.9* RBC-2.45* Hgb-8.0* Hct-24.9* MCV-102* MCH-32.7* MCHC-32.1 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-48.3* Plt ___ ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD ___ PTT-25.6 ___ ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD Glucose-129* UreaN-9 Creat-0.9 Na-141 K-4.8 Cl-107 HCO3-24 AnGap-10 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 3. Levothyroxine Sodium 88 mcg PO DAILY 4. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H as needed for pain 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID to prevent constipation 3. Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC DAILY Duration: 30 Days Start: Today - ___, First Dose: Next Routine Administration Time 4. Nitrofurantoin Monohyd (MacroBID) 100 mg PO DAILY while stents are in place to prevent infection 5. QUEtiapine Fumarate 12.5 mg PO DAILY and once as needed for delirium This can be discontinued when it is no longer medically indicated. 6. Sarna Lotion 1 Appl TP QID: PRN itch 7. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 8. Atorvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 9. Levothyroxine Sodium 88 mcg PO DAILY 10. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Bladder cancer <DISCHARGE CONDITION> WdWn, NAD, AVSS Abdomen soft, appropriately tender along incision Incision is c/d/I Stoma is well perfused; Urine color is yellow Ureteral stents x2 within stoma JP drain has been removed Bilateral lower extremities are warm, dry, well perfused. There is no reported calf pain to deep palpation. No edema or pitting <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> -Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the Ostomy nurse specialist that details the required care and management of your Urostomy -You will be sent home with Visiting Nurse ___ services to facilitate your transition to home, care of your urostomy, Lovenox injections, etc. -Lovenox is an injection that you will use once daily to reduce your risk of dangerous blood clot. Please follow the provided instructions on administration and disposal of syringes/needles ("sharps"). -Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. Always call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor -___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground. --There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have been applied to reinforce wound closure. Allow these bandage strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may get the steristrips wet. -UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED; AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing products and supplements that may have blood-thinning effects (like Fish Oil, Vitamin E, etc.). This will be noted in your medication reconciliation. IF PRESCRIBED (see the MEDICATION RECONCILIATION): -IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You may alternate these medications for pain control. For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, then ibuprofen, and then take the narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief is needed. -Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your stool (dark, tarry stools) -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids to keep hydrated -No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a couch potato -Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___. -Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams from ALL sources -AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up. -No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your Urologist -You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or bathe -Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not operate dangerous machinery -You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener ___ a gentle laxative. These are over-the-counter medications that may be health care spending account reimbursable. -Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative. -Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to further minimize your risk of constipation. -If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or go to the nearest emergency room.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Vancomycin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> IVIG infusion <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with history of AML s/p unrelated alloSCT in ___ c/b GHVD and ESRD presents for elective IVIG infusion. The patient was last admitted from ___ for IVIG and scheduled HD which was tolerated well. In addition, the patient was previously treated with IV vancomycin for staph bacteremia. He completed this course on ___ and was transitioned to minocycline for suppression per ID. In addition, his ruxolitinib was increased from 15mg to 20mg after HD in addition to Vitamin E 100mg TIW. Currently, the patient is feeling well. He has no headache or vision changes. No chest pain or palpitations. No dyspnea. No n/v/d. No fevers/chills. ROS: 10 point review of systems discussed with patient and negative unless noted above <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> ONCOLOGIC HISTORY (PER OMR): ___ has a history of recurrent AML following his matched unrelated allogeneic stem cell transplant in ___. He remains in remission since his DLI with development of extensive sclerodermic GVHD. His severe sclerodermatous GVHD is complicated by multiple lower extremity skin infections requiring debridements and prior admissions for wound care and antibiotics. He has been on amoxicillin and ciprofloxacin for presumed skin colonization as directed by Dr. ___ ___; this was changed based on other antibiotics needs. His GVHD has progressed after receiving various immunesuppressant agents. He was started on ruxolitinib, the Jak 2 inhibitor for his GVHD on ___ as part of Protocol ___: Single patient IND of Ruxolitinib in a single patient, MA, with steroid refractory cGVHD. His dose has been adjusted over time, currently 15 mg following his HD, three times per week. He remains on Prednisone 10mg daily; Sirolimus has been discontinued. ___ other issues have been related to increasing shortness of breath requiring repeated admissions as outlined below. This has been in the setting of infections at times, but evaluation by Pulmonary has also shown worsening severe restrictive and obstructive lung disease, consistent with worsening GVHD of the lungs; this is related to sclerodermic GVHD of the chest wall causing restriction, plus possible bronchiolitis obliterans causing obstruction in the lung itself. He also has been noted for sCHF with reduced EF which contributes to his dyspnea, particularly in the setting of increased fluids. He has been followed by Dr. ___. He was on Torsemide for diuresis but often required IV Lasix when inpatient. ___ required a prolonged admission from ___ - ___ with initial issues of increasing cough, diarrhea, and shortness of breath. He was treated for acute on chronic mixed respiratory failure due to CHF exacerbation and pneumonia, acute renal failure, now with HD dependence on MWF hemodialysis schedule, and MRSA bacteremia (grown from port and HD line). Completed a 4-week course daptomycin with dapto locks. The HD line was ultimately replaced due to dehiscence of the tunneling. He developed an acute episode of respiratory distress requiring MICU admission; he was initiated on BiPAP with improvement in respiratory status, and he continues on this as an outpatient, using at night for the most part and during his dialysis. His renal failure was felt to be multi-factorial in the setting of aggressive diuresis for CHF and later with severe infection and sepsis. This was complicated by uremia/toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. He has not needed further diuretics since starting on HD and his most recent echo on ___ with LVEF of 45-50%. His breathing has been better overall with the dialysis but remains tenuous. He has continued on Pulmicort two puffs twice per day, azithromycin and montelukast. Recent PFT's showed a decrease further in his DLCO with stable Chest CT. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY/ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: * AML -Diagnosed in ___ after having a sore throat, cough and fever. Initially treated with ___ 7+3 regimen with a course complicated by fevers, sinusitis requiring multiple antibiotics, febrile neutropenia, s/p bronchoscopy (all cultures negative), C.Diff colitis, and retinal hemorrhage (from coughing). -Bone marrow biopsy on ___, without remission -Reinduction with MEC. Repeat bone marrow biopsy on day 14 after MEC did not show blasts. -MUD PSCT. Day ___: noted to have 10% peripheral blasts suggestive of clinical relapse; received chemotherapy and then DLI on ___, and remains in remission * Extensive chronic GVHD of skin, liver, mouth, eyes, lungs -Initial response to Prograf, but not prolonged -Started on Enbrel in ___, completed 5 weeks of therapy -Briefly on Gleevec without improvements -___, started on Sprycel, but developed bilateral pleural effusions in ___, so discontinued. -___, started low dose IL-2 SQ on DFCI protocol -Continued on CellCept at tapering doses and prednisone as well as Prograf ___ and discontinued ___, Treg DLI infusion with continued IL-2 injections. Overtime, felt he had received maximum benefit from IL-2 -Enrolled on Abatacept trial for steroid refractory cGVHD and received 1st dose on ___. Received total of 6 doses, last given on ___. Felt he did not have sustained response so taken off study. -Started Sirolimus, ___ with increasing dose based on levels, now 1.5 mg daily -___, started on ruxolitinib, the Jak 2 inhibitor for his GVHD as part of Protocol ___: Single patient IND of Ruxolitinib in a single patient, MA, with steroid refractory cGVHD. -___, Therapeutic Maggot wound therapy through ___, stopped due to increased pain; ___, restarted without issues. Currently on hold. * sCHF with EF ___. Most recent echo, ___ with LVEF 40% * History of RSV in ___ * Depression * C. diff colitis * Parainfluenza ___ * Streptococcal pneumoniae bacteremia in ___. * ___, admitted with fever, chills and worsening cough with MSSA pneumonia and bacteremia presumably from his leg wounds. * Recurrent skin infections related to his skin changes and breakdown with necrosis and bacterial overgrowth on the skin and has been on intermittent courses of oral antibiotics, including Keflex and Doxycycline with courses in ___ and ___. Improved over ___ with more recent admissions for skin ulcerations. Followed by Dermatology here at ___ and the Wound care team. Currently on Ciprofloxacin and Amoxicillin. Needs to establish dermatology care as Dr. ___ longer at ___. * ___, Admitted with pseudomonas skin infection. Treated with antibiotics with change in wound care. * Severe hypogammaglobulinemia receiving IVIG. * ___, Admitted with pseudomonas skin infection, treated with IV Cefepime. * ___, Readmitted for increased skin infections, treated with antibiotics and changed dressings to twice per day. * ___, Admitted at OSH for UTI. * ___, Readmitted for wound care and recurrent skin infections. * ___, Readmitted for wound care and recurrent skin infections. Treated with IV antibiotics and completed course of Ciprofloxacin. * ___ and ___, admitted for increased foot pain, antibiotics, and wound care. * ___, admitted with fever, chills, dyspnea, and cough and noted for pneumonia. Treated with IV antibiotics. D/C ___. * ___, admitted for increased foot pain, antibiotics and wound care. * ___, admitted twice during month with exacerbation of his GVHD of lower extremities with superimposed pseudomonas infection. Treated with IV antibiotics and had his dressing care changed; started on Cipro and Amoxicillin. * ___, admission for GI illness with diarrhea and vomiting. * ___ - ___, received Abatacept on study, total 6 doses; off study in ___. * ___ - ___, admitted for pain control and wound care. * ___ - ___, admitted for increasing shortness of breath with continued wound care. No pulmonary embolism, but chest CT was concerning for HCAP, treated with antibiotics. Repeat PFTs showed worsening severe restrictive & obstructive lung disease, consistent with worsening GVHD of the lungs. Prednisone was increased with tapering back to dose of 25 mg of prednisone. * ___, started on ruxolitinib, the Jak 2 inhibitor for his GVHD as part of Protocol ___: Single patient IND of Ruxolitinib in a single patient, MA, with steroid refractory cGVHD. * ___, Admitted for shortness of breath and possible pneumonia noted on Chest CT. Underwent bronchoscopy with complication of pneumothorax. Noted for drop in EF. * CHF, with noted drop in EF; evaluated by cardiology. Cardiac MRI with improved EF; no evidence for restrictive pericarditis. * ___, admitted with pneumonia and increased shortness of breath. * ___ - ___, admitted with fever, nausea, weakness and increased drainage from skin lesions. * ___ - ___, admitted with fever and cough. Treated with antibiotics and IVIG. * ___ - ___, admitted with malaise. No etiology for symptoms. * ___ - ___, admitted with shortness of breath. Chest CT improved and no infectious etiology noted. * ___, admitted for shortness of breath, hypoxia with noted probable pneumonia, CHF. Improved with antibiotics, and diuresis. Discharged on daily Torsemide. * ___ - ___, Admitted with fever, cough, with noted hypoxia. Found to have RSV pneumonia and required intubation with ICU support due to respiratory compromise. Treated with antibiotics, diuresis, and palivizumab for RSV. * ___ - ___, Admitted with fever. Infectious work up essentially negative. * ___ - ___, Admitted with increased lower extremity pain and erythema. Noted for pseudomonas bacteremia. Treated with Ciprofloxacin. Required ICU stay. Also noted HAP. * ___ - ___, Admitted with fevers and chills. Source of infection felt related to chronic leg wounds with pseudomonas colonization. Treated with IV antibiotics and transitioned to oral antibiotics. * ___ - ___, Admitted with shortness of breath with exacerbation of CHF with volume overload. Aggressively diuresed * ___ - ___, Admitted due to increase in cough and not feeling well with no source of infection found. * ___ - ___, Admitted with fever and noted for E. coli bacteremia. In setting of IV antibiotics and IV fluids, developed dyspnea. With diuresis, addition of Ace inhibitor and antibiotics, developed renal failure. Improved over time. * ___ - ___. Admitted to ___ service with increasing shortness of breath. Managed with diuretics and was discharged on Torsemide 50 mg BID which was then increased as an outpatient. * ___ - ___, admitted to the FICU for hypercarbic respiratory failure likely multifactorial but ultimately felt to be secondary to severe hypoventilation from restricted chest wall movement from fibrotic tissue disease ___ GVHD, coronavirus infection and acute heart failure exacerbation. Diuresed with IV Lasix and then transitioned to torsemide and discharged on 100 mg daily along with home oxygen to use as needed. * ___ - ___, admitted with increasing cough, diarrhea, and shortness of breath. He was treated for acute on chronic mixed respiratory failure due to CHF exacerbation and pneumonia, acute renal failure, now with HD dependence, and MRSA bacteremia. * ___ - ___, admitted with shortness of breath and cough. Noted for PE, now on Apixaban. No evidence of DVT's in lower legs. * ___ - ___, planned admission for IVIG prior to HD. Treated for cellulitis on left arm. - ___ - ___: Planned admission for IVIG prior to HD. - ___ - ___: Planned admission for IVIG prior to HD. * ___ - ___, admitted with left hand swelling, pain, and increased erythema. Treated for cellulitis. ___ - ___, Admission for IVIG and HD but discharge delayed with fever; no etiology found. Given Doxycycline for antibiotic. ___ - ___, Admission for fever and cough. Treated with antibiotics but then discontinued as felt more viral. ___ - ___, Admission for a high fever, found to have MRSA bacteremia. Gave Zosyn + Started on IV vancomycin as well as Vancomycin locks with course end date of ___. Has been receiving vancomycin during HD days on ___. Fexofenadine prior to each dose to prevent red man's. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY (PER OMR): - Cardiomyopathy with EF 30% - ESRD - Chronic Sinus Tachycardia - Pericarditis in ___ as a complication of his allo-BMT - Hypothyroidism - GERD - Depression/Anxiety - History of RSV in ___ - C. Diff Colitis - Parainfluenza in ___ - Streptococcal pneumoniae bacteremia in ___ - MSSA pneumonia and bacteremia presumably from his leg wounds in ___ - Recurrent skin infections related to his skin changes and breakdown with necrosis and bacterial overgrowth on the skin and has been on intermittent courses of oral antibiotics, including Keflex and Doxycycline with courses in ___ and ___. Improved over ___ with more recent admissions for skin ulcerations. Followed by Dermatology here at ___ and the Wound care team. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father with a history of myocardial infarction/coronary artery disease. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission ========= VITALS: T 98.2 BP 144/92 HR 108 R 18 SpO2 98 Ra GENERAL: NAD HEENT: Clear OP without lesions EYES: PERRL, anicteric NECK: supple RESP: no increased WOB, faint, end expiratory wheezing b/l ___: RRR no MRG GI: Hard due to overlying sclerosis EXT: warm, sclerotic skin SKIN: multiple patches of sclerotic skin, RLE wrapped in ___ NEURO: CN II-XII intact ACCESS: R POC and LIJ HD line Discharge ========== VITALS: ___ 0923 Temp: 98.1 PO BP: 140/91 HR: 85 RR: 18 GENERAL: NAD HEENT: Clear OP without lesions EYES: PERRL, anicteric NECK: supple RESP: no increased WOB, faint, end expiratory wheezing b/l ___: RRR no MRG GI: Hard due to overlying sclerosis EXT: warm, sclerotic skin SKIN: multiple patches of sclerotic skin, RLE wrapped in ___ NEURO: CN II-XII intact ACCESS: R POC and LIJ HD line <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 05: 15AM BLOOD WBC-9.0 RBC-2.85* Hgb-9.6* Hct-29.8* MCV-105* MCH-33.7* MCHC-32.2 RDW-15.4 RDWSD-58.8* Plt ___ ___ 05: 15AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 05: 15AM BLOOD Glucose-94 UreaN-27* Creat-1.5* Na-144 K-3.5 Cl-103 HCO3-26 AnGap-15 ___ 05: 15AM BLOOD Calcium-8.5 Phos-3.9 Mg-2.2 Blood culture from HD line x2 pending <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ ___. WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL? - You were admitted for IVIG WHAT HAPPENED TO ME IN THE HOSPITAL? - You had IVIG and HD without complication WHAT SHOULD I DO AFTER I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? - Continue to take all your medicines and keep your appointments. We wish you the best! Sincerely, Your ___ Team Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> SOB <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year old ___ s/p repeat LTCS on ___ who presents to L&D from ___ with elevated blood pressures and SOB. Of note, patient has elevated blood pressures post-partum for which she was started on Labetalol and this was titrated up to 600mg PO TID. The patient reports that her SOB initially began on ___ and has gradually worsened. She endorses orthopnea throughout the pregnancy requiring her to sleep on three pillows. Since discharge she has experienced several episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Also endorses dyspnea on exertion. She denies any HA, chest pain, palpitations, visual changes or RUQ pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> OBHx: -___ SVD @ term, ___, girl, 5.5#, no comps during pregnancy or delivery, had elevated BP postpartum no meds. -___ SVD @ term, ___, girl, 7#, no comps during pregnancy, delivery, or PP. No HTN. -___ LTCS @ term for ___ and ___ stage arrest, ___, boy, #7, had ___, required anti-hypertensives x 2 weeks postpartum. -TAB x 3 first trimester, no complications GYNhx: had LSIL Pap during this pregnancy at ___ -> for colpo PP no STIs PMH: Denies PSH: LTCS D&C <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> <PHYSICAL EXAM> T: 98.9 HR: 97 BP: 150/91-> 137/93 RR: 25 O2: 96-97%RA CV: RRR Pulm: Decreased breath sounds bilaterally at the bases. Slight crackles at the bases. No wheezing, Abd: Obese, Soft, + BS, NT, No guarding or rebound, incision C/D/I Ext: 1+ edema B/L to mid-shin, DTR 2+ B/L, non-tender <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 10: 27AM WBC-6.7 RBC-3.68* HGB-8.9* HCT-26.3* MCV-72* MCH-24.1* MCHC-33.6 RDW-18.0* ___ 10: 27AM PLT COUNT-316 ___ 10: 27AM CREAT-0.6 ___ 10: 27AM ALT(SGPT)-21 AST(SGOT)-22 ___ 10: 27AM URIC ACID-5.3 ___ 10: 27AM URINE BLOOD-MOD NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-7.5 LEUK-NEG ___ 10: 27AM URINE RBC-0 WBC-1 BACTERIA-NONE YEAST-NONE EPI-1 ___ 10: 27AM URINE COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 10: 27AM proBNP-1326* ECHO ___: Pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Normal biventricular cavity sizes with preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation with normal valve morphology. Dilated aortic arch. These findings are suggestive of a primary pulmonary process (e.g., obstructive sleep apnea, pulmonary embolism, bronchospasm, etc.). CXR ___: Enlargement of the cardiac silhouette with prominence of pulmonary vessels. Some prominence of the azygos vein. There is opacification at the left base that most likely represents combination of small pleural effusion and atelectasis. CTA ___: Allowing for respiratory motion, no large or central pulmonary embolus seen. Mild cardiac enlargement and pulmonary artery is at upper limits of normal. Patchy, predominantly central airspace consolidation in the right lung, non-specific, but may be due to infection or pneumonitis. Small hiatal hernia. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Labetalol 600 TID Colace ibuprofen percocet <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Nifedipine 30 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Tablet Sustained Release(s)* Refills: *2* 2. Labetalol 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> pulmonary edema hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted with shortness of breath and high blood pressures. For your shortness of breath, you were given 2 doses of lasix with much improvement in your symptoms. You had an ECHO (ultrasound of your heart) which showed high blood pressures in your lungs but was otherwise normal. You had a CT scan of your chest which showed no evidence of a blood clot but did show a little fluid in your lungs. For your hypertension, we treated you with nifedipine and labetalol. Please continue to take these medications as prescribed. Call for shortness of breath, headache, visual changes, upper abdominal pain.

Sertraline 150 mg PO DAILY 18. umeclidinium 62.5 mcg/actuation inhalation DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: bladder cancer, muscle invasive Secondary: Acute kidney injury due to hypovolemia/dehydration Acute kidney injury due to major surgical procedure and manipulation of the ureters and kidney (s) <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> -Please also refer to the instructions provided to you by the Ostomy nurse specialist that details the required care and management of your Urostomy -You will be sent home with Visiting Nurse ___ services to facilitate your transition to home, care of your urostomy, Lovenox injections, etc. -You will have home infusion services to reduce risk of dehydration. -Lovenox is an injection that you will use once daily to reduce your risk of dangerous blood clot. Please follow the provided instructions on administration and disposal of syringes/needles ("sharps"). -Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. Always call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor -___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision sites; remember to log roll onto your side and then use your hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground. --There may be bandage strips called steristrips which have been applied to reinforce wound closure. Allow these bandage strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may get the steristrips wet. -IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You may alternate these medications for pain control. For pain control, alternate ACETAMINOPHEN (AKA Tylenol) and IBUPROFEN. -Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your stool (dark, tarry stools) -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids to keep hydrated -No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a couch potato -Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE grams from ALL sources -AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up. -No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS from surgery or until you are cleared by your Urologist -You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or bathe -You may be given prescriptions for a stool softener and/or a gentle laxative. These are over-the-counter medications that may be health care spending account reimbursable. -Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative. -Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to further minimize your risk of constipation. -If you have fevers > ___ F, vomiting, or increased redness, swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or go to the nearest emergency room.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> Paxil / tramadol <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> right hip OA <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> right hip replacement ___, ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old female with right hip OA s/p right THA. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: HTN, h/o skin carcinoma, h/o broken right ankle @ ___ years old PSH: tubal ligation, ectopic pregnancy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Well appearing in no acute distress Afebrile with stable vital signs Pain well-controlled Respiratory: CTAB Cardiovascular: RRR Gastrointestinal: NT/ND Genitourinary: Voiding independently Neurologic: Intact with no focal deficits Psychiatric: Pleasant, A&O x3 Musculoskeletal Lower Extremity: * Incision healing well with staples * Thigh full but soft * No calf tenderness * ___ strength * SILT, NVI distally * Toes warm <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 50AM BLOOD Hgb-11.0* Hct-34.4 ___ 07: 50AM BLOOD Creat-0.6 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> 1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 2. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO DAILY 3. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin EC 325 mg PO BID 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 3. Gabapentin 100 mg PO TID 4. HYDROcodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate 5. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H Continue while on 4-week course of Aspirin 325 mg twice daily. 6. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 7. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO DAILY 8. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> right hip OA <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by your physician. 8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Aspirin 325 mg twice daily for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). Continue Pantoprazole daily while on Aspirin to prevent GI upset (x 4 weeks). If you were taking Aspirin prior to your surgery, take it at 325 mg twice daily until the end of the 4 weeks, then you can go back to your normal dosing. 9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by ___ in two weeks. 10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, wound checks. 11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. Mobilize. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Mobilize frequently. Physical Therapy: WBAT RLE Posterior hip precautions x 6 weeks from date of surgery Wean assistive devices as able (i.e., 2 crutches, walker) Mobilize frequently Treatments Frequency: daily dressing changes as needed for drainage wound checks daily ice staple removal and replace on POD14-17 at ___

Improved with 10 minutes of rest, not present at rest. Not better or worse with flexion. A few days after onset of pain he noticed swelling of his left foot which has now extended up to his hip. Discharge: . ___ 05: 55AM BLOOD WBC-6.8 RBC-4.71 Hgb-14.4 Hct-41.4 MCV-88 MCH-30.7 MCHC-34.9 RDW-14.3 Plt ___ ___ 06: 29AM BLOOD ___ ___ 05: 55AM BLOOD Glucose-97 UreaN-16 Creat-1.2 Na-137 K-4.7 Cl-104 HCO3-26 AnGap-12 ___ 06: 22AM BLOOD Calcium-8.9 Phos-3.2 Mg-2.1 . Multiplanar reformations were obtained and reviewed. The partially imaged lungs show mild bibasilar atelectasis. The partially imaged heart is unremarkable. CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST: The liver, spleen, both adrenals, both kidneys, pancreas and gallbladder are unremarkable. No abdominal free fluid or free air is present. The small and large bowel loops are unremarkable. No abdominal, retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy by CT size criteria is present. CT OF THE PELVIS WITH IV CONTRAST: The rectum, sigmoid colon, seminal vesicles and prostate are unremarkable. There is asymmetric thickening of the left wall of the bladder (3: 164) which likely represents a combination of bladder cancer and effects of x-ray therapy. There is a clot in the left external iliac vein measuring 2 cm in longitudinal axis (3: 158). No other area of venous clot is noted. No evidence of ___ syndrome is noted either. The right internal iliac vein is unremarkable. No pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy or pelvic free fluid is present. OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: The visible osseous structures show no suspicious lytic or blastic lesions or fractures. IMPRESSION: Left external iliac vein clot measuring 2 cm in longitudinal axis. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> AMLODIPINE 10 mg daily LOVASTATIN 80 mg qhs METOPROLOL TARTRATE 50mg BID MVI daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Deep vein thrombosis Secondary: Transitional bladder cell carcinoma Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ with left leg swelling, pain, and redness. Though initial ultrasounds of your leg did not show blood clots in the lower leg, a CT scan of your pelvis revealed a 2-cm clot in your external iliac vein. You may have a higher tendency to form clots given your history of cancer and radiation to your bladder. We started you on a blood thinning medication called Coumadin (Warfarin) which you will continue for 6 months. Your INR level is a measure of how well your blood is being thinned and your goal level is ___. You will need to have this checked frequently and your dose adjusted accordingly. Until you INR level is therapeutic, you should continue to take Lovenox injections twice daily as you have been doing in the hospital. You will have your bloodwork checked on ___. You will follow with your PCP and Dr. ___ at the dates/times below. We have made the following changes to your medications: - Take Lovenox injections (110mg) at 8am and 8pm every day until your INR is ___ - Take Coumadin 10mg daily and get your INR level measured frequently - Continue the rest of your home medications

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> tramadol <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Pneumothorax <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Right lower lobe core needle biopsy and fiduciary placement <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms ___ is a ___ woman with history of hypertension and bilateral non small cell lung cancer s/p multiple RFA sessions and systemic chemo/radiation who presents from the radiology unit for overnight monitoring after a high-risk lung biopsy complicated by a small pneumothorax. For a full detailed history of the patient's lung cancer, please see ___ note from ___. In brief, most recently in ___, the patient had a CT chest which showed a 1.3 x 1.0 cm right lower lobe lung nodule, increased from 1.0 x 0.4 cm, thought to be most likely bronchogenic carcinoma. On ___ the patient had a CT guided RFA of this lesion. The procedure was complicated by a small amount of hemorrhage, and a small pneumothorax, so a biopsy of the lesion was not obtained. Ms. ___ was admitted to ___ from ___ to ___ with respiratory failure after the RFA. She was treated with Levaquin for pneumonia. Her oxygenation improved and she was discharged to ___ in ___, where she stayed for two weeks. A follow up CT with contrast on ___ showed a cavitary nodule in the medial RLL significantly increased to 3.4 x 3.7 cm compared with 2.3 cm with central low density suggesting necrosis. The nodule abutted the esophagus and posterior pericardium without definite evidence of invasion. Given the location of the patient's lesion, it was not felt to be amenable to a wedge resection, but would rather require a basal segmentectomy. However, it was also thought to be amenable to CyberKnife SBRT which would require biopsy and fiducial marker placement. On ___, she underwent outpatient biopsy & fiducial placement of RLL lung mass. 4 core biopsy samples were sent for pathology, and 10cc of purulent fluid were sent for microbiology. A CT showed a small paramediastinal pneumothorax post-procedure, with follow up CXRs at 2 and 4 hours post procedure showing resolution of the PTX. Clinically, she has been stable on room air. Upon arrival to the floor, the patient reports that her breathing is at baseline with no shortness of breath. She states that the procedure was quite painful, but that she no longer has any pain. She has no chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations or other complaints, and is hopeful that she will be able to go home early tomorrow. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - Age-related macular degeneration - GERD - Hyperlipidemia - Prior removal of a vocal cord polyp - Hypertension - Lung cancer - Squamous cell cancer on the face - Left bundle branch block PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: - s/p squamous cell cancer removal from face - s/p vocal cord polyp removal <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> son died of met CA, daughter healthy Physical ___: ADMISSION EXAM: -== VITALS: 97.3PO148 / 79 HR: 70RR: 20O2: 96RA GENERAL: Alert and interactive. In no acute distress. Lying comfortably in bed, no eye contact (legally blind) HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. NECK: No cervical lymphadenopathy. No JVD. CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate. ___ systolic late peaking crescendo-decrescendo murmur radiating to carotids. Carotid upstroke was brisk and not delayed. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally w/appropriate breath sounds appreciated in all fields. No wheezes, rhonchi or rales. No increased work of breathing. BACK: Dressing in mid right back over site of biopsy was clean dry and intact. ABDOMEN: Normal bowels sounds, non distended, non-tender to deep palpation in all four quadrants. No organomegaly. EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Pulses DP/Radial 2+ bilaterally. Tenderness to palpation of bilateral lower extremities which the patient states is normal and at her baseline. NEUROLOGIC: CN2-12 intact. ___ strength throughout. Normal sensation. AOx3. Discharge Exam: VITALS: 97.___ HR: 70RR: 20O2: 96RA GENERAL: Alert and interactive. In no acute distress. Lying comfortably in bed, no eye contact (legally blind) HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. NECK: No cervical lymphadenopathy. No JVD. BACK: Dressing in mid right back over site of biopsy was clean dry and intact. ABDOMEN: Normal bowels sounds, non distended, non-tender to deep palpation in all four quadrants. No organomegaly. EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Pulses DP/Radial 2+ bilaterally. Tenderness to palpation of bilateral lower extremities which the patient states is normal and at her baseline. NEUROLOGIC: CN2-12 intact. ___ strength throughout. Normal sensation. AOx3. Discharge Exam: VITALS: Per OMR GENERAL: Alert and interactive. In no acute distress. Lying comfortably in bed, no eye contact (legally blind) HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. NECK: No cervical lymphadenopathy. No JVD. NEUROLOGIC: CN2-12 intact. ___ strength throughout. Normal sensation. AOx3. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: -== ___ 09: 35PM BLOOD WBC-8.9 RBC-3.12* Hgb-9.3* Hct-27.8* MCV-89 MCH-29.8 MCHC-33.5 RDW-13.8 RDWSD-44.9 Plt ___ ___ 09: 35PM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-23* Creat-1.1 Na-141 K-4.0 Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-12 PERTINENT STUDIES: -= CXR ___: No pneumothorax appreciated. No significant change compared to the prior study. DISCHARGE LABS: -== ___ 05: 05AM BLOOD WBC-8.3 RBC-3.25* Hgb-9.5* Hct-29.0* MCV-89 MCH-29.2 MCHC-32.8 RDW-13.4 RDWSD-43.7 Plt ___ ___ 05: 05AM BLOOD Glucose-97 UreaN-20 Creat-1.0 Na-142 K-4.3 Cl-106 HCO3-24 AnGap-12 <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? - You had a biopsy of your right lower lung - After the biopsy you had a small collapse of a part of your lung WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS HERE? - You had repeat imaging of your chest - This showed that the small area of collapse had improved - Your breathing remained stable while you were here and you were discharged home WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I LEAVE? - Please take all of your medications as prescribed - Please go to all of your follow up appointments as arranged for you It was a pleasure to care for you during your hospital stay. Your ___ Medicine Team

Home # Lower GI bleed - resolved # h/o colon cancer # asthma # lyme disease (presumed based on your deer tick bite) stable ___ You were admitted to observe your noted prior bright blood from your rectum - as you know you did not re-bleed here - your blood counts remained stable - and your volume status was stable at time of discharge (us checking your blood pressures while standing up).
Please resume all your prior home medications INCLUDING your doxycycline for your presumed lyme disease treatment - AND importantly call your gastroenterologist immediately as below to set-up a follow-up evaluation.
If your bleeding re-starts - please call your provider ___ gastroenterologists for further instructions - if worsenes, feeling new lightheadedness/dizziness sx - or any other concerning symptom like shortness of breath, chest pain, new fevers - please return to the hospital for further evaluation.

He is s/p 2 ECT treatments ___ today). Pt has a significant somatic focus primarily on nausea, which he has had since age ___ and which is associated with his depression. Pt reports that he has a ___ history of intractable nausea associated with depressive symptoms. Nausea is also exacerbated by anxiety. He is upset that he cannot throw up. Pt considers himself a worrier and a "nervous person" and thinks his nausea might be related to his anxiety. Last night his nausea was worse than ever before and this led him to feel like life is not worth living if he continues to feel that way. Pt no longer feels like he wants to end his life and states,"I don't want to die." However he is worried that he will have another bout of nausea and will feel suicidal again and go through with it. His plan was CO poisoning via car in garage. He still enjoys playing golf and landscaping his property. He does not have any close friends and is satisfied with this. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> -Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - take this discharge paperwork to your appointments. -Please continue all medications as directed. -Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen your medical and psychiatric illnesses. -Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers if you have any concerns. -Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your health care providers. *It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you the best of health.*

He is s/p 2 ECT treatments ___ today). Pt has a significant somatic focus primarily on nausea, which he has had since age ___ and which is associated with his depression. Pt reports that he has a ___ history of intractable nausea associated with depressive symptoms. Nausea is also exacerbated by anxiety. He is upset that he cannot throw up. Pt considers himself a worrier and a "nervous person" and thinks his nausea might be related to his anxiety. Last night his nausea was worse than ever before and this led him to feel like life is not worth living if he continues to feel that way. Pt no longer feels like he wants to end his life and states,"I don't want to die." However he is worried that he will have another bout of nausea and will feel suicidal again and go through with it. His plan was CO poisoning via car in garage. He still enjoys playing golf and landscaping his property. He does not have any close friends and is satisfied with this. Pt feels his major source of distress is his nausea and GI discomfort. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Chronic nausea, not responsive to treatment, ___ BPH Past Psych History -Dx: depression -Hospitalizations: none -SA/SI: no SA. Hx passive SI -Harm to others: denies -Medication/ECT trials: many medications including multiple tricyclics, MAOI (current). Now trying first round of ECT -Treaters: Psychiatrist: Dr. ___ @ ___ Dr. ___ ECT -___: denies Pt recalls specifically when his symptoms began - including the exact setting and location when his nausea began (he was eating a dinner with his parents and a lady friend). He correlates this nausea with his depression - he is often depressed about the nausea. He also correlates nausea to anxiety. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> B/R in ___, then ___. Currently lives in ___. Never married; no children. No close friends or close social supports. Has a sister and niece in ___. Spends time playing golf, taking care of his home, landscaping his yard, watching sports. Does not have much social contact. Has MS in biology from ___. Worked for the ___ x ___ years. Retired x ___ years. <PHYSICAL EXAM> General- well nourished elderly male sitting comfortably in NAD Skin- warm, dry, tan HEENT- NCAT, moist mucosa, no ulcerations, deformities or masses Neck and Back- neck supple, no LAD, back w/no sig deformity or focal tenderness Lungs- CTAB, no crackles, wheezes, or rhonchi CV- RRR, no m/r/g Abdomen: soft, nondistended, NTTP, NABS Extremities- no c/c/e, wwp Neuro- Cranial Nerves- I: Not tested II: PERRLA III, IV, VI: EOMI w/o nystagmus V, VII: Facial strength and sensation intact and symmetric. Makes eye contact with interviewer infrequently. *Speech: slow, with many pauses. Prosody is minimal. *Behavior: cooperative with psychomotor retardation. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> tacrolimus <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> symptomatic splenomegaly <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Splenic artery Embolization ___ pseudoaneurysm embolization ___ ERCP with stent <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ yo male s/p liver transplant on ___ for NASH cirrhosis who is presenting today as a planned admission for pain control after a mid-pole splenic embolization for symptomatic splenomegaly. His post transplant course has been complicated by significant immunodeficiency, pancytopenia derived from thalassemia, pyruvate kinase deficiency and a profound splenomegaly. Mr. ___ was hospitalized recently for a pneumonia likely developed in the setting of immunodeficiency as well as sinusitis. He was treated with IV vancomycin, Zosyn, erythromycin and ceftriaxone for a total of seven days. He has been getting weekly aranesp shots by hematology. He is currently on CSA 100mg BID and Creat 2.5-3.0.m PLT count is 37, so he required 2u FFP prior to the procedure today. On presentation, Mr. ___ denies any pain (abdominal, groin, or otherwise), nausea, vomiting, fevers, chills, headaches, chest pain, diarrhea, or constipation. He does endorse some SOB, however, this has been stable for years. He is voiding and stooling normally. This morning he took 6u of Lantus instead of his normal dose of 12u, otherwise he took all of his medications as prescribed. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. ___ cirrhosis complicated by mild ascites, portal hypertension in the form esophageal varices and splenomegaly. - S/p variceal bleed s/p banding ___ - S/p TIPS ___ and TIPS redo/downsize ___ d/t recurrent hepatic encephalopathy and TIPS stenosis - S/p OLT ___ from ___ year old ABO compatible standard criteria brain dead donor 2. S/p OLT ___: No history of rejection, no history of BK, high CMV risk D+/R-. On tacrolimus monotherapy. For PPX he is on atovoquone from Bactrim due to persistent leukopenia. 2. Pyruvate kinase deficiency, complicated by chronic hemolysis. 3. Cholelithiasis, likely related to pigment stones from chronic hemolysis. 4. Beta thalassemia. 5. History of iron deficiency on iron supplementation. 6. Diabetes mellitus, on insulin. 7. History of migraines. 8. Chronic back pain and leg pain status post fall in ___. 9. Gout. 10. History of right cheek basal cell carcinoma excised in ___. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> There is a family history of thalassemia trait and arthritis. There is no family history of liver disease or GI cancers. No famly history of CAD/MI. <PHYSICAL EXAM> P/E: VS: T: 97.2 P: 59 BP: 162/76 RR: 18 O2sat: 95 RA GEN: WD, WN in NAD HEENT: NCAT, anicteric, MMM, EOMI CV: RRR PULM: non-labored, no respiratory distress ABD: soft, NT, ND, no mass, +splenomegaly. 1.5 cm incisional hernia present. L inguinal hernia present. Groin: R groin puncture site with angioseal present over top. no swelling present, area slightly tender to palpation. minimal shadowing present on dressing. EXT: WWP, 2+ radial pulses, palpable femoral pulses b/l and palpable DP pulse b/l. NEURO: A&Ox3, no focal neurologic deficits <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 07: 43AM BLOOD WBC-2.3* RBC-3.11* Hgb-7.1* Hct-23.6* MCV-76* MCH-22.8* MCHC-30.1* RDW-17.1* RDWSD-47.3* Plt Ct-28* ___ 07: 43AM BLOOD ___ ___ 07: 43AM BLOOD Creat-3.0* ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Glucose-103* UreaN-32* Creat-2.7* Na-139 K-4.7 Cl-109* HCO3-18* AnGap-17 ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD ALT-20 AST-51* AlkPhos-54 TotBili-2.4* DirBili-1.4* IndBili-1.0 ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Calcium-7.8* Phos-3.3 Mg-1.3* ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Cyclspr-64* Discharge Labs: ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD WBC-6.1# RBC-3.32* Hgb-8.2* Hct-24.9* MCV-75* MCH-24.7* MCHC-32.9 RDW-18.6* RDWSD-49.2* Plt Ct-44* ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.2 ___ ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD Glucose-120* UreaN-40* Creat-3.0* Na-136 K-5.4* Cl-106 HCO3-14* AnGap-21* ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD ALT-<5 AST-8 AlkPhos-56 Amylase-25 TotBili-5.0* ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD Calcium-8.0* Phos-3.8 Mg-1.7 ___ 06: 08AM BLOOD Cyclspr-122 ___ 05: 58AM BLOOD Cyclspr-125 ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD Cyclspr-197 ___ 05: 46AM BLOOD Hapto-49 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. CycloSPORINE (Neoral) MODIFIED 100 mg PO Q12H 2. Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH Q4H: PRN sob/wheeze/cough 3. Atovaquone Suspension 1500 mg PO DAILY 4. Nephrocaps 1 CAP PO DAILY 5. Aranesp (in polysorbate) (darbepoetin alfa in polysorbat) 100 mcg/0.5 mL injection 1X/WEEK ___ 6. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (MO) 7. Filgrastim 300 mcg SC PRN: AS DIRECTED BY TRANSPLANT CLINIC neutropenia 8. Fludrocortisone Acetate 0.1 mg PO 3X/WEEK (___) 9. FoLIC Acid 4 mg PO DAILY 10. Glargine 12 Units Breakfast Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin 11. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO BID 12. Ondansetron 8 mg PO DAILY: PRN nausea. takes prior to am meds 13. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H 14. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 2 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *hydromorphone 2 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*10 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Glargine 12 Units Breakfast Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin 3. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours 4. Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH Q4H: PRN sob/wheeze/cough 5. Aranesp (in polysorbate) (darbepoetin alfa in polysorbat) 100 mcg/0.5 mL injection 1X/WEEK ___ 6. Atovaquone Suspension 1500 mg PO DAILY 7. CycloSPORINE (Neoral) MODIFIED 100 mg PO Q12H 8. Filgrastim 300 mcg SC PRN: AS DIRECTED BY TRANSPLANT CLINIC neutropenia 9. Fludrocortisone Acetate 0.1 mg PO 3X/WEEK (___) 10. FoLIC Acid 4 mg PO DAILY 11. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO BID 12. Nephrocaps 1 CAP PO DAILY 13. Ondansetron 8 mg PO DAILY: PRN nausea. takes prior to am meds 14. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H 15. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (MO) <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Symptomatic Splenomegaly s/p splenic artery embolization. anemia ___ nephropathy <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please have your labs drawn tomorrow, ___ MEDICATION: - Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed - You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any post procedure pain or discomfort WHAT TO EXPECT: - It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time - Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals - It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing - To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet ACTIVITIES: - When you go home, you may walk and use stairs - You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, rinse and pat dry) - The groin puncture site may be left uncovered, unless you have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or band aid over the area - No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) - No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ - Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities - Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours - New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or green drainage from incisions - Bleeding from groin puncture site SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site) - Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call Interventional Radiology office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> aspirin / shellfish derived <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Leg pain, scrotal pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis (6.5L removed; ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o male with h/o IVDU, homelessness, HCV, cirrhosis, ascites, BLE cellulitis x 6 months, poor compliance with care and multiple prior AMA departures from outside hospitals. Presented as OSH ED transfer with worsening of his preexisting cellulitis and two days of scrotal induration, erythema, and tenderness. Exam notable for severe edema, induration, exquisite tenderness of scrotum but no appreciable crepitus. Labs obtained at OSH ED notable for WBC 9.7, Cr 0.58. CT scan with soft tissue swelling but no gas. Urology consulted in the ED and favored cellulitis over necrotizing soft tissue infection (___). Recommended admission, close clinical monitoring with serial ___ exams, broad spectrum abx (guided by prior cultures from OSH if possible). R IJ TLC placed in ED. In the ED, initial vital signs were: 98.3 84 132/69 16 97% RA - Exam notable for: erythema and induration of the bilateral upper medial thighs, with copious erythema, edema and induration of the scrotum. on re-examination by this resident no clear crepitus. erythema has not advanced past borders on medial thighs. very tender to palpation - Labs were notable for Lactate: 1.2, WBC 7.6, Hb 9.7, K 3.1 (repleted), alk phos 152, Alb: 2.3; Clean UA - Patient was given: -- ___ 06: 18 SC Morphine Sulfate 8 mg ___ -- ___ 06: 54 IV HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 1 mg x 3 -- ___ 07: 45 IV Vancomycin 1500 mg ___ -- ___ 12: 44 IV Clindamycin ___ Started -- ___ 12: 44 PO Acetaminophen 1000 mg ___ -- ___ 13: 14 IV Clindamycin 600 mg ___ Stopped -- ___ 15: 00 IV Piperacillin-Tazobactam 4.5 g x 2 -- ___ 15: 47 PO Potassium Chloride 40 mEq ___ ___ ___ -- 4L NS ACS consulted: ___ with chronic Hep C, cirrhosis (Meld 9), IVDU, ETOH use, depression and anxiety with recurrent episodes of bilateral lower extremity cellulitis since ___, transferred for management of his cellulitis. The patient has no crepitus on exam or areas of fluid collections. He is stable and should be treated with antibiotics. There is no need for surgical intervention at this point. It is unclear as to why he continues to have this cellulitis. I would recommend venous ultrasounds to see if these are venous stasis ulcers. I also would recommend good wound care by keeping the base clean and changing the sterile dressing daily with adaptik over the wound. Continue with IV abx and please obtain wound cultures." - Vitals on transfer: 98.4 109/64 75 18 100 ra Upon arrival to the floor, the patient is severe pain and reluctant to talk. He states that the pain in his legs has been ongoing since ___, and he has received many courses of antibiotics. The pain and swelling in his scrotum has only been over the past three days, and he has never experienced this before. NO antecedent trauma. Notably, patient stopped taking medications (including diuretics) approximately one week prior, cannot say why. Review of Systems: Unable to obtain due to language barrier and patient reticence. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Hepatitis C - Cirrhosis with ascites, s/p large volume paracentesis - Normocytic anemia - Chronic arthritic pain - Depression <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> -======== ADMISSION EXAM -======== Vitals- 98.4 109/64 75 18 100 ra ___: AOx3, ___ speaking male, unkempt, in distress HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate, III/VI systolic murmur loudest in LUSB LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally w/appropriate breath sounds appreciated in all fields. No wheezes, rhonchi or rales. . ABDOMEN: Normal bowels sounds, abdomen quite distended, tender to palpation in all four quadrants. Tympanic to percussion. EXTREMITIES: Taut pitting edema to knees. Multiple wounds on lower extremities, most prominently a 5x4cm lesion on right medical malleolus. Extremities are tender to palpation. GU: Extreme, taut edema of scrotum and penis, tender to light touch with no crepitus. 7x4cm erythematous plaque in right inguinal lesions. Erythema throughout perineum but no extending to marker outlines in ED. Entire area is exquisitely tender to palpation. SKIN: No evidence of ulcers, rash or lesions suspicious for malignancy aside from those mentioned above. ACCESS: R IJ, dried blood at site but no hematoma or purulence NEUROLOGIC: CN2-12 grossly intact. -======== DISCHARGE EXAM -======== Vitals- Tmax 98.3 BP 90-100/40-60s HR 60-70s RR 18 O2 98 on RA ___: AOx3, ___ speaking male, NAD HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. CARDIAC: Regular rhythm, normal rate, III/VI systolic murmur loudest in LUSB LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally w/appropriate breath sounds appreciated in all fields. No wheezes, rhonchi or rales. ABDOMEN: Normal bowels sounds, abdomen quite distended but less so than prior to ___ paracentesis, nontender EXTREMITIES: Taut pitting edema to knees. Multiple wounds on lower extremities, most prominently a 5x4cm lesion on right medical malleolus, a 1x5cm lesion by Achilles tendon, both with prank purulence (last fully visualized on ___. Extremities are tender to palpation, R > L. GU: Significant edema of scrotum and penis, tender to light touch with no crepitus, much less taut/tender as of ___. 7x4cm erythematous plaque in right inguinal region. Erythema throughout perineum not extending to marker outlined in ED, improving over hospital course. SKIN: No evidence of ulcers, rash or lesions suspicious for malignancy aside from those mentioned above. ACCESS: R IJ, dried blood at site but no hematoma or purulence NEUROLOGIC: CN2-12 grossly intact. <PERTINENT RESULTS> -==== ADMISSION LABS -==== ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD WBC-8.7 RBC-3.76* Hgb-9.9* Hct-29.8* MCV-79* MCH-26.3 MCHC-33.2 RDW-15.4 RDWSD-44.2 Plt ___ ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Neuts-67.0 Lymphs-8.2* Monos-18.0* Eos-6.0 Baso-0.2 Im ___ AbsNeut-5.80 AbsLymp-0.71* AbsMono-1.56* AbsEos-0.52 AbsBaso-0.02 ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD ___ PTT-36.4 ___ ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Glucose-86 UreaN-7 Creat-0.5 Na-133 K-3.1* Cl-98 HCO3-22 AnGap-16 ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD ALT-15 AST-32 AlkPhos-152* TotBili-0.8 ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Albumin-2.3* Calcium-7.9* Phos-2.5* Mg-1.9 ___ 07: 04AM BLOOD Lactate-1.0 -==== PERTINENT RESULTS -==== ___ 05: 16AM BLOOD calTIBC-208* Ferritn-54 TRF-160* -==== MICROBIOLOGY -==== ___ Blood cultures: Pending without growth to date. == ___ Urine culture: < 10,000 CFU/mL. == ___ 05: 48PM ASCITES WBC-46* RBC-237* Polys-8* Lymphs-48* ___ Mesothe-2* Macroph-42* ___ 05: 48PM ASCITES TotPro-1.9 Albumin-LESS THAN ___ Peritoneal fluid culture: Pending without growth to date. -==== IMAGING -==== CXR (___): The right IJ central line tip projects low in the right atrium and should be withdrawn at least 4 cm for optimal placement. No evidence of pneumothorax. === CXR (___): IMPRESSION: Interval adjustment of right IJ CVC which terminates in the right atrium. RECOMMENDATION(S): Recommend pulling back right IJ catheter 2.5 cm if desired location is at the cavoatrial junction. === ___: after attempting to pull back IJ FINDINGS: Right IJ central line tip in the right atrium, similar. No pneumothorax. Stable cardiopulmonary findings. IMPRESSION: Right IJ central line in place. -==== DISCHARGE LABS -==== ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD WBC-5.6 RBC-3.55* Hgb-9.2* Hct-28.6* MCV-81* MCH-25.9* MCHC-32.2 RDW-15.5 RDWSD-45.2 Plt ___ ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD Glucose-108* UreaN-5* Creat-0.5 Na-138 K-3.4 Cl-103 HCO3-26 AnGap-12 ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD ALT-11 AST-23 LD(LDH)-139 AlkPhos-121 TotBili-0.4 ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD Albumin-2.0* Calcium-7.5* Phos-3.4 Mg-1.9 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires futher investigation. 1. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 2. Furosemide 80 mg PO DAILY 3. Gabapentin 800 mg PO TID 4. HydrOXYzine 50 mg PO DAILY 5. Lactulose 15 mL PO TID 6. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 7. Spironolactone 200 mg PO DAILY 8. Emtricitabine-Tenofovir (Truvada) 1 TAB PO DAILY 9. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY 10. FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 1 mg IV Q4H: PRN Pain - Severe 2. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 4 mg PO Q3H: PRN Pain - Moderate 3. Levofloxacin 750 mg PO Q24H 4. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 2 TAB PO BID 5. Citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY 6. FoLIC Acid 1 mg PO DAILY 7. Furosemide 80 mg PO DAILY 8. Gabapentin 800 mg PO TID 9. Lactulose 15 mL PO TID 10. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 11. Spironolactone 200 mg PO DAILY 12. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY 13. HELD- Emtricitabine-Tenofovir (Truvada) 1 TAB PO DAILY This medication was held. Do not restart Emtricitabine-Tenofovir (Truvada) until discharge, if patient requests. 14. HELD- HydrOXYzine 50 mg PO DAILY This medication was held. Do not restart HydrOXYzine until patient develops symptoms that require it (e.g. pruritis). <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY: - Cellulitis, lower extremities and scrotum SECONDARY: - Right lower extremity wounds - Cirrhosis - Hepatitis C - Normocytic anemic - Chronic pain <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you. You came to the hospital because you were having pain and swelling in her your legs and scrotum. We found that you had an infection of your skin and we gave you antibiotics to treat this. You also had extra fluid on your belly, which we removed. Please continue to take your medications as prescribed. We wish you the best of health, Sincerely, Your ___ Team

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> ACE Inhibitors / ___ Receptor Antagonist <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain, lightheadedness, toe gangrene <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Right foot partial ___ ray amputation <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ with a history of NICM (EF ___, AF/SSS/VT on amiodarone s/p ICD to CRT (___), ESRD on HD, PVD with left hallux dry gangrene presenting after episode of chest tightness, lightheadedness, and weakness after dialysis. After his last dialysis session (during which 1L was removed), the patient had 30 min of chest tightness. This was associated with shortness of breath, palpitations, and weakness that lasted 2 hours. He also endorsed lightheadedness when standing and blurry vision, which have since resolved. The patient came to the ED, where a pacemaker interrogation was performed by EP, demonstrating normal pacer function with 98.6% AS-VP. Troponin was 0.14 and MB was 5. Cardiology recommended admission, but the patient left AMA to take his daughter to an appointment. He returned shortly thereafter and agreed to be admitted. The patient also has a chronic non-healing left great toe wound that has been painful for the past 10 months and has become more swollen and productive of yellow discharge over the past week. He was evaluated by podiatry and planned for a partial amputation. In the ED, initial VS were 98.2 78 128/69 15 97RA. Exam was notable for RRR, clear lungs, necrotic toe with brisk pulse, swelling with mild erythema, no tenderness or visible discharge. Labs were: 139 93 19 --------------< 87 3.2 30 3.7 93 6.9 > 10.7/35 <116 CK: 115 MB: 5 N: 79.0 L: 6.6 M: 10.8 E: 2.6 Bas: 0.7 ___: 0.3 Absneut: 5.46 Abslymp: 0.46 Absmono: 0.75 Abseos: 0.18 Absbaso: 0.05 ___: 46.4 PTT: 51.0 INR: 4.2 Foot radiograph showed no evidence of acute osteomyelitis. CXR showed stable cardiomegaly, resolution of retrocardiac opacity, and pacemaker placement unchanged. ECG showed no evidence of ischemia. Patient received vancomycin 1000mg and Piperacillin-Tazobactam 4.5 g. Blood cultures sent. Transfer VS were 97.7 67 116/68 16 100%RA. Podiatry was consulted and planned partial right toe amputation for the following day, and the patient was made NPO. Decision was made to admit to medicine for further management. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Compazine / Toradol <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Left facial pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HPI: The pt is a ___ yo RHW w/ hx of migraines, TMJ syndrome s/p surgery, recurrent otitis externa no presents with an episode of sudden onset L sided facial pain and headache. Today at 2 an she awoke her from sleep with a sharp, like a knife in nature pain on the left side of her face. In addition she describes this as a head in vice, not throbbing, around temporal area and radiation to behind L ear and into the maxilla. She took 15mg PO of morphine w/o relief. She reported associated nausea, but no emesis, no photo/phonophobia. There was no numbness, paresthesias, weakness, changes in vision, vertigo or hearing. There is no trauma associated with this. Because the pain was intractable, she came to the ED. On arrival, she received IV morphine, Ativan and Valium w/o relief of the pain. Her pain is ___ and does not radiate. She endorses pain at her occiput as well. Of note, she had a similar episode last week, was admitted to ___ where she reportedly had a negative head CT and LP, was treated with IVF and Dilaudid and was discharged home. At this time, she endorses mild TMJ pain with mastication. There is no ear pain, but she notes a decreased hearing on L over the past 3 months. 1 mo ago, she was treated for a "raging" ear infection for which she was treated with ABx. She also has a history of migraines w/ associated L sided weakness (states that resolved). Her current symptoms are entirely different from her migraines (throbbing, scintillations, photo/phonophobia). . Neuro ROS: ( - ) loss of vision, blurred vision ( - ) diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia ( - ) lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus ( - ) difficulties producing or comprehending speech ( - ) focal weakness, numbness, paraesthesia ( - ) bowel or bladder incontinence or retention ( - ) difficulty with gait General ROS: ( - ) recent fever or chills, night sweats or recent weight loss. ( - ) cough, shortness of breath ( - ) chest pain or tightness, palpitations ( - ) vomiting ( - ) diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain ( - ) recent change in bowel or bladder habits. ( - ) arthralgias or myalgias <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - intermittent otitis externa on her left ear - TMJ pain, s/p surgical repair - Migraine - Rotator cuff tendinopathy with possible bursitis. - Bicipital tendinopathy. - hysterectomy s/p lysis of adhesions ___ SBO in ___ - s/p cholecystectomy - s/p appendectomy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> [ + ] CVA - Gmother [ + ] CAD - Gmother [ + ] Cancer - mother, cervical/breast ca [ + ] Intracerebral aneurysms - Grandmother. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: ___ P: 76 R: 16 BP: 136/78 SaO2: 98% RA General: Awake, anxious, tears streaming down face. HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM. B/l injected sclera. TTP at L occipital notch, TTP at TMJ on L and external canal erythema and irritation. She mild TTP at L maxilla. Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. Full ROM. Pulmonary: CTA bilaterally Cardiac: RR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G Abdomen: soft, NT/ND. Extremities: warm, dry, no edema Pulses: 2+ radial, DP bilaterally. Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. MSK: no tenderness to palpation of C/T/L spine. Neurologic: -Mental Status: Alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attention: ___ but not ___ backward (missed ___. Language: Fluent Repetition and comprehension intact. Normal prosody. No paraphasic errors. Naming: low frequency objects intact. Reads without difficulty. Speech was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Registers 3 objects and recalls ___ at 5 minutes, ___ w/ prompting. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: PERRL 4 to 2mm and brisk. VFF to confrontation. Funduscopic exam revealed no papilledema. III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus. Normal saccades. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch and pin-prick. VII: mild LNLF flattening, resolves w/ affective smile and grin. VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally, but decreased on L. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes in midline. -Motor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. No pronator drift bilaterally. No tremor, noted. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE L 5 5 5 4+ 5 4+ R 5 5 5 5 5 5 IP Quad Ham TA ___ ___ ___ L 5- 5 4+ 5- 5 4+ 4+ R 5 5 5 5 5 4+ 4+ -Sensory: Light touch - intact Pinprick - intact Cold sensation - intact Vibratory sense - intact Proprioception - intact No extinction to DSS. -DTRs: Bi Tri ___ Pat Ach L 2 2 2 2 1 R 2 2 2 2 1 Plantar response: RIGHT - flexor LEFT - flexor -Coordination: No intention tremor. No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally. -Gait: Good initiation. Narrow-based, normal stride and arm swing. Able to walk in tandem without difficulty. Romberg absent. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 04: 10AM BLOOD WBC-6.6 RBC-4.34 Hgb-11.8* Hct-37.7 MCV-87 MCH-27.3 MCHC-31.4 RDW-13.3 Plt ___ ___ 03: 12AM BLOOD Neuts-51.6 ___ Monos-4.3 Eos-4.6* Baso-0.9 ___ 03: 12AM BLOOD ___ PTT-30.0 ___ ___ 04: 10AM BLOOD Glucose-129* UreaN-11 Creat-0.7 Na-142 K-3.8 Cl-109* HCO3-28 AnGap-9 CT Head ___: No acute intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect. Small foci of air are noted in the paraspinal soft tissues, spinal canal, extradural in location at the level of atlanto-occipital region (series 102b/im 322 and 326) which are of uncertain origin and significance if there is no h/o trauma- may be seen secondary to IV injection, if any- correlate with history; new from prior CT Head study of ___. MRI/MRA/MRV Head ___ (Verbal report from radiology): Unremarkable except for infundibular origin or vessels, but no sign of aneurysm. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> ALENDRONATE [FOSAMAX] - 70 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth weekly as needed for for bones MORPHINE - 15 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth three times a day as needed for pain (chronic for abdomina and pelvic pain) NEOMYCIN-POLYMYXIN-HC - 3.5 mg/mL-10,000 unit/mL-1 % Drops, Suspension - 4 drops(s) in ear three times a day OMEPRAZOLE - (Prescribed by Other Provider) - Dosage uncertain CALCIUM CARBONATE-VITAMIN D3 - 600 mg-400 unit Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth twice a day as needed for for bones <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Butalbital-Acetaminophen-Caff 50-325-40 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain. Disp: *12 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 2. Neomycin-Polymyxin-HC 3.5-10,000-1 mg-unit/mL-% Drops, Suspension Sig: Four (4) Drop Otic TID (3 times a day). 3. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 4. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable PO DAILY (Daily). 5. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 6. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times a day). 7. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 8. Polyethylene Glycol 3350 17 gram/dose Powder Sig: Seventeen (17) g PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for constipation. 9. Lactulose 10 gram/15 mL Syrup Sig: Thirty (30) ML PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for constipation. 10. Morphine 15 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO QID (4 times a day) as needed for pain. 11. Oxcarbazepine 150 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *120 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 12. Dilaudid 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day as needed for pain for 3 doses. Disp: *3 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Trigeminal neuralgia TMJ Migraine <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted with left facial pain which is likely due to a combination of TMJ, irritation of the nerve called trigeminal neuralgia, and possibly migraine as well as prior ear infections. Your MRI was normal. Take all medications as directed to prevent worsening or recurrence of the pain. Follow-up with Dr. ___ in the pain clinic for further recommendations, as well as a dentist or oromax___ surgeon specializing in TMJ disease. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> Ancef <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> elective hernia repair <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Ventral hernia repair, Lysis of adhesions <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ gentleman who presented in ___ with a necrotic wound overlying a clinically evident incisional hernia. Patient had a subsequent repair following several months later, however was found to have fecal fistulization likely from his previous colectomy which also required a component separation and takedown of this colocutaneous fistula. After recovering from this surgery, the patient did develop a recurrence in several locations and symptomatic. He presents today for elective hernia repair. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1 Atrial fibrillation status post cardioversion in ___ and ___ at ___. 2. Atrial flutter, status post cardioversion at ___ on ___ and status post atrial flutter ablation on ___ & ___ at ___. 3. Hypertension. 4. Hyperlipidemia. 5. Aortic pseudoaneurysm after MVA, status post repair in ___. 6. Severe obstructive sleep apnea. 7. Diastolic heart failure. 8. Chronic back pain, on chronic narcotics. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father died from an MI in his ___. No other family history of premature MI, arrhythmias, or other cardiac history. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical examination: ___: His pulse was regular at 70 beats per minute, blood pressure 120/80. His cardiac exam revealed a regular rhythm, normal apical impulse, normal heart sounds, no significant murmurs. No S3 or S4, no edema. Peripheral pulses were present. Extremities were warm. His lungs were clear. His abdomen was soft and benign other than his ventral hernia DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: Vitals: AF, VSS. HEENT: PERRL, EOMI. Moist mucous membranes. CV: Regular rate/rhythm, no m/r/g. Resp: Lungs CTAB, scattered wheezes. No rales or rhonchi. Abd: Soft, midline incision with irregular blanching erythema. No drainage. Mild tenderness. Skin: Erythema as noted above; no other lesions. Ext: 2+ peripheral pulses bilaterally. No cyanosis or clubbing. Neuro: CN II-XII intact.
