Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for elective hernia repair. You were taken to the operating room where you had a ventral hernia repaired. During your post-operative course, you were noted to have an elevated white blood cell count and you were started on an antibiotic for a presumed pneumonia. Your skin around the incision site also developed some redness, which can be a sign of infection. The antibiotic you are on will likely be able to cover for any possible skin infection - we are giving you a prescription for a 10-day course. Your vital signs have been stable and your white blood cell count has normalized. You are now preparing for discharge home with the following instructions: Medications: Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take any new medications as prescribed. These will include: *Clindamycin 450 mg by mouth daily, for 8 days *Oxycodone 4 mg by mouth every four hours, as needed for pain *Colace 100 mg by mouth twice daily, while taking oxycodone Activity: -Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity restrictions. -Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications. -Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider (PCP) as advised. Incision Care: -Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision site. -Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment. -You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap and warm water. Gently pat the area dry. -If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up appointment. -If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery. Pain control: -You were given oxycodone, an opioid pain medication. This may cause constipation so you should increase your fiber intake and take colace twice daily to prevent this. -Only take your pain medication when you need to. -Do not drive after taking oxycodone.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> Lactose <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> abdominal pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ ERCP <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Patient is a ___ female with a history of alcoholic-related chronic pancreatitis with previous admissions to ___ (___), now returning with abdominal pain for one day. Since her discharge on ___, she had an MRCP done on ___, which showed ongoing pancreatitis and distal CBD narrowing. She was then scheduled to have an ERCP done on ___ for further evaluation. In the meantime, she has had ongoing abdominal pain that was tolerable on PO Percocet. Earlier this morning, she noted onset of her pain after eating cereal and took Percocet for pain as usual. However, her pain became increasingly worse throughout the day until tonight, when she finally went to ___ ER. After initial workup and pain control, it was finally decided that the patient would be transferred to ___ under Dr. ___ service for further workup and management of the patient. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HTN, peptic ulcer, hypelipidemia, pancreatitis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father deceased, aged ___, from liver cancer. Two paternal uncles have died from cancer, one <PHYSICAL EXAM> on admission: VS: T 98.6, HR 78, BP 130/90, RR 18, SpO2 97RA GEN: NAD, uncomfortable. HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. MMM. Anicteric sclera. Poor dentition was noted. Noticeable alcohol smell from breath. Patient has bilateral hearing aids to improve her poor hearing, which she has had since a child. CV: RRR, no MRG. Resp: CTAB, no crackles or wheezes. Abd: Soft, nondistended, moderately tender to palpation and percussion of left epigastric region, no rebound tenderness. Hyperactive bowel sounds in all 4 quandrants. Ext: No cyanosis, clubbing or edema; + ___ pulses Rectal: Guaiac +. <PERTINENT RESULTS> At discharge, ___: WBC 3.7, Hct 32.8, Chem ___ AST 16, ALT 9, Amylase 38, Lipase 15, Bili 0.4 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Norvasc 5 mg PO daily, Labetalol 100 mg PO BID, Ferrous sulfate 325 mg PO BID, Lisinopril 40 mg PO daily, HCTZ 25 mg PO daily, Multivitamins with Fe 1 tab PO daily, Percocet prn <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 3. Lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 4. Labetalol 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 5. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day: take in the morning before meals. Disp: *30 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> pancreatitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the Emergency Department for any of the following: *You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. *New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze. *If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your medications. *You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. *You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a bowel movement. *You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your urine, or experience a discharge. *Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or back. *You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius. *Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you. Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take any new medications as prescribed. Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications.

On initial presentation, his O2 saturation was 88% on room air and denied chest pain. O2 sat improved after a nebulizer treatment. In the ED, his vital signs were: T: 99.6 P: 96 BP: 173/91 RR: 20 POx: 98% RA. Exam was notable for: RR ___, belly breathing, on 2L NC b/l rales in Lower lobes, wheezing throughout right lung, b/l 1+ edema to knees. Labs were notable for: BNP: ___, no leukocytosis, electrolytes wnl. Flu PCR was negative. Cr 1.3 --> 1.1 with Lasix. Trop 0.03 --> 0.04. CXR showed diffusely increased reticular opacity throughout the lungs possibly pulmonary edema, but no pleural effusion. EKG showed: NSR at 100, LBBB. In the ED, patient went into A.fib with RVR, and received Metoprolol 5mg IV and received metoprolol tartrate 25mg PO and 500cc IVF x1. Heart rates then decreased to 110s. Patient was given Duonebs (x2), furosemide 20mg IV. Total output while in ED was 2L. Upon arrival to the floor, he was afebrile, and VSS. He reported that he was at home in his apartment, and he is not sure how he got to the hospital. This morning, he was aware he was in the hospital but unsure how he got here. The patient's wife was contacted via telephone who corroborated with the above history, and clarified that he is often confused. She reports that he has a bad cold at the moment. Patient complains on right shoulder pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -==== CAD s/p remote MI, no coronary artery bypass graft. LBBB since ___ Bilateral lower extremity edema following traumatic truck rollover in ___ managed with compression stockings. HTN COPD Cervical radiculopathy at C4-C5 OSA BPH DM2 Aortic regurgitation Gastritis History of sinusitis Cognitive decline <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No known history of heart disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 98.6PO 158/88 88 28 94 Ra Admission weight: 170.19 lbs GENERAL: Elderly gentleman, alert and interactive, awake and resting comfortably. ABDOMEN: Soft, ND/NT to deep palpation in all four quadrants. EXTREMITIES: 1+ pitting edema to knees. No clubbing or cyanosis. Pulses DP/Radial 2+ bilaterally. SKIN: Warm. Hyperpigmentation of dorsal forearms. Chronic venous dermatitis on bilateral shins. Multiple AKs throughout back and biopsy scars on upper back. NEUROLOGIC: AOx3. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> ___ <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> S/p fall <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> A ___ male with h/o epilepsy presented to the ED on ___ after a fall from 15-feet with +HS/LOS. He states that he was up on a lift for work and "lost his momentum" and fell. He reports that he tried to grab a tree "on the way down" and denies any seizure activity. In the ED he was found to have a scalp laceration, L1-l4 transverse process fractures, and L 11th rib fracture. He was admitted to the trauma service, and today an over read of a CT abdomen/pelvis identified non-displaced fractures through the right inferior and superior pubic rami. He notes that he is having intermittent mid to low back pain that is exacerbated by movement. He reports he is having some mild discomfort in the right hip but denies any numbness or tingling in the right leg. He denies any chest pain, SOB, abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Epilepsy S/p R hip surgery ___ ___ c/b chronic R foot drop <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Exam on Admission: Gen: NAD, AAOx3 CV: RRR Resp: CTAB Abdomen: Soft, Wound: Incisions clean, dry, intact scalp lacerations sutured with no active bleeding Ext: Warm Physical Exam on Discharge: <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 06: 21AM BLOOD WBC-7.8 RBC-3.73* Hgb-11.5* Hct-36.0* MCV-97 MCH-30.8 MCHC-31.9* RDW-12.9 RDWSD-46.2 Plt ___ ___ 09: 25AM BLOOD Neuts-74.2* Lymphs-12.9* Monos-11.5 Eos-0.0* Baso-0.4 Im ___ AbsNeut-5.82 AbsLymp-1.01* AbsMono-0.90* AbsEos-0.00* AbsBaso-0.03 ___ 06: 21AM BLOOD Glucose-127* UreaN-17 Creat-0.9 Na-141 K-4.4 Cl-99 HCO3-32 AnGap-10 ___ 02: 29AM BLOOD CK-MB-11* cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 06: 21AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-2.8 Mg-2.5 ___ 02: 32AM BLOOD Type-ART pO2-132* pCO2-48* pH-7.41 calTCO2-31* Base XS-5 ___ 02: 32AM BLOOD Lactate-1.0 ___ 02: 32AM BLOOD freeCa-1.13 TRAUMA #3 (PORT CHEST ONLY) ___: IMPRESSION: No definite acute cardiopulmonary process. Prominent contour of the mediastinum most likely a function of technique, to be followed on subsequent CT. CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS W/CONTRAST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. Acute fracture of the left posterior eleventh rib. Multiple left transverse process fractures from L1 through L4. 2. Nondisplaced fractures through the right inferior and superior pubic rami. 3. No evidence of visceral organ injury. 4. 6 mm hyperdensity in the gallbladder which may represent stone or polyp. CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST ___: IMPRESSION: No fracture or dislocation. PELVIS AP ___ VIEWS ___: IMPRESSION: No new fractures identified on the single AP view of the pelvis. CTA CHEST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism. 2. Extensive consolidation in the bilateral lower lobes and right middle lobe with air bronchograms. Patchy consolidative and ground-glass opacities in the right upper lobe. Findings are compatible with multifocal pneumonia. 3. Right hilar lymphadenopathy, likely reactive. 4. Component of enhancing atelectasis in the left lower lobe. Small left pleural effusion. 5. Please see separately dictated report for CT of the abdomen/pelvis performed the same day. CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No source of infection in the abdomen or pelvis. 2. Known fractures are unchanged compared to CT of the torso from ___. 3. Please refer to separately dictated report for CTA of the chest performed the same day. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Clobazam 20 mg PO QHS 2. LamoTRIgine 375 mg PO QAM 3. LamoTRIgine 450 mg PO QPM 4. LORazepam 1 mg PO Q6H: PRN seizure <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 2. Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H: PRN Constipation - Third Line 3. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Moderate Reason for PRN duplicate override: Patient is NPO or unable to tolerate PO RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours Disp #*14 Tablet Refills: *0 4. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY: PRN Constipation - First Line 5. Clobazam 20 mg PO QHS 6. LamoTRIgine 375 mg PO QAM 7. LamoTRIgine 450 mg PO QPM 8. LORazepam 1 mg PO Q6H: PRN seizure <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Polytrauma head lacerations L1-4 transverse process fx, L 11th rib fx nondisplaced fx through the R inf and sup pubic rami <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Weight baring as tolerated on Right Lower Extremity <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You suffered a fall and were admitted to ___ due to your injuries, you suffered a spine fracture, rib fracture and pelvic fracture along with lacerations in your scalp. You have recuperated well and you are now ready to head home. Please follow this instructions in order to continue your recovery * Your injury caused 1 rib fractures which can cause severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of the pain. Please use your IS machine every 10 minutes in order to continue improving your breathing. * You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and notify your physician. * Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures. In order to decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 times every hour while awake. This will help expand the small airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that pool in the lungs. * You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and deep breathing. * Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short periods may ease the pain. * Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid and fiber intake if possible. * Do NOT smoke * If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side effects so make sure your doctor approves. * Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation around your ribs (crepitus).

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> fever and shaking <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ w/ hx of HTN; type 2 DM; chronic anemia; BPH/prostatitis/PSA elevation (s/p [-] TRUS Bx ___ per ___ onychomycosis; prior hepatitis B; diverticulosis; severe varicosities who presents with fever and chills/rigors since yesterday evening. He was sitting watching television when he began feeling very hot and developed chills and shaking in his extremities. He tried to lay in bed but feeling persisted and friends at his facility convinced him to come to the ED. He denies an diarrhea,constipation, nausea or vomiting. He further denies any sputum production, shortness of breath, cough, fatigue/weakness. No chest pain, lightheadedness, or dizziness associated with symptoms. He does have a hx of prostatitis but denies any dysuria, increase frequency, or pelvic discomfort. In the ED, initial vs were: 101.8 110 176/86 24 98%. CBC, chemistry 7, LFTs, and urine analysis were all within normal limits. On physical exam prostate was non-tender, no abdominal pain, no skin lesions except for nonhealing ulcer on the right foot, but no evidence of osteo-myelitis as he is able to walk on it without any pain No meningismus, no altered mental status, No exudates in oropharynx, and ___ clear. After Toradol, Tylenol and IV fluids the patient remained tachycardic and have a fever. His blood pressure remained normal. Since there was high concern for bactermia, he is admitted to medicine for further observation. On arrival to the floor, he says he is feeling better and expressed desire to go home. He denies any current chills, sweats, or rigors. He denies any SOB, chest pain, lightheadedness or dizziness. Review of sytems: (+) Per HPI (-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Glargine 16 Units Bedtime Humalog 12 Units Breakfast Humalog 12 Units Lunch Humalog 12 Units Dinner <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY: Neutropenia, Dilated Cardiomyopathy s/p Orthotopic Heart Transplant SECONDARY: Hypothyroidism, Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, Osteoporosis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to ___ after routine labs found that you were neutropenia, which means you have low levels of the cells that fight infections. After consulting the infectious disease and hematology specialists, we think that the most likely cause of your neutropenia is due to a medication effect. We have stopped Bactrim and are putting you on a different medication, atovaquone. We also decreased your mycophenolate dose to 750mg twice a day, because it too can cause neutropenia. Your counts recovered without any complications. We also had the endocrine specialists to come see you. They thought that you should be adequately treated for hypothyroidism on 75mcg of levothyroxine daily, which we will continue until you follow up with Dr. ___. Please weigh yourself every morning, and call Dr. ___ your weight goes up more than 3 lbs. Also, take your medications as directed and keep all of your appointments. It was a pleasure to take care of you. We wish you the ___! Sincerely, Your ___ Care Team

She has not fevers, chills, or night sweats. She has not been around anyone who is sick or has had any recent travels. She has a slight headache, but no neck stiffness or vision changes. She does not have rhinorrhea or congestion. She has no cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Percocet <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> abdominal pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ with h/o recurrent pancreatitis of unknown etiology c/b pancreatic pseudocyst formation and rupture who now presents with abdominal pain. The patient reports that her pain began 2 days prior to admission while placing A/C units in the window. She noticed ___ back pain as if someone put a fist through her back. She thought is was muscular in etiology, but when she got home from her daughters, she developed nausea and mid/epigastric abdominal pain consistent with her pancreatitis flares. SHe went to bed that night and the next morning tried to eat some toast with some tea and her pain became ___ and she had increased nausea without vomiting. She took some tylenol and advil without benefit and she made herself NPO. On the morning of admission, she tried to work from home hoping the pain would improve, but it was persistent so she came to the ED for further evaluation. She also reports some mild loose BM the day of admission. Not watery or bloody, just loose. In addition over the last few days, she has had increased vaginal itching and whitish discharge. In the ED, initial vs were: 97.3 71 162/87 16 98% RA. Labs were remarkable for lipase 362, Hgb 16, UA w/ large leuk (12 WBC) few bacteria. Patient was given ceftriaxone 1gm for possible UTI and morphine 5mg x3 for pain control. Also given zofran 4mg IV x2 and metoclopramide 10mg IV x1 for nausea. CT abdomen/pelvis was performed which showed Stranding along the second and third portions of the duodenum may be duodenitis, however, given elevated lipase inflammation may be secondary to pancreatitis. Patient was given 2L NS. Vitals on Transfer: 98.2 70 128/70 16 97% On the floor, patient pain is better controlled, but with nausea and vomiting. Review of sytems: (+) Per HPI (-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies constipation. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Exploratory laparotomy (___) External drainage of pancreatic pseudocyst (___) ? Gallstone pancreatitis in ___ although recurrent episodes after cholecystectomy and no evidence of stones on imaging. Chronic pancreatitis of the tail of the pancreas evident on imaging Obesity Splenic vein thrombus Laparoscopy ccy (___) C-section x2 (remote past) Diabetes Mellitus <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Notable for PBC and Sjogren's in mother. Sister with multiple sclerosis Father with CAD and DM <PHYSICAL EXAM> admission Vitals: T: 97.7 BP: 127/78 P: 77 R: 12 O2: 94% RA, FSG: 282 General: Alert, oriented, in moderate distress ___ nasuea HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: supple, no LAD Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV: Regular rate and rhythm, distant heart sounds, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen: soft, tender in epigastric area with no gaurding with mid/deep palpation, non-distended, bowel sounds present, Organomegaly difficult to assess given body habitus Ext: Warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema, varicosities of the lower extremity Neuro: CN II-XII intact, strenght and sensation intact on extremities, gait deferred . discharge VS: 97.4 74 106/59 18 96%RA I/O: NPO 150 IVF | 550 UOP BMx1 General: Alert, oriented, in moderate distress ___ nasuea HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: supple, no LAD Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV: Regular rate and rhythm, distant heart sounds, no m/r/g Abdomen: soft, minimally tender in epigastric area with no gaurding with mid/deep palpation, non-distended, bowel sounds present Ext: Warm, well perfused Neuro: A&Ox3 <PERTINENT RESULTS> admission ___ 03: 11PM BLOOD WBC-10.6# RBC-5.38 Hgb-16.3* Hct-46.8 MCV-87 MCH-30.3 MCHC-34.7 RDW-13.5 Plt ___ ___ 03: 11PM BLOOD Glucose-174* UreaN-11 Creat-0.8 Na-140 K-4.1 Cl-101 HCO3-28 AnGap-15 ___ 03: 11PM BLOOD ALT-33 AST-26 AlkPhos-110* TotBili-1.2 ___ 03: 11PM BLOOD Albumin-4.8 ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD Calcium-8.5 Phos-3.5 Mg-2.1 . STUDIES: CT ABD/PELVIS ___ 1. Stranding along the second and third portions of the duodenum may be duodenitis, however, given elevated lipase inflammation may be secondary to pancreatitis. 2. Chronic splenic vein thrombosis. 3. Splenomegaly. . discharge ___ 07: 20AM BLOOD WBC-5.5 RBC-4.09* Hgb-12.7 Hct-36.4 MCV-89 MCH-31.0 MCHC-34.8 RDW-13.4 Plt ___ ___ 07: 20AM BLOOD Glucose-133* UreaN-8 Creat-0.7 Na-141 K-4.0 Cl-108 HCO3-24 AnGap-13 ___ 07: 20AM BLOOD Calcium-8.9 Phos-3.0 Mg-1.8 <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Ms. ___: It was a pleasure to take care of you. You were admitted to ___ because of belly and back pain likely to be due to a flare of pancreatitis. We treated you with intravenous fluids and pain medications. As you are tolerating oral intake, we are able to discharge you today. Please follow up with your doctors as below. Please review your medication list closely.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> Bactrim <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> liver/kidney transplantation <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___: Exploratory laparotomy, orthotopic liver transplant, renal transplant. ___: Exploratory laparotomy, removal of intra-abdominal packing, liver biopsy, and hepaticojejunostomy. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with ESLD due to hepatitis C cirrhosis and ESRD thought to be multifactorial from HTN, DM and hepatorenal syndrome, recently started on dialysis, presents today for liver-kidney transplantation. His ELSD has been characterized by ascites (requiring multiple taps), encephalopathy (treated with lactulose/rifaximin) and grade 1 varices (no history of GI bleed). He was recently admitted from ___ for these issues; he was tapped twice, treated with lactulose for asterixis, and started on dialysis for worsening renal failure. He was tapped again yesterday at ___. He feels well today. No complaints. Denies recent fever, chill, nausea or vomiting or pain anywhere. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: hepatitis C (___) c/b cirrhosis, salmonella gastroenteritis with acute renal failure, chronic kidney disease with renal stones s/p lithotripsy (___), DM (dx ___, off medications, diet-controlled), HTN ___, well-controlled, off medications), ITP s/p splenectomy (___), asthma PSH: splenectomy ___, lithotripsy ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> FH: His family history is significant for an aunt and uncle with diabetes. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Discharge Physical VS: T 98.4 P 95 BP 137/96 RR 18 O2sat 99RA NAD, AAOx3 no murmurs ctab abd soft, apropriately tender over incision, incision closed with staples c/d/i, minimal surrounding ecchymosis, no discharge from incisions. two JP sites closed with nylon suture. no ___ edema <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ LIVER U/S: 1. No evidence of biliary dilation. Patent hepatic vasculature. 2. Stable appearance of a postoperative right perihepatic fluid collection adjacent to the right hepatic dome. A left subhepatic collection is newly apparent, though this may be secondary to differences in imaging technique, and is likely post-operative in nature. 3. Moderate left pleural effusion. 4. Diffusely increased echogenicity of the liver most compatible with fatty infiltration, with focal areas of sparing, concerning for a substantial parenchymal abnormality. 5. Geographic and nodular hypoechoic areas in the liver, which may be associated with focal fatty sparing. A 6 mm lesion in the right lobe is not specific; follow-up ultrasound surveillance or consideration of MR evaluation is recommended if clinically indicated. PATH: Pt's liver: Liver, native hepatectomy (A-M): Established cirrhosis, confirmed by trichrome stain. Moderate septal and mild periseptal and lobular mononuclear inflammation (Grade 2 inflammation), consistent with chronic viral hepatitis C. Several microscopic foci of small cell dysplasia; reticulin stain evaluated. Gallbladder with chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis. Negative vascular and biliary margin. Iron stain shows mild iron deposition in hepatocytes. ___ Donor Liver, allograft, needle core biopsy: 1. Moderate mixed macro- and microvesicular steatosis and focally prominent neutrophils. 2. Mild portal mononuclear inflammation, non-specific. 3. No necrosis or features of acute cellular rejection are seen. 4. Trichrome and iron stains will be reported in an addendum. LABS: ___ 05: 18AM BLOOD WBC-18.4* RBC-3.90* Hgb-12.3* Hct-37.3* MCV-96 MCH-31.6 MCHC-33.0 RDW-15.7* Plt ___ ___ 02: 13AM BLOOD ___ PTT-21.4* ___ ___ 05: 18AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Glucose-125* UreaN-33* Creat-1.2 Na-135 K-4.1 Cl-102 HCO3-24 AnGap-13 ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD ALT-18 AST-16 AlkPhos-141* TotBili-1.4 ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Albumin-2.8* Calcium-7.6* Phos-2.3* Mg-1.4* <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> nephrocaps 1', clotrimazole 10 troche''''', lasix 80'', lactulose 30''', propanolol 20'', rifaximin 550'', renleva 800''', spironolactone 50', venlafaxine 37.5', MVI,methadone ___ clinic, Codac in ___ ___, fax ___ <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. fluconazole 200 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q24H (every 24 hours). 2. prednisone 5 mg Tablet Sig: Four (4) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily): follow taper schedule. 3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). 4. mycophenolate mofetil 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 5. valganciclovir 450 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 6. methadone 5 mg Tablet Sig: Seven (7) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily): For Pain . Disp: *49 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 7. venlafaxine 37.5 mg Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). 8. famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 9. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain. Disp: *20 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 10. NPH insulin human recomb 100 unit/mL Suspension Sig: Twenty (20) units Subcutaneous once a day: AM. Disp: *1 bottle* Refills: *2* 11. Humalog 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: follow sliding scale units Subcutaneous four times a day: see printed scale. 12. tacrolimus 1 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO twice a day. 13. Kayexalate Powder Sig: Four (4) tsp PO prn: 4 tsp Powder(s) by mouth once a day as needed for for high potassium level Transplant . 14. pentamidine 300 mg Recon Soln Sig: One (1) inh Inhalation once a month: last dose ___. 15. One Touch UltraSoft Lancets Misc Sig: One (1) Miscellaneous four times a day. Disp: *1 box* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Hep C Cirrhosis/ESRD now s/p combined liver/kidney transplant DM <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> ___ of ___ for labs every ___ and ___ Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, increased redness, drainage or bleeding from the incision, increased abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications. No heavy lifting You may shower, no tub baths or swimming

She was d/c'ed from the ED on azithromycin but but then re-presented two days later with fevers to 102, HA and LH. She was admitted at ___ from ___. She was also found to have small to moderate pericardial effusion. She was diagnosed with legionella pneumonia. She was sent home on PO levaquin 500mg. She initially felt well upon discharge. However patient began to feel worse after discharge with increasing temperature to 100.0, subjective fevers, chills, overall feeling ill. Went to PCP and sent to ED for further workup. Was to see cardio in 1 week post d/c with echo 2 weeks post. She also experienced severe headaches but these have slowly improved. No blurred vision. Of note her insurance denied her levofloxacin and thus her ppx was filled moxifloxacin 400 mg po qd. 1 loose stool two days post dischareg [ ] Constipation [] Abd pain [ ] Other: GU: [X] All Normal [ ] Dysuria [ ] Frequency [ ] Hematuria []Discharge []Menorrhagia SKIN: [X] All Normal [ ] Rash [ ] Pruritus MS: [X] All Normal [ ] Joint pain [ ] Jt swelling [ ] Back pain [ ] Bony pain NEURO: [] All Normal [X ] Headache [ -] Visual changes [ ] Sensory change [ ]Confusion [ ]Numbness of extremities [ ] Seizures [ ] Weakness [ ] Dizziness/Lightheaded [ ]Vertigo [ ] Headache ENDOCRINE: [X] All Normal [ ] Skin changes [ ] Hair changes [ ] Temp subjectivity HEME/LYMPH: [X] All Normal [ ] Easy bruising [ ] Easy bleeding [ ] Adenopathy PSYCH: [] All Normal [ ] Mood change []Suicidal Ideation [ ] Other: []all other systems negative except as noted above <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Hypothyroidsim <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother died at age ___ from PNA complications. Her mother was a heavy smoker. Her father died at age ___ from old age. <PHYSICAL EXAM> PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: T 98.1P 67 BP = 131/86 RR 18 O2Sat = 97% on RA Wt, ht, BMI GENERAL: Thin female laying bed. She is in no acute distress. She looks older than her stated age Nourishment: at risk Grooming: OK Mentation: alert, speaking in full sentences. She has a dry sense of humor. Eyes: NC/AT, PERRL, EOMI without nystagmus, no scleral icterus noted Ears/Nose/Mouth/Throat: MMM, no lesions noted in OP Neck: supple, no JVD or carotid bruits appreciated Respiratory: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W Cardiovascular: RRR, nl. S1S2, ___ early peaking SEM at LUSB Gastrointestinal: soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no masses or organomegaly noted. Genitourinary: deferred Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. No pressure ulcer Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP pulses b/l

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Enalapril / Nifedipine <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> SOB/cough <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo F with Asthma, HTN, GERD who presents with shortness of breath and cough for two days. The patient reports that she was in he USOH until ___ evening; she noticed that her granddaughter "sprayed something," which caused her to start coughing and sneezing. She went in her room to get away from what was irritating her, but continued to cough overnight. On ___, she continued to cough (and the cough become productive of yellow sputum) and began to feel tightness in her chest, so took albuterol nebulizers every four hours. She used her CPAP machine overnight, but couldn't not get comfortable; she turned the setting up from 3 to 5 because she felt short of breath all night. She continued to take her nebulizers this morning, and began to have "shaking chills" this afternoon around 2pm. Her granddaughter called an ambulance, and she was brought to the ED. She reports having some mild nasal congestion for the past few days, as well as a sore throat that developed as a result of her cough. She denies significant headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain or myalgias. She did receive Flu and H1N1 vaccinations this year. Her only sick contacts have been grandchildren, who had "colds." In the ED, initial VS: T 100.5, BP 155/65, HR 97, RR 20, SaO2 100%. A CXR in the ED showed a possible retrocardiac opacity but was otherwise within normal limits. EKG no ischemic changes, biphasic T V4-V5. She was given 125 mg solumedrol, levoflox 750 mg IV, tamiflu, 40 mEq Kcl, 1g tylenol. An influenza DFA was sent, as well as blood cultures. . On arrival to the floor, the patient reported continued shortness of breath and cough. She feels generally "sore" in her chest and abdomen when coughing. She denies chest pain at rest, palpitations or dizziness. . ROS: Denies night sweats, headache, vision changes, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria. Of note, she also reports occasional difficulty swallowing pills and feeling like food gets stuck in her throat for the past ___ years. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. Pulmonary - Asthma: diagnosed in ___. Has had multiple hospitalizations but no intubations. Not on home steroids since ___. - Chronic sinus disease: (___): s/p bilateral CT guided endoscopic maxillary antrostomies, left anterior ethmoidectomy, right anterior and posterior ethmoidectomy, right sphenoidotomy, excision of lateral lamella, left concha bullosa in - Seasonal allergies: h/o hives and lip swelling 2. Cardiac - Hypertension - Heart murmur - h/o atypical chest pain - last nuclear stress test in ___ - negative - Last TTE ___ - EF >55%, mild LV diastolic dysfunction 3. CRI-baseline 1.0-1.2 4. Depression 5. GERD: complicated by hoarseness 6. Back pain: - herniated disc s/p steroid injections, - followed by ___ pain clinic 7. Suspected non-alcoholic steatohepatitis 8. s/p cholecystectomy 9. s/p appendectomy 10. s/p left breast I&D 11. s/p tonsillectomy 12. Hx of post-menopausal bleeding sp endometrial biospy which was neg for malignancy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Sister with diabetes ___. She reports that her mother has heart problems. Her father died of a bleeding ulcer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals - T: 100.7 BP: 162/98 HR: 96 RR: 20 02 sat: 95% RA GENERAL: ill-appearing elderly ___ female, occasionally coughing throughout interview but not using accessory muscle between coughing fits HEENT: NCAT, PERRL, EOMI, OP clear, MMM CARDIAC: RRR, S1, S2, soft systolic murmur loudest LUSB LUNG: Diffusely rhonchorous, worse at bases with expiratory wheezes throughout ABDOMEN: +BS, soft, NT, ND, no HSM EXT: no c/c/e, 2+ DP pulses NEURO: A&O x3, affect appropriate, CN II-XII grossly intact, gait assessment deferred. DERM: no rashes or skin lesions noted <PERTINENT RESULTS> LABORATORY FINDINGS: ___ 04: 40PM BLOOD WBC-9.5 RBC-3.79* Hgb-10.5* Hct-31.8* MCV-84 MCH-27.8 MCHC-33.0 RDW-14.8 Plt ___ ___ 04: 40PM BLOOD Neuts-86.3* Lymphs-7.7* Monos-3.5 Eos-2.3 Baso-0.1 ___ 04: 40PM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-17 Creat-1.0 Na-141 K-3.1* Cl-105 HCO3-26 AnGap-13 ___ 04: 40PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-275* ___ 04: 40PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 06: 58AM BLOOD CK-MB-3 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 06: 58AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-392* ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD proBNP-623 ___ 06: 58AM BLOOD Calcium-9.2 Phos-2.8 Mg-1.6 ___ 04: 33PM BLOOD Lactate-2.0 ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD WBC-8.8 RBC-3.93* Hgb-10.8* Hct-33.7* MCV-86 MCH-27.4 MCHC-32.0 RDW-14.9 Plt ___ ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD Glucose-90 UreaN-23* Creat-1.1 Na-138 K-4.2 Cl-101 HCO3-30 AnGap-11 ___ 06: 00PM URINE Color-Straw Appear-Clear Sp ___ ___ 06: 00PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-NEG Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.0 Leuks-NEG . MICROBIOLOGY: Blood Culture ___ NGTD Influenza DFA ___ Negative Legionella Urine Ag neg ___ . IMAGING: CXR ___: The lung volumes are low causing bibasilar atelectasis and exaggeration of the cardiomediastinal silhouette. The retrocardiac opacity is likely a combination of tortuous aortic contour and adjacent atelectasis. There are no other areas of focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax. There is no pulmonary edema. Heart size is normal. Hilar contours are unremarkable. Cholecystectomy clips are present in the right upper quadrant. IMPRESSION: 1. No acute cardiopulmonary process. 2. Mild bibasilar and retrocardiac atelectasis with a tortuous aortic contour. . CXR PA and LAT ___: As compared to the previous examination, the lung volumes are still low. There is moderate cardiomegaly without signs of overhydration. Mild retrocardiac atelectasis. No evidence of interval recurrence of focal parenchymal opacity suggesting pneumonia. Tortuosity of the thoracic aorta, leading to _____ transparency over the basal spine on the lateral radiograph. Unremarkable hilar contours. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Per OMR - ALBUTEROL nebs and inh prn - Astelin 2 puffs each nostrol BID - Celebrex ___ BID - Advair 100-50 BID - synthroid 75 mcg daily - MOMETASONE 1 puff each nostril BID - OMEPRAZOLE - 40 mg Capsule daily - VALSARTAN [DIOVAN] - 160 mg QHS - VERAPAMIL SR - 360 mg daily - Tylenol ___ mg daily - ASA 81 mg daily - Ca/vit D 315 mg-200 unit Tablet BID <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Fluticasone-Salmeterol 100-50 mcg/Dose Disk with Device Sig: One (1) Disk with Device Inhalation BID (2 times a day). 2. Valsartan 160 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 3. Prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: Four (4) Tablet PO once a day for 15 days: Please take 4 tabs daily for 4 days. Then decrease to 2 tabs daily for 5 days. Then decrease to 1 tab daily for five days and stop. Disp: *31 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 4. Verapamil 180 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: Two (2) Tablet Sustained Release PO Q24H (every 24 hours). 5. Levothyroxine 75 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 6. Benzonatate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times a day) for 2 weeks. Disp: *30 Capsule(s)* Refills: *0* 7. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable PO DAILY (Daily). 8. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: Two (2) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 9. Astelin 137 mcg Aerosol, Spray Sig: Two (2) Nasal twice a day: 2 puffs each nostril daily. 10. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) Solution for Nebulization Sig: One (1) Inhalation Q4H (every 4 hours). 11. Albuterol Sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: Two (2) Inhalation every ___ hours. 12. Mometasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Non-Aerosol Sig: One (1) Nasal twice a day: 1 puff each nostril BID. 13. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) Solution for Nebulization Sig: One (1) Inhalation every four (4) hours as needed for wheeze, SOB. Disp: *30 units* Refills: *2* 14. Calcium Citrate-Vitamin D3 315-200 mg-unit Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day. 15. Tylenol Extra Strength 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO once a day as needed for fever or pain. 16. Celebrex ___ mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Diagnoses: Asthma exacerbation Community acquired pneumonia Dysphagia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You have a diagnosis of asthma and were admitted to the hospital with an asthma flare and pneumonia. You were treated with nebulizers, steroids and antibiotics, with improvement in your symptoms. Additionally, you had a new complaint of difficulty swallowing and were evaluated by the speech therapists; you underwent a video swallow which showed no evidence of aspiration. . We made the following changes to your home medications: - Continue prednisone 40 mg daily for four days, then decrease to 20 mg daily for 5 days, then 10 mg daily for five days - Start tessalon perles as needed for cough - Continue to use albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers every four hours as needed for shortness of breath or wheezing - Please modify your diet as follows: You can drink thin liquids as long as you take one sip at a time. Also, you should have only moist, soft solid foods and medications should be taken whole mixed with pureed foods. Please continue to take all other medications as prescribed. We did not make further changes to your outpatient medications.

He comes after seeing at least one community spine surgeon who advised a surgical decompression, but advised that we performed in a full service hospital whether Cardiology and Cardiac Surgery services available to him. Imaging demonstrated a rather severe stenosis, particularly in the mid to caudal lumbar spine and significant stenosis between L1 and S1. He presents now for surgical treatment. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HLD, aflutter s/p cardioversion on apixaban, HTN, aortic stenosis s/p AVR, thoracic aneurysm repair, mitral regurgitation, OSA, pituitary adenoma <SOCIAL HISTORY> Former Smoker <PHYSICAL EXAM> PE: VS 98.0 PO 113 / 67 L Lying 83 18 93 Ra NAD, A&Ox4 nl resp effort RRR Incision is well approximated with staples intact; no erythema throughout incision or drainage. Lytic lesion measuring 2.5 cm in a midthoracic vertebral body (602: 40). Although this has some features consistent with hemangioma, it isnot entirely characteristic. MRI, or bone scan if patient cannot tolerate MRI, is recommended for further evaluation. 3. Bibasilar atelectasis. No evidence of an acute pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality. 4. Scattered granulomas and micro nodules which could also be calcified. 5. Small hiatal hernia containing hyperdense material. MRI Tspine ___: 1. T3 and T8 vertebral body hemangiomas. 2. No suspicious osseous lesions identified. 3. Multilevel disc degenerative disease affecting thoracic spine vertebral body and disc with no underlying severe spinal canal stenosis or neural foraminal narrowing. CT Chest ___- IMPRESSION: 1. The airways are patent to the subsegmental level. The previously seen right mainstem bronchus partial filling defect has resolved, consistent with passed secretion. 2. Persistent but decreased atelectasis at each lung base. 3. Incidental findings include cholelithiasis, nonobstructive left upper pole nephrolithiasis measuring up to 3 mm, and a small hiatal hernia. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY 3. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY 4. brexpiprazole 2 mg oral every other day 5. ClonazePAM 1 mg PO DAILY: PRN anxiety 6. Dextroamphetamine 20 mg PO Q8H: PRN anxiety 7. Diltiazem Extended-Release 120 mg PO DAILY 8. Finasteride 5 mg PO DAILY 9. Fluvoxamine Maleate 150 mg PO DAILY 10. LamoTRIgine 150 mg PO DAILY 11. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS 12. TraMADol 50 mg PO BID: PRN Pain - Moderate <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 2. Albuterol 0.083% Neb Soln 1 NEB IH Q6H: PRN wheezing/SOB 3. Docusate Sodium 200 mg PO BID 4. Gabapentin 200 mg PO TID 5. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5-5 mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*35 Tablet Refills: *0 6. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 7. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY 8. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO EVERY OTHER DAY 9. brexpiprazole 2 mg oral EVERY OTHER DAY 10. ClonazePAM 1 mg PO DAILY: PRN anxiety 11. Dextroamphetamine 20 mg PO Q8H: PRN anxiety 12. Diltiazem Extended-Release 120 mg PO DAILY 13. Finasteride 5 mg PO DAILY 14. Fluvoxamine Maleate 150 mg PO DAILY 15. LamoTRIgine 150 mg PO DAILY 16. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> 1. Lumbar spinal stenosis. 2. Neurogenic claudication. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> -Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks.You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand more than~45 minutes without getting up and walking around. -Rehabilitation/ Physical ___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.You can walk as much as you can tolerate.Limit any kind of lifting. -Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet.You may have some constipation after surgery.You have been given medication to help with this issue. -Brace: You may have been given a brace.If you have been given a brace,this brace is to be worn when you are walking.You may take it off when sitting in a chair or while lying in bed. -Wound Care: Mepilex Ag applied on ___. This dressing may remain in place for 7 days then: Keep the incision covered with a dry dressing on until follow up appointment. If the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may take a shower and place a new dry dressing on. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool.If the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not get the incision wet.Cover it with a sterile dressing.Call the office. -Medications: You should resume taking your normal home medications. You have also been given Additional Medications to control your pain.Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic prescriptions,so please plan ahead.You can either have them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___.We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic prescriptions(oxycontin,oxycodone,percocet) to your pharmacy.In addition,we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the date of surgery. -Follow up: Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been done already. -Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound. Physical Therapy: 1)Weight bearing as tolerated.2)Gait,balance training.3)No lifting >10 lbs.4)No significant bending/twisting. Treatments Frequency: Mepilex Ag applied on ___. This dressing may remain in place for 7 days then: Keep the incision covered with a dry dressing on until follow up appointment. If the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may take a shower and place a new dry dressing on. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool.If the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not get the incision wet.Cover it with a sterile dressing.Call the office.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> cardiac cath intra-aortic balloon pump <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ yr old male with h/o HTN and OA now tranferred from ___ for a cath tomorrow. Pt states about 2 weeks ago, he who an episode of dizziness, lightheadedness, shortness of breath with exertion. Did not have chest pain or pressure at that time. Since then, pt had a couple of similar episodes. All of them resolved with rest. Last ___ night, pt got up from sleep to go to the bathroom and noticed that he had chest discomfort that did radiate to left arm. Describes it as a heaviness, not pain. Pt went back to sleep and when he got up the next morning, still had the discomfort. It persisted all morning, so he finally presented to ___ in the afternoon. There, he was sent for a stress test ___ morning. Per report, he developed chest pain and 2mm ST elevation in inferior leads on the treadmill, which resolved with rest. Also, per report had an ECHo that showed normal LV fxn w/o regional wall motion abnlormalities. He was given ASA, loaded with Plavix and placed on heparin gtt. Pt awas also started on statin, beta-blocker. Pt was then transferred to ___ for plan for cath with Dr. ___. . Upon arrival to the floor, pt is comfortable, has no complaints. Denies any chest pain, shortness of breath. . Review of systems: as per HPI. endorses some mild rhinorrhea. endorses occ pain in knees and hip. denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain, headache, sinus tenderness. denies cough, palpitations. denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. denies dysuria. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: -CABG: none -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: -PACING/ICD: none 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Osteoarthritis - left hip and left knee treated with motrin in past <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> father with CAD in late ___, mother with "cardiomyopathy" in ___, GM with DMII <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Exam: Vitals: T: 97.7 BP: 147/92 P: 57 R: 18 O2: 98% on RA General: alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT: EOMI, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: supple, no JVD Lungs: CTAB, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV: RRR, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema <PERTINENT RESULTS> Cardiac Cath: 1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated 1 vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA had minimal diffuse atherosclerotic disease. The LAD and LCx had diffuse non-critical disease. The RCA had 90% proximal stenosis as well as 80% mid-segment stenosis. The R-PDA had diffuse disease. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed normal left and right sided filling pressures with an RVEDP of 9 mmHg and a PCWP of 13 mmHg. The pulmonary arterial pressure was normal at ___ mmHg. Systemic arteral pressures were initially elevated at 173/89 mmHg, however post-intervention normalized to 117/64 mmHg. Cardiac output and index were within normal limits. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. 1 vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Normal left and right sided filling pressures. 3. Normal pulmonary and systemic arterial blood pressures. Echo: The left atrium is normal in size. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved regional and global systolic function. Mild mitral and aortic regurgitation. Mild aortic dilation. Borderline pulmonary hypertension. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Ibuprofen (stopped 2 weeks ago) Felodipine 7.5 mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. metoprolol succinate 25 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* 2. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *11* 3. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Tylenol Extra Strength 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO three times a day as needed for pain. 5. simvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 6. aspirin 325 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Coronary artery disease status post drug eluting stent to the right coronary artery. Vaso-vagal episodes <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for a positive stress test. Your heart had a blockage in one of the arteries of your heart. A stent was placed to improve blood flow. Other vessels of your heart have some smaller plaques. We started you on new medications to manage your coronary artery disease. Please make sure to take these medications every day to protect your heart. During your cardiac catheterization procedure, you had some "vagal episodes" which caused a low blood pressure and improved after the procedure and after all the tubes were removed from your body. The vagal episodes of nausea and low blood pressure were likely due to your body's reaction to the procedure. Please avoid any strenuous exersize over the next 1 week. We do not recommend you go back to work for one week and should increase your activity slowly. We recommend you change your diet to a low cholesterol and heart healthy diet. We also recommend you eat foods low in salt. It is important to exercise regularly. The following changes were made to your medications: STOP: Felodipine and Ibuprofen START: Lisinopril to lower your blood pressure START: Metoprolol ot lower your heart rate and prevent a heart attack START: Clopidogrel or Plavix and a full dose (325mg) aspirin to prevent the stent from clotting off. You will need to take these medicines every day without fail for the next ___ year and possibly longer. Stopping or missing these medicines may cause a heart attack. Do not stop these medicines unless Dr. ___ you it is OK. START: Simvastatin to lower your cholesterol and prevent blockages in your heart arteries. START: Tylenol at 1000mg Three times a day as needed to treat your arthritis.

RADIOLOGY Final Report LIVER OR GALLBLADDER US (SINGLE ORGAN) ___ 6: 39 AM REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: eval CBD; r/o cholecystitis HISTORY: ___ female with right upper quadrant tenderness to palpation and known cholelithiasis. Please evaluate for cholecystitis. IMPRESSION: 1. Cholelithiasis with gallbladder distention and wall thickening. These findings are suggestive of cholecystitis. Clinical correlation as well as HIDA scan for further evaluation are recommended. 2. Diffusely echogenic liver consistent with fatty infiltration. However, more advanced forms of liver disease, including significant fibrosis and cirrhosis, may also have this appearance. . Pathology Examination Procedure date ___ DIAGNOSIS: Gallbladder: 1. Acute and chronic cholecystitis. 2. Cholelithiasis, mixed-type. 3. One unremarkable lymph node. Clinical: Cholelithiasis. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Lexapro 40mg qd Atenolol 25mg qd <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Escitalopram 10 mg Tablet Sig: Four (4) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. Atenolol 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day) as needed for constipation for 1 months. Disp: *60 Capsule(s)* Refills: *0* 4. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours): Do not exceed 4000mg/day. 5. Vicodin ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours for 2 weeks: Take with Food. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Acute cholecystitis with obstruction and hydrops of the gallbladder. . Secondary: OSA, HTN, carpal tunnel syndrome, multiple burn surgeries, no intraabdominal surgery <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Stable Tolerating a regular diet Adequate pain control with oral medication <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the following: * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. * If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your medications. * You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. * You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a bowel movement. * Your skin, or the whites of your eyes become yellow. * Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or becoming progressively worse, or inadequately controlled with the prescribed pain medication. * You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) degrees or 38(C) degrees. * Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you. . Incision Care: *You may shower. Pat incision dry. *Avoid swimming and baths until further instruction at your followup appointment. *Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

You were seen by dermatologists who believed the rash was likely related to an antibiotic you had recently received (either ceftriaxone or ertapenem). Do not take these medications again. While you were here you were also found to have a heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure. You were seen by cardiologists who started you on various medications to control your heart rate and help your heart pump better. You have been started on warfarin with lovenox until your INR is 2. Please take this everyday as directed by your PCP. Please have your INR checked Your discharge weight was: 50.12 kg (110.49 lb). Please call your cardiologist if your weight increases by more than 3 pounds.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chills, myalgias, headache <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ with PMH of Prader-Willi, ADHD, chronic migraine without auras, known 2mm R PCA aneurysm, hx Kawasaki's disease, with recent hiking trip to ___, who presents with body aches, extreme headache, meningismus. Over the weekend, she went to ___ and had a few bug bites, primarily mosquitoes. The day before presentation, she developed myalgias and malaise coupled with subjective fevers and chills. She also endorsed a sore throat, with intermittent painful swallowing. This was followed by a occipital headache "where the aneurysm is" the AM of presentation which progressed to a generalized headache along with neck stiffness. Of note, neck stiffness resolved prior to presentation to the ED. She states that this headache was different than her typical migraines: more extreme, coupled with photo and phonophobia. She has never experienced anything like this before. On arrival to the ED, she was tachycardic with HR to the 140's, normotensive (110/70's), satting well on room air (99%). She had a leukocytosis with a neutrophilia and a lactate of 2.4. She received IVF and multiple attempts were made at an LP which all failed. Her lactate downtrended to 2.0. She was then initiated on empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis with vanc and ceftriaxone. On arrival to the floor, she gives the above history. She notes that her headache is improved, though still present, and her body aches continue. She also endorses symmetrical joint pain in her ankles, knees and now hips; this has been present since childhood because she has "loose joints"; however, it has worsened in the past few days. Denies shortness of breath, chest pain, continued photophobia or phonophobia. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - ___ - ___ - personal scan showed a 2mm PCA aneurysm - Chronic migraines <SOCIAL HISTORY> Marital status: Single Lives with: Siblings; Parents Lives in: Apartment Multiple partners: Past ___ activity: Past Sexual orientation: Male and Female Sexual Abuse: Denies Domestic violence: Denies Contraception: Condoms - Male; OCPs Tobacco use: Never smoker Alcohol use: Denies Recreational drugs Present (marijuana, heroin, crack pills or other): Recreational drugs years ago <FAMILY HISTORY> Relative Status Age Problem Onset Comments Mother Living DIABETES ___ HYPERTENSION Father Living Aunt ___ HEMORRHAGIC STROKE brain aneurysm Aunt Living STROKE brain aneurysm Sister Living ASTHMA Sister Living ASTHMA Sister Living ASTHMA Brother Living ASTHMA <PHYSICAL EXAM> -===== ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM -===== VITALS: ___ 0656 Temp: 98.7 PO BP: 105/72 L Sitting HR: 111 RR: 16 O2 sat: 100% GEN: Young female, appears stated age, with dyed red hair, lying in bed covered by Dory blanket. Alert, conversational with appropriate questions and answers, interactive. Does not appear in acute distress. HEENT: MMM, PERRL, EOMI, no neck stiffness, neg brudzinski/kernig CV: tachycardic, regular. No murmurs, rubs, gallops. PULM: CTA b/l. No increased work of breathing, no accessory muscle use. Speaking comfortably in full sentences. GI: Soft, nondistended, nontender in all quadrants except some "discomfort" suprapubically with palpation. EXT: Warm, well-perfused, no cyanosis or edema. No pain to palpation of joints. SKIN: No rashes, lesions. NEURO: CNII-XII intact, grossly symmetric face. B/l Upper and lower extremities ___ motor strength, good grip strength. No FND. Normal, steady, balanced gait. -===== DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM -===== VS: afebrile, HDS, setting well on room air GENERAL: young woman lying in bed, tired appearing PULM: breathing comfortably on room air <PERTINENT RESULTS> - ADMISSION LABS - ___ 10: 22PM PARST SMR-NEG ___ 10: 22PM PLT COUNT-296 ___ 10: 22PM NEUTS-80.3* LYMPHS-13.2* MONOS-5.6 EOS-0.3* BASOS-0.2 IM ___ AbsNeut-11.09* AbsLymp-1.83 AbsMono-0.78 AbsEos-0.04 AbsBaso-0.03 ___ 10: 22PM WBC-13.8* RBC-4.50 HGB-13.1 HCT-38.7 MCV-86 MCH-29.1 MCHC-33.9 RDW-13.1 RDWSD-40.5 ___ 10: 22PM ALBUMIN-4.4 CALCIUM-9.7 PHOSPHATE-2.5* MAGNESIUM-1.7 ___ 10: 22PM ALT(SGPT)-10 AST(SGOT)-14 ALK PHOS-81 TOT BILI-0.2 ___ 10: 22PM estGFR-Using this ___ 10: 22PM GLUCOSE-136* UREA N-6 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-3.8 CHLORIDE-101 TOTAL CO2-21* ANION GAP-18 ___ 10: 25PM LACTATE-2.4* ___ 11: 45PM URINE MUCOUS-RARE* ___ 11: 45PM URINE RBC-1 WBC-2 BACTERIA-FEW* YEAST-NONE EPI-1 ___ 11: 45PM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-7.5 LEUK-SM* ___ 11: 45PM URINE COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 11: 45PM URINE UCG-NEGATIVE ___ 11: 45PM URINE HOURS-RANDOM ___ 02: 21AM LACTATE-2.0 ___ 02: 21AM ___ COMMENTS-GREEN TOP ___ 08: 57AM ___ PTT-31.5 ___ ___ 12: 07PM CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF) TNC-1 RBC-8* POLYS-8 ___ ___ 12: 07PM CEREBROSPINAL FLUID (CSF) PROTEIN-27 GLUCOSE-70 ___ 03: 30PM OTHER BODY FLUID FluAPCR-NEG FluBPCR-NEG -=== PERTINENT STUDIES -=== NCHCT ___ 1. No acute intracranial process, specifically no evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage. CXR ___ No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality. ============ MICROBIOLOGY ============ _________________________________________________________ ___ 2: 51 pm Rapid Respiratory Viral Screen & Culture Source: Nasopharyngeal swab. Respiratory Viral Culture (Preliminary): Respiratory Viral Antigen Screen (Final ___: Negative for Respiratory Viral Antigen. Specimen screened for: Adeno, Parainfluenza 1, 2, 3, Influenza A, B, and RSV by immunofluorescence. Refer to respiratory viral culture and/or Influenza PCR (results listed under "OTHER" tab) for further information.. __________________________________________________________ ___ 12: 07 pm CSF;SPINAL FLUID SOURCE: LP // CSF TUBE #3. GRAM STAIN (Final ___: NO POLYMORPHONUCLEAR LEUKOCYTES SEEN. NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN. This is a concentrated smear made by cytospin method, please refer to hematology for a quantitative white blood cell count, if applicable. FLUID CULTURE (Preliminary): NO GROWTH. __________________________________________________________ ___ 4: 02 am BLOOD CULTURE SET#2. Blood Culture, Routine (Pending): No growth to date. __________________________________________________________ ___ 3: 50 am BLOOD CULTURE Blood Culture, Routine (Pending): No growth to date. __________________________________________________________ ___ 11: 45 pm URINE **FINAL REPORT ___ URINE CULTURE (Final ___: MIXED BACTERIAL FLORA ( >= 3 COLONY TYPES), CONSISTENT WITH SKIN AND/OR GENITAL CONTAMINATION. - DISCHARGE LABS - ___ 08: 17AM BLOOD WBC-6.3 RBC-3.94 Hgb-11.3 Hct-34.7 MCV-88 MCH-28.7 MCHC-32.6 RDW-13.4 RDWSD-43.2 Plt ___ ___ 08: 17AM BLOOD ___ PTT-32.5 ___ ___ 03: 40PM BLOOD Glucose-126* UreaN-5* Creat-0.6 Na-141 K-3.9 Cl-108 HCO3-20* AnGap-13 ___ 03: 40PM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-3.4 Mg-1.8 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Sumatriptan Succinate 50 mg PO ASDIR as needed for migraines 2. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO TID: PRN Nausea/Vomiting - First Line 3. Topiramate (Topamax) 50 mg PO BID 4. HydrOXYzine 25 mg PO QHS insomnia 5. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 6. Loratadine 10 mg PO DAILY: PRN allergies 7. Blisovi Fe ___ (28) (norethindrone-e.estradiol-iron) 1.5 mg-30 mcg (21)/75 mg (7) oral DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild/Fever RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Ibuprofen 800 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild RX *ibuprofen [IBU] 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*15 Tablet Refills: *0 3. Lidocaine 5% Patch 1 PTCH TD ONCE Duration: 1 Dose RX *lidocaine 5 % leave on for 12 hours only once a day Disp #*5 Patch Refills: *0 4. Blisovi Fe ___ (28) (norethindrone-e.estradiol-iron) 1.5 mg-30 mcg (21)/75 mg (7) oral DAILY 5. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 6. HydrOXYzine 25 mg PO QHS insomnia 7. Loratadine 10 mg PO DAILY: PRN allergies 8. Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO TID: PRN Nausea/Vomiting - First Line 9. Sumatriptan Succinate 50 mg PO ASDIR as needed for migraines 10. Topiramate (Topamax) 50 mg PO BID <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> viral syndrome <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were here because of chills, muscle aches, and headaches. You had a number of tests performed including a lumbar puncture (aka spinal tap) that were all negative. We believe you have a viral infection that should get better on its own. After you leave the hospital, please continue to take all of your medications as prescribed and follow-up with your primary care physician. We wish you the best in the future! Sincerely, Your ___ care team

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROSURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> h/a, Nausea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___: Suboccipital Craniotomy and resection of ___ ventricular tumor. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ years old right handed man with no significant medical history who presents to the ___ for further evaluation of a recent ___ ventricle mass that was picked up on his brain Mri. Patient was seen in the ___ on ___. During initial visit, MRI of spine was ordered. Spine MRI showed focal enhancement seen along the anterior surface of the spinal cord at T12 level and joint degenerative disease. Patient was also sent home on dexamethasone 2 mg bid. Today he reports improvement with headaches, rash. He denies any seizures or weakness, numbness or tingling. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Vasectomy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> NC <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ MRI Brain- IMPRESSION: MRI performed for surgical planning with surface markers demonstrates a small inferior fourth ventricle tumor with subtle enhancement. ___ CT Brain- IMPRESSION: Expected post-operative changes status post suboccipital craniotomy including pneumocephalus and blood layering within the occipital horns of the lateral ventricles. A metallic density object within the cisterna magna is noted- correlate with surgical details if this is expected. ___ MRI Brain- IMPRESSION: 1. Punctate signal abnormality and slow diffusion in the right posteromedial aspect of the medulla, suggestive of a tiny acute infarct. 2. No evidence of residual tumor within the ___ ventricle. 3. Expected post-operative appearance, little changed since the head CT performed the previous day. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> DEXAMETHASONE - 2 mg Tablet - 2 Tablet(s) by mouth 2 TABS TWICE/DAY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain, T>38.5. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *6* 2. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 3. bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *10 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills: *2* 4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *30 Capsule(s)* Refills: *2* 5. doxycycline hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q12H (every 12 hours) for 7 days. 6. dexamethasone 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q8hrs () for 1 days. Disp: *qs Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 7. dexamethasone 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q12hrs () for 1 days. Disp: *qs Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 8. dexamethasone 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Qday () for 1 days. Disp: *qs Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 9. famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day: While taking dexamethasone. Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Biopsy result pending. Results will be discussed at future follow-up appointment. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Normal mental status and neurological function at time of discharge. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> General Instructions/Information -Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for signs of infection. -Take your pain medicine as prescribed. -Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, or excessive bending. -Dressing may be removed on Day 2 after surgery. -If you have dissolvable sutures you may wash your hair and get your incision wet day 3 after surgery. You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover your head. -If your wound was closed with staples or non-dissolvable sutures then you must wait until after they are removed to wash your hair. You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover your head. -Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) & Senna while taking narcotic pain medication. -Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and Ibuprofen etc. -If you have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing in one week. This can be drawn at your PCPs office, but please have the results faxed to ___. If you have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will not require blood work monitoring. -If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach irritation. Make sure to take your steroid medication with meals, or a glass of milk. -Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit. -Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while at home.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Tylenol/Codeine No.3 / Percocet / Tetracycline / Sulfa (Sulfonamides) / Aloe ___ ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> neck pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o F h/o NIDDM, epilepsy, HTN, chronic pain c/b opioid dependence transferred from ___ after presenting with neck pain. She had the abrupt onset of acute on chronic anterior/posterior/left acute dull, squeezing neck pain after rolling over in bed two days ago. Her pain radiates down the left arm and is associated with left arm parasthesias, both of which are chronic. She denies new weakness or bowel or bladder incontinence. Admission V/S were unremarkable and labs were notable for Na 126 (was 122 at OSH) which has corrected to 137 with NS, and Hct 33% which is slightly above her b/l ~30%. She did not tolerate a cervical spine MRI due to nausea. The consulting neurology team suspected that her symptoms were most consistent with worsening of her chronic cervical myelopathy with associated neck spasm, and recommended a soft cervical collar to be worn at night, current pain regimen, and ___. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> NIDDM c/b gastroparesis - A1c 6.3% in ___ Epilepsy Atypical chest pain - nl cath ___ Grade 4 reflux esophagitis ___ EGD) HTN Hyperlipidemia Chronic back pain s/p discectomy x 2 c/b opioid dependence Bilateral ovarian serous cystadenoma, R ovarian ___ tumor, endometriosis Seasonal allergies <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother - COPD Father - MI at ___, DM Brother - MI in early ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: V/S: Wt 147.7 lbs T 97.8 BP 98/60 HR 60 RR 20 O2sat 97% RA FSG 118 GEN: Well-appearing middle-aged woman in NAD HEENT: sclera anicteric, OP clear with MMM, disconjugate gaze, PERRL NECK: limited ROM in extension/lateral movement ___ pain, no cervical spine TTP; 2+ carotid pulses, no bruit/thrill LUNGS: CTAB no w/r/r CV: reg rate nl S1S2 no m/r/g ABD: soft, NTND normoactive BS EXT: warm, dry +PP no c/c/e NEURO: Drowsy but arousable to appropriate level of alertness, converses appropriately and attentive; CN II-XII intact; ___ strength in BLE/BUE ___ sensation to light touch intact in all distributions; 2+ bi/tri/BR/patellar DTR's, 1+ ankle DTR; no pronator drift; finger-to-nose testing intact; gait not assessed <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 04: 20PM BLOOD WBC-10.3# RBC-3.99*# Hgb-12.0 Hct-33.2* MCV-83# MCH-30.2 MCHC-36.2* RDW-14.2 Plt ___ ___ 04: 20PM BLOOD Neuts-76.8* Lymphs-17.8* Monos-4.5 Eos-0.5 Baso-0.4 ___ 07: 30AM BLOOD WBC-7.4 RBC-4.15* Hgb-12.0 Hct-35.4* MCV-85 MCH-28.8 MCHC-33.8 RDW-14.5 Plt ___ ___ 03: 02PM BLOOD WBC-6.3 RBC-3.56* Hgb-10.7* Hct-31.0* MCV-87 MCH-30.0 MCHC-34.4 RDW-14.5 Plt ___ ___ 06: 35AM BLOOD WBC-5.6 RBC-3.56* Hgb-10.7* Hct-30.9* MCV-87 MCH-30.1 MCHC-34.7 RDW-14.7 Plt ___ ___ 04: 20PM BLOOD ___ PTT-32.4 ___ ___ 04: 20PM BLOOD Glucose-96 UreaN-4* Creat-0.4 Na-126* K-4.0 Cl-94* HCO3-24 AnGap-12 ___ 07: 30AM BLOOD Glucose-94 UreaN-3* Creat-0.4 Na-137 K-4.2 Cl-104 HCO3-24 AnGap-13 ___ 06: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-83 UreaN-3* Creat-0.5 Na-137 K-4.0 Cl-105 HCO3-24 AnGap-12 ___ 04: 30PM URINE Color-Yellow Appear-Clear Sp ___ ___ 04: 30PM URINE Blood-TR Nitrite-NEG Protein-NEG Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-7.0 Leuks-NEG ___ 04: 30PM URINE ___ Bacteri-FEW Yeast-NONE ___ 03: 00PM URINE Color-Yellow Appear-Hazy Sp ___ ___ 03: 00PM URINE Blood-SM Nitrite-POS Protein-NEG Glucose-NEG Ketone-TR Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.5 Leuks-TR ___ 03: 00PM URINE ___ Bacteri-MANY Yeast-NONE ___ . ___ 3: 00 pm URINE ___. URINE CULTURE (Preliminary): GRAM NEGATIVE ROD(S). >100,000 ORGANISMS/ML.. . ___ CXR Normal appearance of the lung parenchyma, no parenchymal disease. Normal shape and aspect of the cardiac silhouette and the hilar and mediastinal contours. . ___ C-SPINE X-RAY FINDINGS: Normal bone density, the physiologic cervical lordosis is markedly decreased. There is a relatively sharp angle at the level of C5 and C6, there appears to be a fusion between C6 and C7. No evidence of compression fractures, no evidence of pathologic vertebral displacement. The anteflexion, however, is markedly reduced overall. Mild dorsal spondylosis of the entire C-spine. Minimal arthrosis of the intravertebral joints. . ___ C-SPINE MRI W/O CONTRAST - Preliminary Report !! PFI !! 1. Congenital block vertebral body. At C6 through T1 with partial obliteration of the dorsal intervertebral disc spaces; there is no motion at this segment, as demonstrated on the concurrent flexion/extension series, which may relate to abnormal motion at the C5-6 and more superior levels, and the degenerative changes, as detailed above. 2. C5-6: Multifactorial canal narrowing with no spinal cord deformity or intrinsic signal abnormality; bilateral neural foraminal narrowing with possible bilateral exiting C6 nerve root impingement. 3. C4-5: Disc - left endplate/uncovertebral complex severely encroaches on the left neural foramen, likely impinging upon the exiting left C5 nerve root. 4. Unremarkable STIR sequence with no acute-appearing abnormality. . ___ MRA NECK - Preliminary Report !! PFI !! Unremarkable enhanced study of the cervical vessels with no specific evidence of vertebral or carotid arterial dissection or flow-limiting stenosis and overall unremarkable appearance to the aortic arch. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> fentanyl patch 150 mcg/hr simvastatin 20 mg daily tizanidine 2 mg BID ASA 81 mg daily pantoprazole 40 mg BID metoclopramide 10 mg QID tegretol 400 BID (recent decrease from ___ estradiol 0.0375 patch Q72H alendronate 70 mg weekly - NOT TAKING carafate 1 gram QID vicodin 2 tab TID diazepam 7 mg TID senna BID lidoderm patch lactulose prn glyburide 2.5 mg daily - NOT TAKING imdur 60 mg daily miralax MSIR 45 mg TID <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1.
