An MRI of your neck and cervical spine did NOT show any problems with the spinal cord or blood vessels. You were also diagnosed with a urinary tract infection. Please take ciprofloxacin twice daily for 3 days, through ___, ___. No changes were made to your other medications. Please continue taking your medications as prescribed. Please call the office of Dr. ___ at ___ for an appointment within 1 week. Please call the ___ Department of Neurology at ___ for an appointment at your earliest convenience. Please call your physician or return to the Emergency Department if you experience fever, chills, sweats, dizziness, lightheadedness, chest pain, palpitations, cough, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, flank or back pain, difficulty with urination, diarrhea, or bloody or dark stools.

Her pain radiates down the left arm and is associated with left arm parasthesias, both of which are chronic. She denies new weakness or bowel or bladder incontinence. She did not tolerate a cervical spine MRI due to nausea. The consulting neurology team suspected that her symptoms were most consistent with worsening of her chronic cervical myelopathy with associated neck spasm, and recommended a soft cervical collar to be worn at night, current pain regimen, and ___. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> NIDDM c/b gastroparesis - A1c 6.3% in ___ Epilepsy Atypical chest pain - nl cath ___ Grade 4 reflux esophagitis ___ EGD) HTN Hyperlipidemia Chronic back pain s/p discectomy x 2 c/b opioid dependence Bilateral ovarian serous cystadenoma, R ovarian ___ tumor, endometriosis Seasonal allergies <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother - COPD Father - MI at ___, DM Brother - MI in early ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: V/S: Wt 147.7 lbs T 97.8 BP 98/60 HR 60 RR 20 O2sat 97% RA FSG 118 GEN: Well-appearing middle-aged woman in NAD HEENT: sclera anicteric, OP clear with MMM, disconjugate gaze, PERRL NECK: limited ROM in extension/lateral movement ___ pain, no cervical spine TTP; input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Percodan / Demerol / Nsaids / oxybutynin chloride / morphine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Pharmacologic stress test with nuclear perfusion imaging <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ y/o man with PMHx CAD c/b STEMI ___ - posterolateral ventricular branch of the right coronary artery now s/p BMS), Ulcerative Colitis, HTN and HLD presenting with CP. He describes the CP and sharp, intermittent, R sided and occuring at rest. The pain radiates to the back and is assocaited with SOB. He does not think the pain is ever assocaited with exertion. He denies PND or orthopnea, but does endorse LLE edema, which he has only noted for the past ___ days. He states this this chest pain is very similar to the pain he experienced in ___ immeditely prior to his STEMI. He denies h/o blood clots or PE. . Two weeks ago, he presented to ___ with dyspnea and chest pain. He underwent cath that showed total occlusion of the RCA. A wire could be passed and as such, plan was to medically manage him. During that admission, he also had a moderate HCT drop, and CT scan was performed to r/o RP bleed, which was negative. After d/c, he did well initially, but since then he has had progressively worsening chest pain accompanied by dyspnea. He called Dr. ___ was asked to come to the ED. . In the ED, initial vitals were: 97.6 72 124/65 16 95% Labs were notable for trop <0.01 and WBC 12 (PMNs 81%). EKG was notable for poor R wave progression, but was otherwise unremarkable. Cardiology was consulted and recommended Heparin gtt and admission to medicine for r/o ACS and possible repeat cardiac cath vs stress test. . On arrival to the floor, initial VS were: T 98 BP 116/60 HR 70 RR 18 O2 Sat 98%RA He denied CP/SOB/N/V/D/HA. . On review of systems, the patient denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. The patient denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. The patient denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: - Diabetes, + Dyslipidemia, - Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: -CABG: None -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: BMS to posterolateral ventricular branch of the right coronary artery (___) -PACING/ICD: None 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Ulcertaive Colitis HTN HLD CAD c/b STEMI s/p BMS to LAD - ___ Chronic Back Pain GERD BPH <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION EXAM T 98 BP 116/60 HR 70 RR 18 O2 Sat 98%RA GENERAL: Middle aged man in NAD. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: Supple with JVP to the angle of the mandible CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominal bruits. EXTREMITIES: LLE with 1+ pitting edema to the patella. Trace edema of the RLE. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ NEURO: A/Ox3, CN II-XII intact, non focal DISCHARGE EXAM VS - 97.4 95/62 90-110/50-70 hr 60-70 hr 75 rr 18 95RA wt 87.5<==88.7 i/o: 280/0 ___ GENERAL: awake, alert, in NAD HEENT: EOMI, PERRLA, oral mucosa dry, no lesions NECK: supple, no appreciable JVP CARDIAC: RRR, S1/S2, no appreciable m/r/g LUNGS: CTABL, no crackles or wheezing ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominal bruits. EXTREMITIES: trace edema in ___ bilaterally SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. NEURO: A/Ox3, CN II-XII intact, strength ___ in UE and ___ bilaterally <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS ___ 09: 00PM GLUCOSE-110* UREA N-19 CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-3.9 CHLORIDE-106 TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-15 ___ 09: 00PM cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 09: 00PM CK-MB-7 ___ 09: 00PM ALBUMIN-4.0 CALCIUM-9.1 PHOSPHATE-3.3 MAGNESIUM-2.1 ___ 09: 00PM WBC-12.3* RBC-3.74* HGB-11.1* HCT-34.2* MCV-91 MCH-29.8 MCHC-32.6 RDW-14.3 ___ 09: 00PM NEUTS-81.3* LYMPHS-12.8* MONOS-5.6 EOS-0.1 BASOS-0.2 ___ 09: 00PM PLT COUNT-247 ___ 09: 00PM ___ PTT-25.9 ___ PERTINENT RESULTS ___ 10: 13AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 07: 20AM BLOOD CK-MB-5 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 09: 00PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 09: 00PM BLOOD CK-MB-7 DISCHARGE LABS ___ 07: 25AM BLOOD WBC-8.7 RBC-3.94* Hgb-11.9* Hct-35.3* MCV-89 MCH-30.2 MCHC-33.7 RDW-14.0 Plt ___ ___ 07: 25AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 07: 25AM BLOOD Glucose-94 UreaN-16 Creat-0.9 Na-138 K-4.7 Cl-103 HCO3-28 AnGap-12 ___ 07: 25AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-4.5 Mg-2.4 MICRO NONE REPORTS ECG Study Date of ___ 9: 04: 16 ___ Sinus rhythm. Poor R wave progression. Possible prior inferior wall myocardial infarction, age undetermined. Compared to previous tracing no interim change. CHEST (PA & LAT) Study Date of ___ 9: 51 ___ FINDINGS: The heart appears mildly enlarged. There is mild unfolding and calcification along the aorta. The lungs appear clear. There are no pleural effusions or pneumothorax. Mild-to-moderate degenerative changes are similar along the thoracic spine. IMPRESSION: No evidence of acute disease UNILAT LOWER EXT VEINS LEFT Study Date of ___ 11: 09 AM IMPRESSION: 1. No sonographic evidence for left lower extremity deep vein thrombosis. 2. Left ___ cyst. Portable TTE (Complete) Done ___ at 12: 37: 53 ___ FINAL The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with focal hypokinesis of the basal to mid inferior wall and basal inferolateral wall. The remaining segments contract normally. Overall left ventricular systolic function is low normal (LVEF 50-55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. There is no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: Mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunctio c/w CAD. Normal right ventricular cavity size and systolic function. No pathologic valvular abnormalities. Stress Study Date of ___ INTERPRETATION: This ___ year old man with h/o HLD; s/p MI and RCA stent in ___ with known CAD was referred to the lab for evaluation of chest pain and dyspnea. The patient was administered 0.4 mg of Regadenoson IV bolus over 20 seconds. Post infusion, the patient noted ___ substernal chest pressure, improving as recovery continued and resolving by minute 9.75. There were no significant ST segment changes throughout the study. The rhythm was sinus with no ectopy throughout the study. Appropriate hemodynamic response to the infusion. IMPRESSION: Possible anginal type symptoms in the setting of Regadenoson infusion. No ischemic EKG changes. Nuclear report sent separately. CARDIAC PERFUSION PHARM Study Date of ___ INTERPRETATION: The image quality is good. Left ventricular cavity size is normal. Rest and stress perfusion images reveal uniform tracer uptake throughout the left ventricular myocardium. Gated images reveal normal wall motion. The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 50%. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of reversible ischemia. 2. Normal left ventricular systolic function. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY on hold for tooth extraction 2. Pravastatin 40 mg PO HS 3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 4. Senna 1 TAB PO BID 5. Oxycodone SR (OxyconTIN) 60 mg PO Q12H 6. Quetiapine Fumarate 100 mg PO QHS 7. Metoprolol Tartrate 12.5 mg PO DAILY 8. Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY 9. Isosorbide Mononitrate (Extended Release) 30 mg PO DAILY 10. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 11. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 12. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO HS 13. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY on hold for tooth extraction 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 3. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY 4. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 5. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 6. Oxycodone SR (OxyconTIN) 60 mg PO Q12H 7. Quetiapine Fumarate 100 mg PO QHS 8. Senna 1 TAB PO BID 9. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO HS 10. Isosorbide Mononitrate (Extended Release) 30 mg PO DAILY 11. Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY 12. Amlodipine 2.5 mg PO DAILY RX *amlodipine 2.5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 13. Pravastatin 40 mg PO HS 14. Nitroglycerin SL 0.3 mg SL PRN chest pain Take 1 tablet SL Q5MIN PRN chest pain for up to 3 tablets. If pain persists, call ___ RX *nitroglycerin [Nitrostat] 0.3 mg 1 sublingually Q5MIN Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Chest pain, possible coronary vasospasm Secondary: Coronary Artery Disease <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure to take care of you at ___. You were admitted for chest pain. You underwent a pharmacological stress test which did not show any new problems in your heart function. It is possible that you are experience some spasm in the arteries in your heart. We have started you on some medicines to treat this condition. Please see the attached list for changes made to your medications.

Currently improved with morphine. No vomiting. Mild nausea; attempted to self-induce vomiting but did not make feel better. No fever, chills. H/O similar episodes for ___ since his colon surgery. Work-up by his GI doctors was ___ negative (had CT scan, no EGD). Last ___ pain lasted less than overnight after eating peanuts. Otherwise had been a long time since last episode after he made diet modifications. No diarrhea, constipation, anorexia, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, frequency, headache, dizziness, palpitations, CP , SOB, myalgias. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMHx: Colon polyps, rosacea. . EXTREM: No ___ edema, extremities warm and well perfused. . At Discharge: AVSS/afebrile GEN: Well appearing in NAD HEENT: Sclerae anicteric. O-P clear. NECK: Supple. LUNGS: CTA(B) COR: RRR ABD: Laparoscopic incisions c/d/i. BSx4. Appropriately tender near lap incisions, otherwise soft/NT/ND. EXTREM: WWP; no c/c/e NEURO: A+Ox3. Non-focal/grossly intact. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 08: 45AM ___ PTT-23.2 ___ ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD WBC-6.0 RBC-4.43* Hgb-13.8* Hct-39.0* MCV-88 MCH-31.1 MCHC-35.3* RDW-12.6 Plt ___ ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD Glucose-96 UreaN-10 Creat-0.9 Na-142 K-4.2 Cl-103 HCO3-29 AnGap-14 ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD ALT-186* AST-147* AlkPhos-184* Amylase-47 TotBili-5.6* ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD Calcium-9.0 Phos-2.8 Mg-1.9 ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD Lipase-31 . IMAGING: ___ Liver/gallbladder U/S: Multiple small gallstones at the gallbladder neck. Mildly thickened gallbladder wall. Normal CBD. Findings could represent early acute cholecystitis or chronic cholelithiasis with mild gallbladder wall thickening. Recommend clinical correlations. . ___ CXR: No acute cardiopulmonary abnormality. . PATHOLOGY: ___ Pathology Report Tissue: gallbladder and stones: PENDING. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> 1. Nexium 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day. 2. Tetracycline Oral PRN rosacea flare. <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for fever or pain. 2. Nexium 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day. 3. Tetracycline Oral 4. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day as needed for constipation. Disp: *60 Capsule(s)* Refills: *0* 5. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day as needed for constipation: Over-the-counter. 6. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3-4 Hours: PRN as needed for Pain. Disp: *40 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> 1. Cholelithiasis 2. Choledocholithiasis 3. Chronic cholecystitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take any new medications as prescribed. Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity restrictions. Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications. Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider (PCP) as advised. Incision Care: *Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision site. *Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment. *You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap and warm water. Gently pat the area dry. *If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up appointment. *If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

He was seen in the outpatient clinic, offered open repair with diastasis plication and component separation given the amount of diastasis, the recurrence and the presence of intra-abdominal mesh. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Obesity, depression, GERD, osteoarthritis, back pain, non-insulin dependent DM, HTN PSH: Cholecystectomy, rotator cuff repair, lap ventral hernia repair <FAMILY HISTORY> N/C <PHYSICAL EXAM> Per resident: VS: 24 HR Data (last updated ___ @ 657) Temp: 97.9 (Tm 99.5), BP: 151/100 (123-151/74-100), HR: 94 (75-94), RR: 18, O2 sat: 98% (94-98) GEN: A&Ox3, NAD, resting comfortably HEENT: EOMI, sclera anicteric CV: RRR PULM: no respiratory distress ABD: soft, NT, ND, no rebound or guarding EXT: warm, well-perfused PSYCH: normal insight, memory, and mood WOUND(S): Incision c/d/i DRAIN(S): Fluid Balance: Fluid Balance (last updated ___ @ 555) Last 8 hours Total cumulative -1067.6ml IN: Total 212.4ml, PO Amt 120ml, IV Amt Infused 92.4ml OUT: Total 1280ml, Urine Amt 1250ml, JP 30ml Last 24 hours Total cumulative 473.4ml IN: Total 2353.4ml, PO Amt 780ml, IV Amt Infused 1573.4ml OUT: Total 1880ml, Urine Amt 1850ml, JP 30ml Labs: None today <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 04: 05AM BLOOD WBC-9.4 RBC-3.58* Hgb-10.4* Hct-33.9* MCV-95 MCH-29.1 MCHC-30.7* RDW-14.5 RDWSD-50.4* Plt ___ ___ 05: 00PM BLOOD WBC-11.9* RBC-3.97* Hgb-11.6* Hct-37.0* MCV-93 MCH-29.2 MCHC-31.4* RDW-14.6 RDWSD-49.8* Plt ___ ___ 06: 10AM BLOOD WBC-12.5* RBC-4.17* Hgb-12.3* Hct-39.8* MCV-95 MCH-29.5 MCHC-30.9* RDW-14.8 RDWSD-51.4* Plt ___ ___ 07: 20AM BLOOD WBC-6.3 RBC-4.61 Hgb-10.9* Hct-35.8* MCV-78* MCH-23.6* MCHC-30.4* RDW-15.5 RDWSD-42.1 Plt ___ <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires further investigation. 1. lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide ___ mg oral DAILY 2. BusPIRone 5 mg PO TID 3. Metoprolol Succinate XL 50 mg PO DAILY 4. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 1000 mg PO DAILY 5. Ibuprofen 800 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild 6. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 7. FLUoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 8. Chlorthalidone 25 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID constipation RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*15 Capsule Refills: *0 3. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*15 Tablet Refills: *0 4. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID: PRN Constipation - First Line RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 tablet by mouth twice a day Disp #*15 Tablet Refills: *0 5. BusPIRone 5 mg PO TID 6. Chlorthalidone 25 mg PO DAILY 7. FLUoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 8. lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide ___ mg oral DAILY 9. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 1000 mg PO DAILY 10. Metoprolol Succinate XL 50 mg PO DAILY 11. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 12. HELD- Ibuprofen 800 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild This medication was held. Do not restart Ibuprofen until you discuss with Dr. ___. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Recurrent ventral hernia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You have undergone repair of your abdominal hernia, recovered in the hospital and are now preparing for discharge to home with the following instructions: ACTIVITY: - Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and feel you could respond in an emergency. - You may climb stairs. You should continue to walk several times a day. - You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you see your surgeon at your next visit. - You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. Slowly increase your activity back to your baseline as tolerated. - Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common sense and go slowly at first. - No heavy lifting (10 pounds or more) until cleared by your surgeon, usually about 6 weeks. - Continue to wear your abdominal binder. - You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you otherwise. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: - You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. - You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your throat during the surgery. YOUR BOWELS: - Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medicine such as oxycodone. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these medicines without a prescription. - If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving the bowels, call your surgeon. - After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get diarrhea, don't take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of fluids and see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is severe and you feel ill, please call your surgeon. PAIN MANAGEMENT: - You are being discharged with a prescription for oxycodone for pain control. You may take Tylenol as directed, not to exceed 3500mg in 24 hours. Take regularly for a few days after surgery but you may skip a dose or increase time between doses if you are not having pain until you no longer need it. You may take the oxycodone for moderate and severe pain not controlled by the Tylenol. You may take a stool softener while on narcotics to help prevent the constipation that they may cause. Slowly wean off these medications as tolerated. - Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. If you experience any of the following, please contact your surgeon: - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours - chest pain, pressure, squeezing, or tightness - cough, shortness of breath, wheezing - pain that is getting worse over time or pain with fever - shaking chills, fever of more than 101 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain - nausea and vomiting, inability to tolerate fluids, food, or your medications - if you are getting dehydrated (dry mouth, rapid heart beat, feeling dizzy or faint especially while standing) -any change in your symptoms or any symptoms that concern you Additional: - pain that is getting worse over time, or going to your chest or back - urinary: burning or blood in your urine or the inability to urinate MEDICATIONS: - Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as you did before, unless you have been told differently. - If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to take, please call your surgeon. WOUND CARE: -You may shower with any bandage strips that may be covering your wound. Do not scrub and do not soak or swim, and pat the incision dry. If you have steri strips, they will fall off by themselves in ___ weeks. If any are still on in two weeks and the edges are curling up, you may carefully peel them off. -Do not take baths, soak, or swim for 6 weeks after surgery unless told otherwise by your surgical team. -Notify your surgeon if you notice abnormal (foul smelling, bloody, pus, etc) or increased drainage from your incision site, opening of your incision, or increased pain or bruising. Watch for signs of infection such as redness, streaking of your skin, swelling, increased pain, or increased drainage. Please call with any questions or concerns. Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care. We hope you have a quick return to your usual life and activities. DRAIN CARE: You are being discharged with a drain in place. Drain care is a clean procedure. Wash your hands with soap and warm water before performing your drain care, which you should do ___ times a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull the stopper out of the bottle and empty the drainage fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of fluid on the record sheet, and reestablish drain suction. A visiting nurse ___ help you with your drain care. - Clean around the drain site(s) where the tubing exits the skin with soap and water. Be sure to secure your drains so they don't hang down loosely and pull out. -Strip the drain tubing, empty the bulb(s), and record the output ___ times a day as described above. -Keep a written record of the daily amount from each drain and bring this to every follow up appointment. Your drains will be removed once the output tapers off to an acceptable amount. -- Your ___ Care Team

Labs significant for sterile pyuria (WBC 29), stable Hct 32.1 and elevated BNP > 1000 from unknown baseline. EKG with new twi in 1, avL and QTc prolongation 494.6. ABDOMEN: Soft/NT/ND, incisions c/d/i EXTREMITIES: 2+ b/l edema, induration and warmth to mid-calf; +2 DP NEURO: Awake, A&Ox2 (not fully to date), CNs II-XII grossly intact, moving all extremities At discharge: Objective: V/S T98 BP ___ RR22 94% RA 540 in 420 out BRx2 Examination: HEENT: EOMI, PERRL, MMM NECK: JVP at 10cm HEART: RRR, grade II/VI systolic murmur LUNGS: CTA bilat, no r/rh/wh, good air movement, resp unlabored. ABDOMEN: Soft/NT/ND, incisions c/d/i EXTREMITIES: Lower extremities edematous to knee bilaterally; non-pitting; edema is improved, pt has on ___ stockings. Aortic root reconstruction with a bovine pericardial patch. 2. Aortic valve replacement with a ___ mm On-X mechanical valve. 3. Mitral valve replacement with ___ On-X mechanical valve. ___: Temporary screw in pacemaker placed via right IJ using ultrasound guidance. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension. He presented from an outside hospital with strep viridans bacteremia likely related to a periodontal infection in ___. He reportedly he pulled his own tooth out. He subsequently developed progressive back and left hip pain along with fatigue, weight loss, and malaise. He was seen by his PCP as an outpatient and underwent MRI of lumbar spine which showed evidence of discitis vs osteomyelitis, prompting presentation to ___ on ___. His hospital course was further complicated by lumbar osteomyelitis, multifocal PNA, bilateral PEs and emphysema seen on CTA, as well as aortic and mitral endocarditis. In addition to aortic and mitral vegetations, TTE/TEE at the outside hospital showed severe aortic regurgitation with an abscess in the mitral-aortic continuity and involvement of the anterior mitral leaflet. He is on Penicillin G, heparin gtt for PE's (HIT neg) and hemodynamically stable at present. We are consulted for consideration of valve reconstruction. Of note MRI was notable for diffuse abnormal bone marrow signal, consistent with a marrow replacement process, also with anemia at OSH requiring 2 units PRBC, along with splenomegaly found on imaging. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Endocarditis, Strep Viridans Hyperlipidemia Hypertension Smoker, current Surgical History: s/p rotator cuff repair, s/p hernia repair, s/p L knee repair, s/p jaw repair <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother and father with heart disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> PREOPERATIVE EXAM: Pulse: 84 Resp: 2 0 O2 sat: 98 B/P Right: 143/48 Left: Height: 6'1" Weight: 76 kg General: NAD Skin: Dry [x] intact [x] HEENT: PERRLA [x] EOMI [x] Neck: Supple [x] Full ROM [x] Chest: Lungs clear bilaterally [x] Heart: RRR [x] Irregular [] Murmur [x] grade ______ Abdomen: Soft [x] non-distended [x] non-tender [x] bowel sounds + [x] Extremities: Warm [x], well-perfused [x] Edema [] _____ Varicosities: None [x] Neuro: Grossly intact [x] Pulses: Femoral Right: Left: DP Right: p Left: p ___ Right: p Left: p Radial Right: p Left: p Carotid Bruit: Right: - Left: - DISCHARGE EXAM: Vital Signs Temp: 98.2, BP: 113/72, HR: 74, RR: 18, O2 sat: 98%, O2 delivery: RA, Wt: 157.63 lb Pre-op 167.5 lbs Physical Examination: General: NAD [x] Neurological: A/O x3 [x] non-focal [x] HEENT: PEERL [x] Cardiovascular: RRR [x] mech valve click [x] Respiratory: CTA [x] Decreased at bases No resp distress [x] GI/Abdomen: Bowel sounds present [x] Soft [x] ND [x] NT [x] Extremities: Right Upper extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Left Upper extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Right Lower extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Left Lower extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Pulses: DP Right: 1 Left: 1 ___ Right: 1 Left: 1 Radial Right: 1 Left: 1 Skin/Wounds: Dry [x] intact [x] Sternal: CDI [x] no erythema or drainage [x] Sternum stable [x] Other: R PICC c/d/I <PERTINENT RESULTS> STUDIES: Transthoracic Echocardiogram ___ The left atrial volume index is SEVERELY increased. The right atrium is mildly enlarged. There is no evidence for an atrial septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with a mildly increased/dilated cavity. There is normal regional and global left ventricular systolic function. Quantitative 3D volumetric left ventricular ejection fraction is 52 % (normal 54-73%). Due to severity of aortic regurgitation, intrinsic left ventricular systolic function is likely lower. Left ventricular cardiac index is high (>4.0L/min/m2). There is no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. Normal right ventricular cavity size with normal free wall motion. Tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) is normal. The aortic sinus diameter is normal for gender with normal ascending aorta diameter for gender. The aortic arch diameter is normal with a mildly dilated descending aorta. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) are mildly thickened. No mass/vegetation seen, but cannot fully exclude due to suboptimal image quality. There is no aortic valve stenosis. The increased velocity is due to aortic regurgitation/stroke volume. There is an eccentric, interventricular septum directed jet of moderate to severe [3+] aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened with no mitral valve prolapse. A LARGE (2.4 cm) echodensity is seen on the left atrial side of the mitral valve with central lucency most c/w a vegetation with abscess. A LARGE ABSCESS is present. There is mild [1+] mitral regurgitation. Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation could be UNDERestimated. The pulmonic valve leaflets are not well seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets appear structurally normal. There is physiologic tricuspid regurgitation. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. A right pleural effusion is present. IMPRESSION: Large mitral valve echodensity most c/w vegetation/abscess. Moderate to severe aortic regurgitation without discrete vegetation. Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with mild cavity dilation and regional/global biventricular systolic function. Moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There're also multiple perforations of the AMVL with resultant flow through them. There're smaller vegetations attached to either the NCC or LCC of the aortic valve with sparing of the aortic root as seen on TEE. Both TV and PV are clear of any vegetations. Well seated, normal functioning bileaflet MAVR with normal gradient and no mitral regurgitation. Small secundum type atrial septal defect with near continuous left-to-right flow at rest. Ascorbic Acid ___ mg PO DAILY 18.Outpatient Physical Therapy Rolling Walker Dx: Infective Endocarditis PX: good ___: 13 months <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home with Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Endocarditis s/p Mechanical AVR/MVR with pericardial patch ___ postop atrial fibrillation intermittent high-grade AV blocks/p temporary screw-in pacemaker placement and removal Secondary: Hyperlipidemia prior ETOH use (sober ___ yrs) current smoker <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Alert and oriented x3, non-focal Ambulating with steady gait Sternal pain managed with oral analgesics Sternal Incision - healing well, no erythema or drainage Edema - none RUE ___ c/d/i <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please shower daily -wash incisions gently with mild soap, no baths or swimming, look at your incisions daily Please - NO lotion, cream, powder or ointment to incisions Each morning you should weigh yourself and then in the evening take your temperature, these should be written down on the chart No driving for one month or while taking narcotics Clearance to drive will be discussed at follow up appointment with surgeon No lifting more than 10 pounds for 10 weeks Encourage full shoulder range of motion, unless otherwise specified **Please call cardiac surgery office with any questions or concerns ___. Answering service will contact on call person during off hours** OPAT Diagnosis: strep viridans OPAT Antimicrobial Regimen and Projected Duration: Agent & Dose: Penicillin G 3 million units IV Q4H Start Date: ___ (first neg BCx and ___ Projected End Date: ___ (6 weeks from first neg BCx) LAB MONITORING RECOMMENDATIONS: NOTE: For lab work to be drawn after discharge, a specific standing order for Outpatient Lab Work is required to be placed in the Discharge Worksheet - Post-Discharge Orders. Please place an order for Outpatient Labs based on the MEDICATION SPECIFIC GUIDELINE listed below: ALL LAB RESULTS SHOULD BE SENT TO: ATTN: ___ CLINIC - FAX: ___ Penicillin G: WEEKLY: CBC with differential, BUN, Cr ADDITIONAL ORDERS: *PLEASE OBTAIN WEEKLY CRP for patients with bone/joint infections and endocarditis or endovascular infections FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS: The ___ will schedule follow up and contact the patient or discharge facility. All questions regarding outpatient parenteral antibiotics after discharge should be directed to the ___ R.N.s at ___ or to the on-call ID fellow when the clinic is closed.
reduced_text: <|begin_of_text|><SEX> M <SERVICE> CARDIOTHORACIC <ALLERGIES> Bactrim <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Malaise <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___: 1. Aortic root reconstruction with a bovine pericardial patch. 2. Aortic valve replacement with a ___ mm On-X mechanical valve. 3. Mitral valve replacement with ___ On-X mechanical valve. ___: Temporary screw in pacemaker placed via right IJ using ultrasound guidance. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension. He presented from an outside hospital with strep viridans bacteremia likely related to a periodontal infection in ___. He reportedly he pulled his own tooth out. He subsequently developed progressive back and left hip pain along with fatigue, weight loss, and malaise. He was seen by his PCP as an outpatient and underwent MRI of lumbar spine which showed evidence of discitis vs osteomyelitis, prompting presentation to ___ on ___. His hospital course was further complicated by lumbar osteomyelitis, multifocal PNA, bilateral PEs and emphysema seen on CTA, as well as aortic and mitral endocarditis. In addition to aortic and mitral vegetations, TTE/TEE at the outside hospital showed severe aortic regurgitation with an abscess in the mitral-aortic continuity and involvement of the anterior mitral leaflet. He is on Penicillin G, heparin gtt for PE's (HIT neg) and hemodynamically stable at present. We are consulted for consideration of valve reconstruction. Of note MRI was notable for diffuse abnormal bone marrow signal, consistent with a marrow replacement process, also with anemia at OSH requiring 2 units PRBC, along with splenomegaly found on imaging. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Endocarditis, Strep Viridans Hyperlipidemia Hypertension Smoker, current Surgical History: s/p rotator cuff repair, s/p hernia repair, s/p L knee repair, s/p jaw repair <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother and father with heart disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> PREOPERATIVE EXAM: Pulse: 84 Resp: 2 0 O2 sat: 98 B/P Right: 143/48 Left: Height: 6'1" Weight: 76 kg General: NAD Skin: Dry [x] intact [x] HEENT: PERRLA [x] EOMI [x] Neck: Supple [x] Full ROM [x] Chest: Lungs clear bilaterally [x] Heart: RRR [x] Irregular [] Murmur [x] grade ______ Abdomen: Soft [x] non-distended [x] non-tender [x] bowel sounds + [x] Extremities: Warm [x], well-perfused [x] Edema [] _____ Varicosities: None [x] Neuro: Grossly intact [x] Pulses: Femoral Right: Left: DP Right: p Left: p ___ Right: p Left: p Radial Right: p Left: p Carotid Bruit: Right: - Left: - DISCHARGE EXAM: Vital Signs Temp: 98.2, BP: 113/72, HR: 74, RR: 18, O2 sat: 98%, O2 delivery: RA, Wt: 157.63 lb Pre-op 167.5 lbs Physical Examination: General: NAD [x] Neurological: A/O x3 [x] non-focal [x] HEENT: PEERL [x] Cardiovascular: RRR [x] mech valve click [x] Respiratory: CTA [x] Decreased at bases No resp distress [x] GI/Abdomen: Bowel sounds present [x] Soft [x] ND [x] NT [x] Extremities: Right Upper extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Left Upper extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Right Lower extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Left Lower extremity Warm [x] Edema neg Pulses: DP Right: 1 Left: 1 ___ Right: 1 Left: 1 Radial Right: 1 Left: 1 Skin/Wounds: Dry [x] intact [x] Sternal: CDI [x] no erythema or drainage [x] Sternum stable [x] Other: R PICC c/d/I <PERTINENT RESULTS> STUDIES: Transthoracic Echocardiogram ___ The left atrial volume index is SEVERELY increased. The right atrium is mildly enlarged. There is no evidence for an atrial septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with a mildly increased/dilated cavity. There is normal regional and global left ventricular systolic function. Quantitative 3D volumetric left ventricular ejection fraction is 52 % (normal 54-73%). Due to severity of aortic regurgitation, intrinsic left ventricular systolic function is likely lower. Left ventricular cardiac index is high (>4.0L/min/m2). There is no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. Normal right ventricular cavity size with normal free wall motion. Tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) is normal. The aortic sinus diameter is normal for gender with normal ascending aorta diameter for gender. The aortic arch diameter is normal with a mildly dilated descending aorta. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) are mildly thickened. No mass/vegetation seen, but cannot fully exclude due to suboptimal image quality. There is no aortic valve stenosis. The increased velocity is due to aortic regurgitation/stroke volume. There is an eccentric, interventricular septum directed jet of moderate to severe [3+] aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened with no mitral valve prolapse. A LARGE (2.4 cm) echodensity is seen on the left atrial side of the mitral valve with central lucency most c/w a vegetation with abscess. A LARGE ABSCESS is present. There is mild [1+] mitral regurgitation. Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation could be UNDERestimated. The pulmonic valve leaflets are not well seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets appear structurally normal. There is physiologic tricuspid regurgitation. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> nausea, vomiting, diarrhea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ pmhx of hypothyroid, HTN, GERD, recent diagnosis of GBS iso PNA s/p plex and IVIG who presents from rehab with new fever, nausea, abd pain and worsening of his ascending weakness. Admitted ___ with ascending weakness and sensory loss s/p 5x IVIG treatments. He was stabilized and discharged to rehab. At rehab he was doing well making progress with walker and abilty to ambulate until ___. But therafter starting ___ he has regressed in his strength. On the day of presentation to ED he said he started to feel warm and unwell. Reports diarrhea, n/v, but otherwise denies HA, photophobia, neck rigidity. He was found to have fever of 103 and transferred to the ED. In the ED, initial vitals were: 103.9, HR 137, 139/83, 16, 98% RA Exam notable for: - decreased ___ strength compared to discharge Labs notable for: - leukocytosis - lactate 4.9 -> 2.1 with IVF - clean U/A, flu neg Patient Given: - IV abx for prelim diverticulitis read, but overread without - IVF - Home medications Neurology was consulted who agreed there was increased weakness in comparison to discharge. Will follow and reassess as infection is stabilized the role of IVIG. Vitals on Transfer: 98.8, 98, 126/82, 15, 96% RA On the floor, he confirms the above history. He says that he has 1 day of feeling unwell, 2 episodes of diarrhea day prior to presentation, nothing since. Nausea, 1 episode vomiting of yellow fluids but nothing since. Has residual mild diffuse/suprapubic abdominal discomfort. No prandial nature. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HTN GERD Hypothyroidism - GBS iso PNA <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No known family history of neurologic disease. No known family history of autoimmune disease, including T1DM, thyroid disease, RA, MS, lupus, IBD. <PHYSICAL EXAM> PHYSICAL EXAM: Vital Signs: 99.0, 148/77, 95, 18, 98% Ra GEN: Laying in bed, flat affect HEENT: Neck supple, MM tacky/dry CV: RRR nl s1/s2 no mrg PULM: CTA b/l GI: Obese, soft, ND, mild diffuse tenderness greatest suprapubic EXT: trace pitting edema to mid shin NEURO: B/l ___ weakness, ___, roughly equal/symmetric, decreased sensation b/l feet, unable to elicit extremity reflexes DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: 24 HR Data (last updated ___ @ 1038) Temp: 98.6 (Tm 99.7), BP: 129/79 (119-159/66-94), HR: 94 (91-98), RR: 18 (___), O2 sat: 96% (96-99), O2 delivery: Ra GEN: Laying in bed, comfortable, NAD HEENT: Neck supple, MMM CV: RRR nl s1/s2 no mrg PULM: CTA b/l GI: Obese, soft, ND, non-tender EXT: trace pitting edema to mid shin NEURO: ___ strength in upper extremities, CN II-XII intact, B/l ___ weakness, ___, roughly equal/symmetric, decreased sensation b/l feet to above the knee, unable to elicit extremity reflexes <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: - ___ 04: 57PM BLOOD WBC-13.3* RBC-5.51 Hgb-15.9 Hct-48.2 MCV-88 MCH-28.9 MCHC-33.0 RDW-13.3 RDWSD-42.6 Plt ___ ___ 04: 57PM BLOOD Neuts-92.8* Lymphs-3.2* Monos-3.2* Eos-0.1* Baso-0.2 Im ___ AbsNeut-12.35* AbsLymp-0.43* AbsMono-0.43 AbsEos-0.01* AbsBaso-0.02 ___ 04: 57PM BLOOD Glucose-127* UreaN-15 Creat-1.1 Na-139 K-5.3 Cl-100 HCO3-23 AnGap-16 ___ 04: 57PM BLOOD ALT-16 AST-32 AlkPhos-116 TotBili-0.8 ___ 04: 57PM BLOOD Albumin-3.8 Calcium-9.0 Phos-4.2 Mg-1.8 DISCHARGE LABS: -= ___ 07: 11AM BLOOD WBC-5.6 RBC-4.61 Hgb-13.2* Hct-41.1 MCV-89 MCH-28.6 MCHC-32.1 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-43.4 Plt ___ ___ 11: 43AM BLOOD Neuts-76.7* Lymphs-13.6* Monos-9.0 Eos-0.0* Baso-0.2 Im ___ AbsNeut-4.34 AbsLymp-0.77* AbsMono-0.51 AbsEos-0.00* AbsBaso-0.01 ___ 07: 11AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-16 Creat-0.9 Na-141 K-4.3 Cl-105 HCO3-25 AnGap-11 ___ 11: 43AM BLOOD ALT-11 AST-12 LD(LDH)-103 AlkPhos-87 TotBili-0.6 ___ 07: 11AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-4.6* Mg-1.9 RELEVANT IMAGING: -=== ___ MRI IMPRESSION: 1. Unchanged faint enhancement of the cauda equina nerve roots, without thickening. 2. Unchanged degenerative changes of the lower lumbar spine. ___ CXR IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. No focal consolidation to suggest pneumonia. ___ CT abdomen IMPRESSION: 1. Fluid-filled non-dilated loops of small bowel, cecum and ascending colon, likely representing a viral gastroenteritis. No evidence of obstruction. The appendix is not visualized but there is no secondary sign of acute appendicitis. 2. Mild colonic diverticulosis without evidence of diverticulitis. 3. Hepatic steatosis. NOTIFICATION: The updated findings were discussed by Dr. ___ with Dr. ___ on the telephone on ___ at 8: 18 am, 5 minutes after discovery of the findings. <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were admitted to the hospital because of nausea and diarrhea and some worsening weakness. You had a CT scan completed that showed irritation in your gut (colon). We later found out that you had norovirus. By the time of discharge your diarrhea and nausea had resolved and we did not think you were contagious any longer. You were also sent for worsening weakness. Our neurology team evaluated you multiple times during your stay. You had an MRI that was unchanged. It was thought that this did not represent worsening of your GBS, thus you did not get any more IVIG. You have follow up with neurology in a few weeks. Please take your medications as prescribed. It was a pleasure taking care of you! Your ___ careteam

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Plaquenil / Daypro / Atenolol / Keppra <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Shortness of breath <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ female with history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, HTN, paroxysmal AF who presents with dyspnea on exertion. . The patient was in her usual state of health until two days ago when she developed progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion. This was not associated with any fevers, chills, cough, chest pain, dizziness or syncope. She has been admitted for this in the past, most recently in ___. This most recent episode is consistent with prior ones. Given this, she came to to ED for further evaluation. . On arrival to the ED, initial vital signs were T-98.6, HR-76, BP-143/68, RR-24, SaO2-100% 15L NRB. She was quickly weaned down to 2L NC and was breathing comfortably. She underwent LENIs and CTA which were negative for any thrombus. Imaging did show signs of fluid overload. There was also concern for RLL opacity so she was treated with levofloxacin 750mg IV. Given overall picture consistent with CHF, she also received lasix 20mg IV x 1. Vital signs on transfer were HR- 69, BP- 141/80, RR- 20, SaO2- 100% on 2L . On arrival to the floor, vital signs were T- 97.0, HR- 64, BP- 130/82, RR- 24, SaO2- 100% on 3L NC. The patient reports symptomatic improvement with the lasix and was resting comfortably. She responded very well to the lasix with a large amount of clear urine noted in the foley bag. She did report left thigh pain, located on the medial aspect, that had improved since yesterday. . ROS: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, chest pain, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Non-ischemic cardiomyopathy: TTE ___: EF 50-55%, LVH, mild MR and AR, moderate TR. - Cardiac Cath ___ with 40% LAD stenosis - Moderate pulmonary HTN - Hypertension - Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation on coumadin - Rheumatoid arthritis on methotrexate and prednisone - Macrocytic Anemia - Osteoarthritis - Gout - Osteoporosis - Pancreatic cyst: Already worked up by heme-onc, and adressed by PCP and GI, no further work up at this time recommended. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - Mother: DM, arthritis - Father: no health problems - No family history of premature CAD or SCD <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL: VS: T- 97.0, HR- 64, BP- 130/82, RR- 24, SaO2- 100% on 3L NC. GENERAL: Elderly female in NAD, comfortable, appropriate. HEENT: NC/AT, EOMI, MMM, OP clear. NECK: Supple, JVP of 10-12cm. LUNGS: Bilateral crackles heard throughout the lung fields with good respiratory effort. No signs of respiratory distress. HEART: Irregular rhythm, normal rate, no MRG, nl S1-S2. ABDOMEN: Soft/NT/ND, no rebound/guarding. EXTREMITIES: 1+ pitting edema in bilateral lower extremities. Both hands demonstrate severe ulnar deviation of metacarpophalangeal joints with joint subluxation and enlarged PIP joints SKIN: No rashes or lesions. NEURO: Awake, A&Ox3, CNs II-XII grossly intact, muscle strength ___ throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout, gait deferred. . DISCHARGE PHYSICAL: VS: 98 106/60 66 96%RA GENERAL: Elderly female in NAD, comfortable, appropriate. HEENT: NC/AT, EOMI, MMM, OP clear. NECK: Supple, JVP: ~7cm LUNGS: good inspiratory effort, minimal crackles at left base, no wheeze, no accessory muscle use HEART: Irregular rhythm, nl rhythm, nl S1-S2, soft SEM heard thru/out, no RG, no peripheral edema. ABDOMEN: Soft/NT/ND, no rebound/guarding. EXTREMITIES: no peripheral edema. Both hands demonstrate severe ulnar deviation of metacarpophalangeal joints with joint subluxation and enlarged PIP joints SKIN: No rashes or lesions. NEURO: Awake, A&Ox3, CNs II-XII grossly intact, muscle strength ___ throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout, gait deferred. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: =========== ___ 10: 55PM BLOOD WBC-5.7 RBC-2.90* Hgb-10.7* Hct-31.6* MCV-109* MCH-36.9* MCHC-33.9 RDW-16.4* Plt ___ ___ 10: 55PM BLOOD Neuts-79.2* Lymphs-16.5* Monos-2.4 Eos-1.4 Baso-0.5 ___ 10: 55PM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.4 ___ ___ 10: 55PM BLOOD Glucose-108* UreaN-27* Creat-0.9 Na-139 K-4.9 Cl-99 HCO3-28 AnGap-17 ___ 10: 55PM BLOOD CK-MB-4 cTropnT-0.01 proBNP-8683* ___ 06: 30AM BLOOD CK-MB-5 cTropnT-0.02* ___ 05: 00PM BLOOD CK-MB-5 cTropnT-0.02* ___ 06: 30AM BLOOD Calcium-8.4 Phos-3.0 Mg-1.6 . DISCHARGE LABS: ___ 07: 20 =========== WBC RBC Hgb Hct MCV MCH MCHC RDW Plt Ct 4.7 2.72* 9.9* 29.9* 110* 36.5* 33.2 17.0* 153 . Glucose UreaN Creat Na K Cl HCO3 AnGap 78 22 1.1 138 4.3 97 32 13 . INR: 1.6 (coumadin restarted on ___ . IMAGING: ====== CXR ___: Mild interstitial pulmonary edema with interval development of small bilateral pleural effusions. No focal pneumonia. . ___ ___: No evidence of left lower extremity deep venous thrombus. . CTA ___: 1. No pulmonary embolism. 2. Unchanged ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm measuring up to 4.3 cm. 3. Findings compatible with right-sided heart failure. Stable cardiomegaly. 4. New patchy linear and nodular abnormality in the right middle lobe, likelya combination of patchy atelectasis and small airways disease. Right basalatelectasis. 5. Left subpleural scarring is seen, similar to prior, including a focal area of subpleural opacity, likely reflecting an area of chronic atelectasis. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> ALENDRONATE - 35 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a week with 8 oz water 30 minutes before food, other meds, stay upright ALLOPURINOL - 300 mg Tablet - ___ Tablet(s) by mouth once a day - gout DIGOXIN [LANOXIN] - 125 mcg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth 3 times per week - ___ - rate control and heart failure ERGOCALCIFEROL (VITAMIN D2) [VITAMIN D] - 50,000 unit Capsule - 1 Capsule(s) by mouth once a week dx: osteoporosis with fractures FOLIC ACID - 1 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth DAILY FUROSEMIDE - (Dose adjustment - no new Rx) - 20 mg Tablet - 0.5 (One half) Tablet(s) by mouth every day + take extra ___ tab on any day that weight is 107 lb or more LATANOPROST [XALATAN] - 0.005 % Drops - 1 gtt in the left eye at bedtime LISINOPRIL - 5 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime - zestril METHOTREXATE SODIUM [METHOTREXATE (ANTI-RHEUMATIC)] - 2.5 mg Tablets, Dose Pack - 3 Tablets(s) by mouth once a week METOPROLOL SUCCINATE - 50 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime - toprol XL PRAVASTATIN - 10 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime - cholesterol PREDNISONE - 5 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day PREDNISONE - 1 mg Tablet - 4 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day SPIRONOLACTONE - (Dose adjustment - no new Rx) - 25 mg Tablet - 0.5 (One half) Tablet(s) by mouth every other day TRAMADOL - 50 mg Tablet - 0.5 (One half) Tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime every night (correct instructions) WARFARIN - 3 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth daily or as directed. Take in the evening. <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. spironolactone 25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. furosemide 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 3. warfarin 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAYS (___). 4. pravastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 5. allopurinol ___ mg Tablet Sig: 1.5 Tablets PO DAILY (Daily). 6. folic acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 7. alendronate 35 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a week: with 8 oz water 30 minutes before food, other meds, stay upright . 8. ergocalciferol (vitamin D2) 50,000 unit Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a week: dx: osteoporosis with fractures . 9. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 10. metoprolol succinate 50 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). 11. methotrexate sodium 2.5 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO once a week. 12. tramadol 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO at bedtime. 13. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain. 14. digoxin 125 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO 3X/WEEK (___). 15. Citracal + D Oral 16. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO once a day as needed for constipation. 17. vit C-vit E-lutein-minerals Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day. 18. Ensure Liquid Sig: One (1) can PO at bedtime. 19. prednisone 1 mg Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 20. latanoprost 0.005 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic HS (at bedtime): In left eye. 21. timolol maleate 0.25 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic DAILY (Daily): In left eye. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Acute on chronic diastolic heart failure Secondary: Atrial fibrillation Rheumatoid arthritis Gout <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to ___ with shortness of breath. On admission, you were fluid overloaded and your chest x-ray showed fluid in your lungs. A CT scan of your lungs did not show any clots. The fluid overload was likely caused by an exacerbation of your heart failure. We gave you diuretics at higher than your usual home dose and your fluid status improved. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs. We have made the following changes to your medications: - DECREASE your coumadin to 2mg daily. - INCREASE your lasix to 20mg daily. - Increase spirinolactone 12.5mg daily (from every other day). - Continue Prednisone dosing to 3mg daily.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Demerol / Iodine / Augmentin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> nausea and vomiting x 4 days <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Cardiac catherization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with medical history significant for Type I Diabetes with ESRD s/p renal transplant in ___ on chronic immunosuppressive agents, who presents with nausea and vomiting of 4 days' duration. Pt stated that this episode was more severe that her usual gastroparesis, and that while her vomiting has eased up in the last two days, she has not been able to tolerate any POs including water, causing her to miss all of her medications since ___. Pt also had loose stools x 4 since yesterday. She had chills, but no fevers that she knows of. . In the ED, she complained of substernal chest pain that felt like pressure with no radiation. Vitals were: 97.7 123 144/72 28 100% on RA. Pt was started on IVF 200cc/hr, Insulin drip 6 units/hr with Q 1hr ___, was given Levaquin 750 mg IV x 1, ASA 325 mg PO x 1, and Zofran 4 mg IV x 1. U cx and B cx were sent. EKG showed demand ischemia (was faxed to Cards fellow for review). CK and Trop sent. Kidney U/S showed mild pelviectasis. CXR demonstrated no acute process. . ROS: Positive for SOB, worse with activity; unintentional weight loss of ___ pounds in 3 months; worsening visual acuity; mild abdominal pain in lower quadrants. Negative for melena, hematochezia, chest pain, orthopnea, PND, lower extremity edema, cough, urinary frequency, urgency, dysuria, lightheadedness, gait unsteadiness, focal weakness, vision changes, headache, rash or skin changes. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Diabetes Type 1, s/p renal transplant in ___, with a history of episodes of diabetic ketoacidosis. Gastroparesis secondary to DM. Hypertension. Hypercholesterolemia. Coronary artery disease with an ejection fraction of 55% in ___, MI x2 and a three-vessel CABG in ___. Left below the knee amputation in ___. Vascular procedures on the right lower extremity. Heel ulcers due to diabetes, s/p bypass graft surgeries Peripheral neuropathy CVA x2. S/p cholecystectomy S/p cataract surgery Depression. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Uncle with diabetes Sister died of colon CA Mother died of brain CA <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: BP: HR: RR: O2Sat: GEN: Well-appearing, well-nourished, no acute distress HEENT: EOMI, PERRL, sclera anicteric, no epistaxis or rhinorrhea, MMM, OP Clear NECK: No JVD, carotid pulses brisk, no bruits, no cervical lymphadenopathy, trachea midline COR: RRR, no M/G/R, normal S1 S2, radial pulses +2 PULM: Lungs CTAB, no W/R/R ABD: Soft, NT, ND, +BS, no HSM, no masses EXT: No C/C/E, no palpable cords NEURO: alert, oriented to person, place, and time. CN II  XII grossly intact. Moves all 4 extremities. Strength ___ in upper and lower extremities. Patellar DTR +1. Plantar reflex downgoing. No gait disturbance. No cerebellar dysfunction. SKIN: No jaundice, cyanosis, or gross dermatitis. No ecchymoses. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Labs (blood) ___ 03: 30PM WBC-14.7 Hgb-12.6 Hct-41.1 MCV-92 MCH-28.3 MCHC-30.7 RDW-13.7 Plt ___ Neuts-92* Bands-0 Lymphs-5.0* Monos-3 Eos-0 Baso-0 ___ PTT-24.2 ___ Glucose-759* UreaN-49* Creat-1.7* Na-130* K-5.6* Cl-86* HCO3-11* Calcium-9.6 Phos-4.2# Mg-2.3 ALT-18 AST-16 LD(LDH)-181 CK(CPK)-77 AlkPhos-213* TotBili-0.5 Lipase-12 cTropnT-0.10* Acetone-LARGE ASA-4 Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG pH-7.31* Glucose-GREATER TH Lactate-3.0* Na-132* K-5.4* Cl-93* calHCO3-11* freeCa-1.04* . Labs (urine) ___ 04: 20PM Color-Straw Appear-Clear Sp ___ Blood-LG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR Glucose-1000 Ketone-150 Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.0 Leuks-NEG ___ Bacteri-FEW Yeast-NONE ___ UTox: bnzodzp-NEG barbitr-NEG opiates-NEG cocaine-NEG amphetm-NEG mthdone-NEG . ___ renal transplant ultrasound FINDINGS: A transplanted kidney is visualized in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen and measures 10.8 cm in length. The corticomedullary differentiation is preserved. Mild pelviectasis is noted which appears new compared to the most recent prior study in ___. Doppler assessment demonstrates resistive indices of the upper, mid and lower poles of 0.8, 1.0, and 1.0. Normal venous flow is demonstrated in the main renal vein. While the arterial upstroke is good in the main renal artery there is minimal diastolic flow. Limited images of the bladder are unremarkable. IMPRESSION: Right lower quadrant transplanted kidney with mild new pelviectasis. Elevated resistive indices as described. Clinical correlation is recommended. . ___ CXR FINDINGS: The lungs are clear without consolidation or edema. There is evidence of prior median sternotomy and CABG. There is convexity involving the AP window which is stable from the prior exam. The cardiac silhouette size is within normal limits. Again seen is minimal blunting of the left costophrenic angle possibly due to the scarring or small effusion. No pneumothorax is noted. The bones are diffusely osteopenic but otherwise unremarkable. The patient has had prior cholecystectomy. IMPRESSION: Relatively stable radiographic examination demonstrating no acute process. . ___ ECG: Sinus tachycardia at 127 bpm, nl axis, nl PR, QRS, and QT intervals, fair R-wave progress, 2mm ST depression in V4-6. . ___ Cardiac cath: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this left dominant system revealed 3 vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA was normal. The LAD had mild luminal irregularities proximally with a total mid-segment occlusion. D1 was patent with moderate diffuse disease. The LCX is a dominant vessel with mild luminal irregularities. The non-dominant RCA had moderate diffuse disease. 2. Graft arteriography revealed a patent LIMA-LAD, and stump occluded SVGs to OM1 and PDA. 3. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed systemic arterial hypertension with aortic pressures of 178/64 and mildly elevated left sided filling pressures with LVEDP of 17. There was no transaortic pressure gradient on pullback of catheter from LV to aorta. 4. Left ventriculography was not performed. . ___ L femoral U/S No evidence of pseudoaneurysm. . <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Cymbalta, hydromorphone, furosemide, prednisone, nitroglycerin, Isordil, Plavix, Prograf, glyburide, tramadol, metoprolol, CellCept, gabapentin, ASA, piroxicam, Lipitor, and insulin. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Diabetic ketoacidosis Non ST-elevation myocardial infarction Right foot ulcer . Secondary: Diabetes Type 1, s/p renal transplant Gastroparesis secondary to diabetes. Hypertension. Hypercholesterolemia. Left below the knee amputation Vascular procedures on the right lower extremity. Peripheral neuropathy cerebrovascular accident x2. S/p cholecystectomy S/p cataract surgery Depression. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Good, stable. Tolerating POs well <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital because you were extremely dehydrated and had high blood sugars. We treated you with intravenous fluids and insulin drip, which resolved the acidosis of your blood caused by high sugar. . You had episodes of chest pain during this hospitalization, with elevation of cardiac enzymes. We performed cardiac catherization to evaluate the cause of these frequent chest pains. It showed that your heart arteries are diffusely narrow, with blockage of two out of three bypass grafts, which were also previously seen in ___. No interventions were made. . The following changes were made to your medication regimen: Isordil 20 mg twice a day --> Imdur 60 mg daily Lipitor 10 mg daily --> Lipitor 80 mg daily Aspirin 81 mg daily --> Aspirin 325 mg daily Please resume all of your other medications. It is very important that you take all medications, especially your immunosuppression medications (CellCept, Tacrolimus, Prednisone). . Please attend all of your follow-up appointments. . If you have severe chest pain, nausea/vomiting, shortness of breath, palpitations, or any other concerning symptoms, please call your primary care physician or return to the emergency room. . ***For today, ___, please take 12 units of Lantus with dinner. Starting tomorrow, you can resume taking 18 units of Lantus once a day with dinner, along with Glyburide and carbohydrate counting for short-acting insulin.***

Cardiac cath shows multivessel coronary disease. He was transferred to ___ for evaluation of coronary artery revascularization. Valve - E Wave deceleration time: 223 ms 140-250 ms TR Gradient (+ RA = PASP): 25 mm Hg <= 25 mm Hg Findings LEFT ATRIUM: Normal LA and RA cavity sizes. RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: No ASD by 2D or color Doppler. LEFT VENTRICLE: Mild symmetric LVH with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). No resting LVOT gradient. RIGHT VENTRICLE: Mildly dilated RV cavity. Normal RV systolic function. AORTA: Normal diameter of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels. Focal calcifications in aortic root. No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation. AORTIC VALVE: Normal aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. No AR. MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. No MVP. Mild thickening of mitral valve chordae. Mild (1+) MR. ___ VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets. Mild [1+] TR. Normal PA systolic pressure. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with normal free wall contractility. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and systolic function. Minimally dilated right ventricle with normal systolic function. Mild mitral regurgitation. What appears to be a pleural line at the lower portion of this area could merely reflect the cartilaginous calcification in the superior aspect of the first rib on the left. Edema <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please shower daily including washing incisions gently with mild soap, no baths or swimming until cleared by surgeon. Look at your incisions daily for redness or drainage Please NO lotions, cream, powder, or ointments to incisions Each morning you should weigh yourself and then in the evening take your temperature, these should be written down on the chart No driving for one month or while taking narcotics. Driving will be discussed at follow up appointment with surgeon-when you will be able to drive No lifting more than 10 pounds for 10 weeks **Please call cardiac surgery office with any questions or concerns ___. Answering service will contact on call person during off hours**

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Gout flare <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with hx gout, atrial flutter, HTN, COPD, DM2, HLD, and recent surgery for spinal stenosis complains of one day of sudden onset L knee pain. The patient stated the pain came on suddenly the morning prior to admission and got progressively worse throughout the day. He stated the knee was very red and swollen. By that evening he was unable to bear weight and came to the ED. The patient stated that the joint pain felt like a gout flare. He denied any fevers, hx of trauma. He has had 3 gout flares in his life, the last one in ___. He thinks the joint was tapped back in ___ and showed gout crystals. His previous episodes have been in his ankle. He does not know what precipitates the attacks. In the ED the patient's intial vitals were 98.2 88 141/58 12 95% ra. He was given colchicine 0.6mg tabs x4, 50mg indomethacin, probenicid ___. Xray of the knee showed soft tissue swelling about the right knee with small joint effusion, as well as "redemonstration of scalloped appearance of the anterior aspect of the femoral trochlea of indeterminate etiology and chronicity". His pain and edema/erythema improved markedly in the ED. ___ saw the patient and because he could not walk well (and has to climb stairs at his apt) he was admitted for further optimizaiton of his pain. On the floor, vs were: 97.3 BP: 144/76 P: 66 R: 20 O2: 95% RA <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> From OMR: Hypertension, Essential Microscopic Hematuria Gout COPD Type 2 diabetes mellitus with renal manifestations, controlled Hyperlipidemia History of Colon Cancer SPINAL STENOSIS - LUMBAR besity Renal cell cancer s/p radiofrequency ablation to two lesions ___. Third stable cystic suspicious left renal lesion, stable on repeat MRI through ___ Atrial flutter <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother - smoker, emphysema Father - ETOH abuse, gout <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYISCAL EXAM: Vitals: T: 97.3 BP: 144/76 P: 66 R: 20 O2: 95% RA General: AAOx3, NAD HEENT: MMM, PERRL Neck: no LAD, supple CV: RRR no m/r/g Lungs: CTAB Abdomen: soft, NTD Ext: L knee with effusion, mildly erythematous, mildly TTP Neuro: ___ strength throughout DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: VSS General: AAOx3, NAD HEENT: MMM, PERRL Neck: no LAD, supple CV: RRR no m/r/g Lungs: CTAB Abdomen: soft, NTD Ext: L knee with decreased effusion and erythema, NTP Neuro: ___ strength throughout, intermediate rectal tone, able to bear down, sensation to touch intact over extremities and in perianal area <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD WBC-9.9 RBC-3.69* Hgb-13.2* Hct-36.7* MCV-100*# MCH-35.9* MCHC-36.1* RDW-13.3 Plt ___ ___ 12: 15AM BLOOD Glucose-138* UreaN-19 Creat-1.0 Na-135 K-3.8 Cl-100 HCO3-26 AnGap-13 DISCHARGE LABS: ___ 07: 25AM BLOOD WBC-6.0 RBC-3.47* Hgb-12.5* Hct-35.4* MCV-102* MCH-36.2* MCHC-35.4* RDW-13.3 Plt ___ ___ 07: 25AM BLOOD Glucose-94 UreaN-22* Creat-1.1 Na-140 K-4.1 Cl-104 HCO___ AnGap-13 ___ 07: 25AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-2.8 Mg-1.7 UricAcd-4.8 STUDIES: Left knee xray ___: IMPRESSION: 1. Soft tissue swelling about the right knee with small joint effusion. 2. Redemonstration of scalloped appearance of the anterior aspect of the femoral trochlea of indeterminate etiology and chronicity. Please see prior recommendations. MICRO: None <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Calcium 500 + D (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 600/400 units Oral daily 3. Diltiazem Extended-Release 240 mg PO DAILY 4. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 5. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 6. Probenecid ___ mg PO BID 7. Ranitidine 150 mg PO BID 8. Simvastatin 10 mg PO HS 9. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg PO DAILY 3. Diltiazem Extended-Release 240 mg PO DAILY 4. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 5. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 6. Probenecid ___ mg PO BID RX *probenecid ___ mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 RX *probenecid ___ mg Two tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*120 Tablet Refills: *0 7. Ranitidine 150 mg PO BID 8. Simvastatin 10 mg PO HS 9. Calcium 500 + D (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 600/400 units Oral daily <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Gout flare <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay. You were admitted on ___ for a gout flare in your left knee. You were given four doses of colchicine and one dose of indomethacin in the emergency room, which greatly improved your pain. Your home dose of probenecid was increased to prevent these gout flares in the future. You were seen by physical therapy who recommended discharge to home with physical therapy services at home. Please follow up with your primary care physician in ___ week after discharge.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> aspirin / Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> dyspnea and 3 pound weight gain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with PMHx AFib, AS s/p aortic pioprosthetic valve, infarct related CM systolic HF (LVEF 25 % s/p PP ICD), Hx VTE (PE) on pradaxa, and dementia with recent admission for hematemesis, abdominal pain found to have incarcerated left inguinal hernia s/p repair with mesh ___, who presents from home with several days of SOB, and 1 day of chest pain. He was accompanied by his daughter ___ in the ED, who lives with him, and states that over the past week since he's been home from rehab, he has been having increasing dyspnea, with weight gain of approx. 3 lbs over the weekend. She states that ___ and ___ were prescribed at home since he left rehab, however the services have not been visiting as frequently as they used were prior to last hospital admission. Of note, due to hypotension, patients home metoprolol was held at last discharge on ___. During his recent hospitalization for hernia repair, cardiology was consulted and noted his CHF to be stable, with euvolemia. In the ED, initial vitals were 97.1 64 120/75 18 98% RA Patient had labs that showed trop 0.02 X2, nl chem-7 with creat 1.1 (at baseline 1.0-1.1), BNP 3655 (only other bnp on file 3355), INR 1.3, h/h 11.1/33.7 (stable). He had CXR that showed no acute cardiopulmonary process. He was given 40 iv Lasix, as well as 1000 mg apap and 0.4 mg tamsulosin. He urinated 500 cc of urine to the Lasix. Patient spent the majority of the day in the ED and did not receive AM home medications. At 1545 he was intermittently with SVT to 130s, and at that time received home metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily. Transfer vitals were 97.1 64 120/75 18 98% RA Given concern for fluid overload, he was admitted to the HF service. On arrival to the floor, he reports that yesterday had one episode of chest pain of left side radiating from site of ICD to hands and then disappeared. He also had associated headache. He denies any active CP or SOB. Review of sytems: (+) Per HPI, also reports fever at home a few days ago, weight gain as above, headache (-) Denies sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Ten point review of systems is otherwise negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Cardiac PMHx: CAD w/ diffuse luminal irregularities in LAD/LCx, 50% lesion in proximal RCA Systolic HF LVEF 25% s/p ICD (placed secondary ppx given ?VT hx) Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation on NOAC AS s/p aortic bioprosthetic valve Other PMHx: HLD BPH PAD Narcolepsy COPD Hearing loss Past Surgical History: Right inguinal hernia repair - long time ago, reported by daughter ___ left inguinal hernia repair with mesh - ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: -==== VS: AF BP ___ 18 93% RA Weight: 63kg General: NAD, comfortable, pleasant, speaking in full sentences, occasionally yells out ___: NCAT, PERRL, EOMI, MMM Neck: supple, JVD just above clavicle at 45 degrees CV: irregular rhythm, grade ___ diastolic murmur heard best at RUSB Lungs: Decrease breath sounds at bases. No rhonchi or wheezes or rales. Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, BS+, left inguinal wound clean and dry Ext: WWP, no c/c/e, Neuro: moving all extremities grossly, alert to person, knows he is in hospital, knows Halloween is soon but does not know month, states "16" as year DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: -==== VS: T 98.2 BP 114/66 HR 68 RR 18 O2 sat 98 RA Wt: 62.5 kg General: NAD, comfortable, pleasant, speaking in full sentences, alert and oriented to self, birthdate, hospital ___, year "___", day ___, knows who the president is ___ and the current presidential candidates ___ & ___: NCAT, PERRL, EOMI; tender to palpation R lower jaw; no oral lesions, no erythema or tenderness on gums; poor dentition Neck: supple, flat JVP CV: irregular rhythm, grade ___ diastolic murmur heard best at RUSB Lungs: CTAB, good inspiratory effort Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, BS+, left inguinal wound clean and dry Ext: WWP, no c/c/e Neuro: moving all extremities sponatenously, follows basic commands but inattentive at times, AAOx3 as above <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: -= ___ 11: 15PM BLOOD WBC-6.7 RBC-3.61* Hgb-11.1* Hct-33.7* MCV-93 MCH-30.7 MCHC-32.9 RDW-15.5 RDWSD-52.4* Plt ___ ___ 11: 15PM BLOOD Neuts-55.5 ___ Monos-9.1 Eos-3.0 Baso-0.4 Im ___ AbsNeut-3.73# AbsLymp-2.13 AbsMono-0.61 AbsEos-0.20 AbsBaso-0.03 ___ 11: 15PM BLOOD ___ PTT-45.1* ___ ___ 11: 15PM BLOOD Glucose-86 UreaN-19 Creat-1.1 Na-138 K-3.7 Cl-97 HCO3-26 AnGap-19 ___ 11: 15PM BLOOD proBNP-3655* ___ 11: 15PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.02* ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.02* ___ 11: 37PM BLOOD Lactate-1.4 ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD Iron-63 ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD calTIBC-259* Ferritn-106 TRF-199* DISCHARGE LABS: -== ___ 08: 35AM BLOOD WBC-7.8 RBC-3.90* Hgb-12.2* Hct-36.7* MCV-94 MCH-31.3 MCHC-33.2 RDW-15.9* RDWSD-53.2* Plt ___ ___ 08: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-85 UreaN-26* Creat-1.2 Na-139 K-4.2 Cl-99 HCO3-26 AnGap-18 ___ 08: 35AM BLOOD Calcium-9.6 Phos-3.8 Mg-2.5 ___ 08: 35AM BLOOD TSH-2.3 STUDIES/REPORTS: -=== ___ ICD INTERROGATION 1. ICD function normal with acceptable lead measurements and battery status. See report for full detail. 2. Programming changes: none 3. Follow-up scheduled: ___ ___ TTE No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated. Overall left ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 25 %) with global hypokinesis and inferio/infero-lateral thinning/akinesis. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. The right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with mild global free wall hypokinesis. A bioprosthetic aortic valve prosthesis is present. Mild to moderate (___) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, no clear change. ___ CXR There is no focal consolidation, pleural effusion, pulmonary edema, or pneumothorax. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged, including mild cardiomegaly and a tortuous descending aorta. A single chamber pacemaker, prosthetic valve, sternotomy wires, and mediastinal clips project in unchanged location. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 2. Acetaminophen 500 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Mild 3. Finasteride 5 mg PO QHS 4. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 5. Spironolactone 12.5 mg PO DAILY 6. Torsemide 40 mg PO DAILY 7. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 8. Tamsulosin 0.8 mg PO QHS 9. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY: PRN constipation 10. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5 mg PO Q4H: PRN jaw pain 11. Dabigatran Etexilate 110 mg PO BID 12. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 13. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY 14. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID: PRN constipation 15. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 500 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Mild 2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 3. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 4. Dabigatran Etexilate 110 mg PO BID 5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID: PRN constipation 6. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg PO DAILY 7. Finasteride 5 mg PO QHS 8. Fluticasone Propionate 110mcg 2 PUFF IH BID 9. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 10. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 11. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 2.5 mg PO Q4H: PRN jaw pain 12. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY: PRN constipation 13. Spironolactone 12.5 mg PO DAILY 14. Tamsulosin 0.8 mg PO QHS 15. Torsemide 40 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Diagnosis: Acute on chronic systolic heart failure exacerbation <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You came to the hospital because you were short of breath and had a few pound weight gain. We think you felt this way because you had too much salt in your diet at home and with your heart failure, you retained fluid. While at the hospital we gave your IV medicine to get the extra fluid off, and you are returning to home on your home medications. We did not change any of your home medications. Please weigh yourself daily in the morning after urinating on a good quality scale in light weight clothing. Call your cardiologist's office ___ if your weight goes up by more than 3lbs in one day or 5lbs in three days. We sent you home with extra torsemide pills. You can take an extra pill in the afternoon if you find your weight is increasing by a few pounds. If you have any questions, call your cardiology doctors office for advice. We wish you all the best! Your ___ Care Team
