input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> respiratory distress <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Chest tube placement-pigtail on right, pigtail/chest tube on left. Intubation Mechanical ventilation <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with CAD s/p PCI, AFib on coumadin, breast CA s/p radical mastectomy, recent admission at ___ ___ for cough and dyspnea due to a left pleural effusion and pericardial effusion complicated by pericardial tamponade. Underwent pericardiocentesis ___ with removal of 400 cc serosanguineous fluid - WBC 2778 (86%PMN 6% lymph 8% mono) Hct 2.0 Tprot 5.1 gluc 105 LDH 461 amylase 24 albumin 2.7. Pericardial drain placed but removed prior to discharge. Left-sided thoracentesis ___ with removal of 600 cc fluid - WBC 660 (11% PMN 5% lymph 77% macro 4% reactive mesothelial cells) RBC 470 Tprot 3.5 (serum total protein 5.3) gluc 97 LDH 88 (serum LDH 153). Cultures from these sites have been no growth to date and cytology from both taps was negative for malignant cells. Referred from ___ for acute dyspnea and markedly diminished breath sounds on the left. ABG on NRB 7.42/58/189/37. Diverted to ___ temporarily for hypotension and hypoxemia (BP and O2sat not documented). Stabilized then transferred to ___. . In the ED, initial VS T 96.7 HR 71 SBP 105 RR 22 O2sat100%NRB. WBC# 22.1 (from 25.9 on ___ with 92% PMN, Hct 23.9 (27.4 on ___, INR 3.8, lactate 1.2, Na 127, K 5.9, Cl 89, CO2 34, BUN 32, Cr 2.1. EKG showed sinus with 1st degree AV conduction delay and old inferiolateral T-wave inversions, but no QRS prolongation or peaked T-waves. CXR showed complete opacification of the left hemithorax without mediastinal shift, and a small to moderate right pleural effusion. Non-contrast chest CT showed left lung collapse and simple pleural effusion and increased pericardial effusion since ___. Bedside U/S reportedly showed a circumferential effusion but no evidence of tamponade. BP nadir 87/40, given 500 cc NS bolus, improved to 101/50. Given vancomycin 1 g, zosyn 4.5 g IV, 1 amp D50, 10U regular insulin, 1 amp CaGluc. Thoracic surgery consulted, plan for thoracentesis vs. pigtail catheter when coagulopathy corrected, as well as for possible VATS pericardial window & talc pleurodesis on ___. Cardiology consulted but repeat pericardiocentesis deferred. Vital signs prior to transfer 97.2 86 110/51 19 100% on 100%NRB. . Upon arrival in the MICU, patient is without complaints. Endorses shortness of breath with minimal exertion and cough with white sputum. Denies fever, chills, sweats, chest pain, palpitations, nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea, dysuria, edema, or rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CAD s/p PCI ___ 2. SBP/volvulus ___ s/p abdominal laparatomy with LOA and extensive R colectomy/ileocolic anastomosis ___. Breast cancer s/p L radical mastectomy ___. 4. Iron deficiency anemia. 5. Hypertension. 6. Gastroesophageal reflux disease. 7. Hypothyroidism. 8. h/o hyponatremia (on sodium chloride at home) 9. Intracranial hemorrhage ___. 10. Depression. 11. Hypercholesterolemia. 12. Osteoporosis with history of vertebral compression fractures. 13. Stable meningioma. 14. Recurrent UTI 15. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / trimethoprim <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> bilateral SDHs and right temporal intracranial hemorrhage <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is an ___ year old man with a past medical history of PD, afib not on anticoagulation ___ falls, HTN, and COPD who presents today with confusion. He was initially brought to ___, and was transferred here upon finding of left hemispheric SDH and left temporal IPH. History is obtained from his son who is in the room. The patient lives in an assisted living facility, and has regular home health aides with him about 16 hours a day (they are gone from about 10pm to 8am). He had reportedly been in his usual state of health on ___, and his son talked to him on the phone (although, there is some concern for confusion as he called his daughter many times for his son's phone numbers, which he had and usually knows this). His other son was at the patient's house for dinner last night and did not note anything unusual. Then, this morning, when his regular home health aide came to see him, she felt that he was somewhat confused. Not many details are available, however it seems he was innattentive, and had to be fed, which is unusual. The aide put him in his recliner, and he seemed "out of it." She talked to his family, and the plan was to check his urine for a UTI. Around 3pm, a new aide came, and she could not rouse him. Therefore he was brought to ___. There, he was noted to have a left facial droop and drift. Heart rate 90-130s, BP unknwon. ___ showed an acute left SDH and left temporal IPH. Labs, including BMP, CBC, LFTs, and coags were wnl. Troponin was 0.05. He was transferred to ___ ___ where neurology was called. He has had no falls or head injuries that anyone knows of. He has a urinal with him in bed, so son does not think that he gets out of bed to go to the bathroom in the middle of the night. The son thinks it is unlikely he had an unwitnessed fall because if he did, he would not be able to get himself up off the floor. When asked if he hit his head, he says "no." At baseline, he has hypophonia and trouble getting his words out (freezing when talking) and has speech therapy. Otherwise he is described as "very sharp and alert" (would know the date, the president, etc). He can still prepare meals. (esually microwaves). He mainly uses a wheelchair to get around. He has frozen shoulders, torn rotator cuffs, R>L. He has had ___ for about ___ years. He has not missed any medicines. ROS not obtained due to altered mental status/aphasia. He denies pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - ___ Disease - Afib ___ ___ not anticoagulated due to falls) - HTN - COPD - C1 fracture ___ - chronic venous stasis (___) - h/o traumatic injury to LLE - carpal tunnel syndrome - cellulitis - high grade neuroendocrine ampullary tumor w/ ? liver mets (s/p Whipple at ___) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> NC <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Exam on Admission: <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 99.5 90 141/71 16 97% RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no masses or organomegaly noted. Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP pulses bilaterally. Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. Neurologic: -Mental Status: Lying in bed with eyes closed, opens to voice. Limited verbal output, follows commands. Attends to both sides and looks to both sides but does not fully look to the right (requires encouragement). Follows midline and appendicular commands. +grasp reflex b/l. -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: Left pupil 2-->1.5, right 1.5 minimally reacts. Blinks to threat consistently on the left, appears to have right upper field cut. III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus except some difficulty with rightward gaze as above, crosses the midline. Normal saccades. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch. VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric. VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes in midline. -Motor: Normal bulk, increased tone throughout. Right pronator drift. No adventitious movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis noted. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ L 5 ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 R 5 ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 -Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick, cold sensation, vibratory sense, proprioception throughout. No extinction to DSS. -DTRs: ___ Tri ___ Pat Ach L 2 2 2 2 1 R 2 2 2 2 1 Plantar response was flexor bilaterally. -Coordination: No tremor or dysmetria noted. -Gait: Not tested. Physical Exam on Discharge: afebrile, normotensive MS - awake, alert, regards examiner, able to follow midline and appendicular commands, unable to give name/location/date, able to repeat one word, motor persistence CN - blinks to threat in all quadrants, restriction of gaze in all directions (vertical and horizontal > lateral), face is grossly symmetric at rest and with activation, hearing intact to loud voice, voice is severely hypophonic, tongue is midline MOTOR - +paratonia and cogwheeling (RUE > LUE), no adventitious movements noted; downward drift with LUE, no pronator drift appreciated, increased tone in B/L ___ ___nd LUE; briefly antigravity with B/L IPs, R TA and Gas ___, L TA 5-, L Gas 5 SENSORY - withdraws to nox in B/L ___ - +glabellar, +grasp (L>R) COORD - no gross evidence of truncal or appendicular ataxia <PERTINENT RESULTS> Relevant Labs: ___ 07: 08PM WBC-7.0 RBC-4.46* HGB-11.7* HCT-35.6* MCV-80*# MCH-26.2* MCHC-32.8 RDW-14.9 ___ 07: 08PM NEUTS-81.9* LYMPHS-11.5* MONOS-5.5 EOS-0.8 BASOS-0.3 ___ 07: 08PM ___ PTT-34.3 ___ ___ 03: 56AM GLUCOSE-117* UREA N-21* CREAT-0.6 SODIUM-138 POTASSIUM-3.6 CHLORIDE-103 TOTAL CO2-27 ANION GAP-12 ___ 03: 56AM ALT(SGPT)-3 AST(SGOT)-13 LD(LDH)-155 CK(CPK)-108 ALK PHOS-98 TOT BILI-0.7 ___ 03: 56AM %HbA1c-5.9 eAG-123 ___ 03: 56AM TSH-0.56 ___ 03: 56AM TRIGLYCER-49 HDL CHOL-37 CHOL/HDL-2.7 LDL(CALC)-53 Imaging: ___ ___ Small left-sided temporal lobe conclusion and small subdural collection again identified. No significant interval change is seen. A right inferomedial frontal the encephalomalacia is again identified. There is no acute hemorrhage seen. There is no midline shift or hydrocephalus. Bilateral cerebellar calcifications are seen. MRI/A brain ___. Unchanged left temporal lobe intraparenchymal hematoma as described in detail above. Unchanged areas of encephalomalacia on the frontal lobes and left basal ganglia. 2. Bilateral subdural collections are seen with no significant mass effect, more evident on the left side causing mild midline shifting of the normally midline structures towards the right. Small trace of intraventricular blood is identified in the right occipital ventricular horn. 3. Unremarkable MRA of the head with no evidence of flow stenotic lesions or aneurysms. Unremarkable MRV of the head with no evidence of dural venous sinus thrombosis. Chest xray Lung volumes are lower today, but mild cardiomegaly is stable. Lungs are grossly clear. Metoprolol Tartrate 37.5 mg PO BID <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Left SDH/temporal IPH and small R SDH <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Confused - sometimes. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or wheelchair. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were admitted to the hospital with confusion and were found to have bleeding in your brain. We think this is most likely due to trauma to your head. We did an MRI brain which did not show any other explanations for the bleeding. You can re-start your aspirin on ___. After discharge, you will follow up in stroke neurology clinic with Dr. ___. The office will call you to schedule this. In case you need it, the # is ___. The following changes were made to your medications: STOP Aspirin 325mg Lasix 40mg START Aspirin 81mg on ___ INCREASE Metoprolol to 37.5mg bid It was a pleasure taking care of you, we wish you all the best!
reduced_text: <|begin_of_text|><SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / trimethoprim <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> bilateral SDHs and right temporal intracranial hemorrhage <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is an ___ year old man with a past medical history of PD, afib not on anticoagulation ___ falls, HTN, and COPD who presents today with confusion. He was initially brought to ___, and was transferred here upon finding of left hemispheric SDH and left temporal IPH. History is obtained from his son who is in the room. The patient lives in an assisted living facility, and has regular home health aides with him about 16 hours a day (they are gone from about 10pm to 8am). He had reportedly been in his usual state of health on ___, and his son talked to him on the phone (although, there is some concern for confusion as he called his daughter many times for his son's phone numbers, which he had and usually knows this). His other son was at the patient's house for dinner last night and did not note anything unusual. Then, this morning, when his regular home health aide came to see him, she felt that he was somewhat confused. Not many details are available, however it seems he was innattentive, and had to be fed, which is unusual. The aide put him in his recliner, and he seemed "out of it." She talked to his family, and the plan was to check his urine for a UTI. Around 3pm, a new aide came, and she could not rouse him. Therefore he was brought to ___. There, he was noted to have a left facial droop and drift. Heart rate 90-130s, BP unknwon. ___ showed an acute left SDH and left temporal IPH. Labs, including BMP, CBC, LFTs, and coags were wnl. Troponin was 0.05. He was transferred to ___ ___ where neurology was called. He has had no falls or head injuries that anyone knows of. He has a urinal with him in bed, so son does not think that he gets out of bed to go to the bathroom in the middle of the night. The son thinks it is unlikely he had an unwitnessed fall because if he did, he would not be able to get himself up off the floor. When asked if he hit his head, he says "no." At baseline, he has hypophonia and trouble getting his words out (freezing when talking) and has speech therapy. Otherwise he is described as "very sharp and alert" (would know the date, the president, etc). He can still prepare meals. (esually microwaves). He mainly uses a wheelchair to get around. He has frozen shoulders, torn rotator cuffs, R>L. He has had ___ for about ___ years. He has not missed any medicines. ROS not obtained due to altered mental status/aphasia. He denies pain. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - ___ Disease - Afib ___ ___ not anticoagulated due to falls) - HTN - COPD - C1 fracture ___ - chronic venous stasis (___) - h/o traumatic injury to LLE - carpal tunnel syndrome - cellulitis - high grade neuroendocrine ampullary tumor w/? liver mets (s/p Whipple at ___) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> NC <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Exam on Admission: <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 99.5 90 141/71 16 97% RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no masses or organomegaly noted. Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP pulses bilaterally. Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. Neurologic: -Mental Status: Lying in bed with eyes closed, opens to voice. Limited verbal output, follows commands. Attends to both sides and looks to both sides but does not fully look to the right (requires encouragement). Follows midline and appendicular commands. +grasp reflex b/l. -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: Left pupil 2-->1.5, right 1.5 minimally reacts. Blinks to threat consistently on the left, appears to have right upper field cut. III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus except some difficulty with rightward gaze as above, crosses the midline. Normal saccades. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch. VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric. VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes in midline. -Motor: Normal bulk, increased tone throughout. Right pronator drift. No adventitious movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis noted. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ L 5 ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 R 5 ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 -Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick, cold sensation, vibratory sense, proprioception throughout. No extinction to DSS. -DTRs: ___ Tri ___ Pat Ach L 2 2 2 2 1 R 2 2 2 2 1 Plantar response was flexor bilaterally. -Coordination: No tremor or dysmetria noted. -Gait: Not tested. Physical Exam on Discharge: afebrile, normotensive MS - awake, alert, regards examiner, able to follow midline and appendicular commands, unable to give name/location/date, able to repeat one word, motor persistence CN - blinks to threat in all quadrants, restriction of gaze in all directions (vertical and horizontal > lateral), face is grossly symmetric at rest and with activation, hearing intact to loud voice

Suboptimal evaluation of the lung parenchyma due to respiratory motion artifact, there is complete collapsibility of bronchus intermedius and near-complete collapse of bilateral upper lobe bronchi. 2. 38% decrease of tracheal area at the sternal notch and 62% decrease at approximately 2 cm above the carina. Persistent severe bronchomalacia with mainstem bronchi measuring less than 3 mm with near-complete collapse on expiration. However, as noted above, respiratory motion results in incomplete analysis of inspiratory and expiratory measurements. 3. Multiple new bilateral parenchymal opacities, with more confluent within the bilateral lower lobes, are concerning for aspiration with some element of mucoid impaction. 4. Stable subsolid lesion with ground-glass opacity and cystic foci, currently measuring 18 x 10 mm, previously 16 x 13 mm. Given the degree of respiratory motion artifact, these measurements are approximation. 5. Moderate-to-severe centrilobular emphysema. 6. Persistent prominence of the main pulmonary artery, measuring up to 3.1 cm. Given patient's known background moderate to severe centrilobular emphysema, this is likely a sequela of pulmonary arterial hypertension. CXR ___ IMPRESSION: Decreased small pleural effusions. No new consolidation. CXR ___ IMPRESSION: In comparison with study of ___, there is little change in the degree of enlargement of the cardiac silhouette and pulmonary edema with continued small bilateral pleural effusions and compressive atelectasis at the bases. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Tegretol / Advil <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abrupt awakenings x 2 overnight <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with dCHF, pulmonary HTN, intersitial lung disease, obstructive sleep apnea who presented to the ED because of 2 episodes of self-reported apnea overnight. Patient states that she was asleep overnight with her CPAP and abruptly woke up. She was not acutely short of breath, and was able to breath right away, but thought she possibly had an episode of apnea. She sat up, but was very sleepy so sat up but fell asleep again without her CPAP on. She later awoke again abruptly without dyspnea, again attributing it to apnea. She then slept for the rest of the night comfortably without CPAP until her CNA woke her up in the morning as per routine. Patient had plans for the day but decided to present to the ED for evaluation of her two abrupt awakenings overnight. Patient's CPAP does not have an apnea alarm. In further exploring her symptoms, patient reports she is (and has been in the recent few days) at her baseline ___ right sided chest pain and abdominal pain. She has an undulating course of shortness of breath also since ___, and although she has been on a mild upswing this week, she is not here for that complaint, as her breathing is still essentially within the worse limit of her baseline. However, she does believe she has been drinking more water lately (dry lips), and feels her ___ edema has worsened. Also reporting increased swelling/edema to lower pannus. She has had multiple admissions under circumstances (most recently in ___. She acknowledges that she sometimes has rib spasms and presents to the ED when she cannot regulate her breathing. BNP on prior admission noted to be at 2262. In the ED, initial vitals were 97.5 81 105/71 20 100% 15L nrb. While in the ED she was weaned to her home 3L O2. She was noted to have slight wheezing. CXR showed no acute process of volume overload. BNP ___, trop 0.02. pH 7.32 pCO2 62 pO2 34 HCO3 33. EKG showed new TWI in V5-V6, prompting admission to Cardiology for possible ACS vs. CHF. At present, she is at her baseline CP and is not particularly short of breath. She has no acute complaints except referring back to her nighttime awakenings as described above. She at first refused to speak to any interns and was upset about having to repeat her answers to H/P questions. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Diabetes, Dyslipidemia 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: - CABG: - PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: - PACING/ICD: 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - Morbid obesity. - Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. - Hypercholesterolemia. - Impaired fasting glucose. - Secondary amenorrhea. - Polycystic ovaries. - Asthma. - Obstructive sleep apnea on CPAP. - Depression. - Nephrolithiasis. - Epilepsy. - GERD. - Learning disability. - Recurrent sinusitis. - Restrictive lung disease, ILD vs hypersensitivity pneumonitis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother alive, h/o Breast Ca. Father had DM, d. Bladder Ca. Four siblings: 1 sister d. in fire, stepsister w/ RA. Nephew w/ asthma. No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 97.6 115/68 p98 R20 97% on 3LNC GENERAL: Obese lady in NAD, speaking in full sentences. Oriented x3. Irritable. Upset about answering questions she has already been asked. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: JVP not visible, possibly due to habitus CARDIAC: RR, S1, S2. SEM at ___. No r/g. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB. No crackles, wheezes or rhonchi appreciable. ABDOMEN: Soft, obsese. Nontender to palpation. Patient reporting increased swelling to lower pannus. EXTREMITIES: Trace pitting edema to extremities, with tense adipose. Distal pulses 1+ ___, 2+ UE bilaterally SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. NEURO: CN II-XII intact. Motor and sensory exam grossly normal. On discharge: VS: 145.4kg. 97.8 Tm 98.3, HR 64-68. BP 92/56-115/68, RR 20, 86-98% on CPAP, 97-98% on 2L I/O: ___ GENERAL: Obese woman in NAD, sleeping with CPAP, easily awakened, speaking in full sentences. Oriented x3. Irritable. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: JVP not visible, possibly due to habitus CARDIAC: RR, S1, S2. ___ SEM at ___. No r/g. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Mild crackles at R base. No wheezes or rhonchi appreciable. ABDOMEN: Soft, obsese. Nontender to palpation. EXTREMITIES: Trace pitting edema in lower extremities, with tense adipose. Distal pulses 1+ ___, 2+ UE bilaterally SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD WBC-11.0 RBC-5.25 Hgb-15.6 Hct-47.6 MCV-91 MCH-29.7 MCHC-32.7 RDW-13.8 Plt ___ ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD Neuts-67.1 ___ Monos-4.8 Eos-4.0 Baso-0.5 ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD Glucose-107* UreaN-20 Creat-1.0 Na-140 K-5.0 Cl-101 HCO3-30 AnGap-14 ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD ALT-36 AST-56* LD(LDH)-638* CK(CPK)-116 AlkPhos-66 TotBili-0.3 ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD CK-MB-5 proBNP-2953* ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.02* ___ 04: 55PM BLOOD CK-MB-5 cTropnT-0.05* ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD CK-MB-3 cTropnT-0.05* ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-4.7* Mg-2.0 ___ 10: 20AM BLOOD Albumin-3.9 ___ 11: 03AM BLOOD ___ Temp-36.4 O2 Flow-3 pO2-34* pCO2-62* pH-7.32* calTCO2-33* Base XS-2 Intubat-NOT INTUBA Comment-NASAL ___ ___ 02: 00PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.0 Leuks-NEG CXR FINDINGS: PA and lateral views of the chest were provided. Diffuse though lower lung predominant interstitial opacities are re-demonstrated compatible with patient's known interstitial lung disease. There is no superimposed consolidation, or effusion/pneumothorax. The heart and mediastinal contours appear stable. Bony structures are intact. IMPRESSION: No acute interval change in diffuse interstitial lung disease. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Fluoxetine 80 mg PO DAILY brand name only 2. ___ 40 mg PO DAILY 3. Quetiapine Fumarate 25 mg PO QPM: PRN Insomnia 4. Zonisamide 300 mg PO QPM 5. MetFORMIN XR (Glucophage XR) 1000 mg PO DAILY Do Not Crush 6. Torsemide 40 mg PO DAILY 7. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H Please do not exceed 3g in 24 hours. 8. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 9. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 10. Advair HFA *NF* (fluticasone-salmeterol) 230-21 mcg/actuation Inhalation BID Patient wishing to use her own home medication 11. Simvastatin 10 mg PO DAILY 12. Potassium Chloride 10 mEq PO DAILY Duration: 24 Hours <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H Please do not exceed 3g in 24 hours. 2. Advair HFA *NF* (fluticasone-salmeterol) 230-21 mcg/actuation Inhalation BID Patient wishing to use her own home medication 3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 4. Fluoxetine 80 mg PO DAILY brand name only 5. ___ Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 6. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY 7. Quetiapine Fumarate 25 mg PO QPM: PRN Insomnia 8. Simvastatin 10 mg PO DAILY 9. Torsemide 60 mg PO DAILY 10. Zonisamide 300 mg PO QPM 11. MetFORMIN XR (Glucophage XR) 1000 mg PO DAILY Do Not Crush 12. Potassium Chloride 10 mEq PO DAILY Duration: 24 Hours <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> acute on chronic diastolic heart failure pulmonary hypertension interstitial lung disease <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital because you woke up abruptly at night and there was some concern about your breathing. It may be that you had some fluid overload which was contributing to your breathing problems. It is important that you do not drink more than one and a half liter of fluid per day and avoid sugary drinks such as gatorade as well as avoid salty foods. You should take torsemide 60mg every day. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> lisinopril <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> ICD firing <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ M with PMH of sCHF (LVEF 20%) s/p PPM/ICD placement, afib on coumadin, HTN, CKD and HLN presenting after being shocked by ICD this morning. During the past month he complains of increased fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. Patient was able to swim 5 laps per day before, now can only swim ___ laps. He reports compliance with medication but not with diet. The patient presented today to the ED after his ICD fired at 8: 05 am. The patient reports feeling dizzy and close to fainting after lifting weight and standing up. Seconds later, he felt a discharge from ICD. He denies chest pain or SOB. Patient arrives to ED, reports symptoms have resolved. On PE there are no signs of acute sCHF decompensation. (lungs clear to auscultation, no edema). His ICD is interrogated, reporting on ___ at 8: 12am- atrial fibrillation with ventricular rate of 200bpm which terminated with 1 shock. In the ED intial vitals were 97.4 78 ___ 100% Labs were notable for: INR 2.7, BUN/Cr ___ (at baseline). Patient was given: No medications received in the ED Vitals on transfer: 97.6 121/82 84 16 100%. On the floor the patient's vitals were 98.1 151/91 80 100% RA. Of note, patient has had two previous hospitalizations this year; on ___ and ___, due to sCHF exacerbation secondary to afib. In both cases he required cardioversion. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: HTN, Hyperlipidemia 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: - ___ with EF 25% in ___ - A. Fib s/p prior cardioversion, on warfarin and amio - CABG: None - PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: None - PACING/ICD: dual-chamber ICD 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: CKD (baseline Cr 1.5) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of MIs <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAMINATION VS: 98.1 151/91 80 100% RA Admission weight: 119.0 kg GENERAL: WDWN. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: No elevation of JVP. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No murmurs/rubs/gallops. No thrills, lifts. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Some crackles on base of left hemithorax, clear breath sounds in right hemithorax. No wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominal bruits. EXTREMITIES: No edema. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: 2+ DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAMINATION GENERAL: WDWN. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: No elevation of JVP. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. Telemetry shows pacing near every beat. No murmurs/rubs/gallops. No thrills, lifts. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Clear breath sounds. No crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominal bruits. EXTREMITIES: No edema. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: 2+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LAB RESULTS ___ 12: 10PM GLUCOSE-116* UREA N-23* CREAT-1.8* SODIUM-138 POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-98 TOTAL CO2-33* ANION GAP-11 ___ 12: 10PM CALCIUM-9.0 PHOSPHATE-4.2 MAGNESIUM-2.1 ___ 12: 10PM WBC-6.2 RBC-4.97 HGB-13.4* HCT-41.7 MCV-84 MCH-26.9* MCHC-32.0 RDW-15.2 ___ 12: 10PM NEUTS-51.2 ___ MONOS-6.3 EOS-2.1 BASOS-0.6 ___ 12: 10PM PLT COUNT-198 ___ 12: 10PM ___ PTT-43.5* ___ ___ 02: 30PM UREA N-28* CREAT-1.8* SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-3.8 CHLORIDE-100 TOTAL CO2-32 ANION GAP-12 ___ 02: 30PM estGFR-Using this ___ 02: 30PM CALCIUM-9.1 PHOSPHATE-3.5 MAGNESIUM-2.3 ___ 02: 30PM ___ DISCHARGE LAB RESULTS ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD WBC-7.1 RBC-5.12 Hgb-13.7* Hct-43.2 MCV-85 MCH-26.8* MCHC-31.7 RDW-15.3 Plt ___ ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD ___ PTT-45.1* ___ ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD Glucose-106* UreaN-29* Creat-1.9* Na-139 K-3.8 Cl-96 HCO3-34* AnGap-13 IMAGING: CARDIAC CT ___: IMPRESSION: Normal pulmonary venous anatomy. No evidence for pulmonary vein stenosis. No left atrial or appendageal thrombus. An addendum with pulmonary vein measurements will be issued subsequently. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO DAILY 2. Potassium Chloride 20 mEq PO DAILY 3. Amiodarone 200 mg PO DAILY 4. Rosuvastatin Calcium 40 mg PO QPM 5. Torsemide 100 mg PO DAILY AM 6. Valsartan 80 mg PO BID 7. Warfarin 7.5 mg PO DAILY16 8. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 9. Torsemide 60 mg PO DAILY ___ <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Amiodarone 200 mg PO DAILY 2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 3. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO DAILY 4. Rosuvastatin Calcium 40 mg PO QPM 5. Valsartan 40 mg PO BID 6. Warfarin 4 mg PO DAILY16 RX *warfarin 4 mg one tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 7. Potassium Chloride 20 mEq PO BID Hold for K > 8. Outpatient Lab Work pls check chem7 including Mg, and INR on ___. pls fax results to Dr. ___ at ___. 9. Torsemide 40 mg PO QPM ___ 10. Torsemide 80 mg PO QAM AM 11. Spironolactone 12.5 mg PO DAILY RX *spironolactone 25 mg half tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary diagnosis Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation Acute on chronic systolic heart failure s/p PPM/ICD Secondary diagnosis Chronic kidney disease Hypertension Hyperlipidemia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It has been a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___. You were admitted because you had an episode of atrial fibrillation that triggered your ICD device. You also had a heart failure exacerbation and were treated with IV diuretics to decrease the fluid retention. You were then changed back to your regular oral diuretic dose. Your ICD showed that you are having recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation. We recommend pulmonary vein isolation, a surgical procedure that can prevent new episodes of atrial fibrillation. This will be done as an outpatient. We have changed the dose of your home warfarin from 7.5mg to 4mg. The rest of your medications have not been modified. Please remember to take you medication as instructed and have a diet low in salt. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs. Once again, it was a pleasure taking care of you. Sincerely, Your ___ team

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> Nafcillin Anhydrous / Heparin Agents / Naprosyn / Lipitor / Captopril <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Epigastric pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ - ercp <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mrs. ___ is an ___ year old female with past histroy of CHF (EF unknown), CKD (baseline unknown), type 2 diabetes and hypertension who presented to the ED this afternoon with epigastric pain x 7hours. She was in normal state of health night prior to admission, tolerating PO, but awoke at 7am with epigastric pain. She initially though tpain was related to gas, however it did not resolve. She tolerated toast and coffee for 30 minutes and then experienced non-bloody vomit. Only other associated symptoms were subjective fever and chills this morning. She denied any other symptoms such as chest pain, palpitaitons, shortness of breath, change in chronic dry cough, bloody emesis, melena, dysuria or confusion. She went to MD office had O2 sats 81%, called EMS to bring her to ED. En Route, EMS stated she had an O2 saturation of 84%. She continued to have nausea and abdominal pain until arriving to the ED. . In the ED, initial vs were: T 97.8 HR 66 BP 142/60 RR 22 O2 Sat: 98%. Patient was given tylenol as needed for pain. Lab work demonstrated WBC of 10.1 with 90.2% neutophils, elevated AST 158 and ALT 86 with T bili of 1.6. Lactate was 2.2. She underwent CT abdomen and pelvis that showed Dilated CBD with possible stone lodged at ampulla. She was evaluated by surgery who felt she may have cholangitis and was admitted for ERCP. During her ED course, her blood pressure started dropping and she recieved 3L IVF without improvement, central subclavian line was placed and she was started on levophed. She was transferred to the ICU for further management and ERCP. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CKD 2. h/o CHF 3. DM2 4. HTN 5. Lipids 6. psoriasis 7. GERD Past Surgical History: - s/p tissue MVR (endocarditis) - s/p tissue AVR <FAMILY HISTORY> Noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Upon presentation: 97.8 66 142/60 22 98 GEN: A&O, NAD HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist CV: RRR, No M/G/R PULM: Clear to auscultation b/l, No W/R/R ABD: Soft, nondistended, nontender, no rebound or guarding, normoactive bowel sounds, no palbable masses DRE: normal tone, no gross or occult blood Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 11: 00PM GLUCOSE-183* UREA N-29* CREAT-1.4* SODIUM-142 POTASSIUM-5.1 CHLORIDE-108 TOTAL CO2-26 ANION GAP-13 ___ 11: 00PM ALT(SGPT)-95* AST(SGOT)-146* ALK PHOS-76 TOT BILI-2.2* ___ 11: 00PM LIPASE-30 ___ 11: 00PM ALBUMIN-3.8 CALCIUM-8.3* PHOSPHATE-4.0 MAGNESIUM-1.8 ___ 11: 00PM WBC-14.5* RBC-3.21* HGB-9.8* HCT-29.8* MCV-93 MCH-30.4 MCHC-32.8 RDW-13.2 ___ 11: 00PM PLT COUNT-183 ___ 04: 40PM ___ PTT-24.5 ___ Images: CT A/P ___ - 1. Moderate dilation of the common bile duct with mild central intrahepatic biliary dilation with an apparent filling defect in the distal CBD at the level of the ampulla, likely a stone. Just proximal to this filling defect, the distal CBD appears to narrow, and there is mild biliary wall enhancement, likely due to inflammation. Recommend further evaluation with MRCP/ERCP. 2. Hypodense lesions within the right kidney are incompletely evaluated. If MRCP is done, these can be evaluated at that time, otherwise recommend ultrasound evaluation on a nonurgent basis. 3. Diverticulosis, with no evidence of diverticulitis. 4. Cholelithiasis. . EKG: NSR 90, NA/NI, poor r wave progression, no ST changes or TWI <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Multivitamin Cap Oral 1 Capsule(s) Once Daily Aspirin 81 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) Once Daily Flonase 50 mcg/Actuation Nasal Spray Nasal 2 Spray, Suspension(s) Once Daily Combivent 18 mcg-103 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Inhaler Inhalation 2 Aerosol(s) Four times daily Amaryl 4 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) Once Daily Benicar 40 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) Once Daily Calcium 600 + D(3) 1 Tablet(s) Twice Daily Fish Oil 1,000 mg Cap Oral 1 Capsule(s) Twice Daily Omeprazole 20 mg Cap, Delayed Release Oral 1 Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.)(s) Twice Daily Crestor 10 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) , at bedtime Sertraline 100 mg Tab Oral .5 Tablet(s) Once Daily Clobetasol 0.05 % Topical Soln Topical 1 Solution(s) Twice Daily, as needed to scalp Temovate 0.05 % Topical Cream Topical 1 Cream(s) Twice Daily, as needed psoriasis Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) Twice Daily Senna Herbal Laxative 12 mg Cap Oral 2 Capsule(s) Once Daily Lasix 20 mg Tab Oral 2 Tablet(s) Once Daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Furosemide 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain. 3. Olmesartan 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO daily (). 4. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 5. reduced_text: <|begin_of_text|><SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> Nafcillin Anhydrous / Heparin Agents / Naprosyn / Lipitor / Captopril <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Epigastric pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ - ercp <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mrs. ___ is an ___ year old female with past histroy of CHF (EF unknown), CKD (baseline unknown), type 2 diabetes and hypertension who presented to the ED this afternoon with epigastric pain x 7hours. She was in normal state of health night prior to admission, tolerating PO, but awoke at 7am with epigastric pain. She initially though tpain was related to gas, however it did not resolve. She tolerated toast and coffee for 30 minutes and then experienced non-bloody vomit. Only other associated symptoms were subjective fever and chills this morning. She denied any other symptoms such as chest pain, palpitaitons, shortness of breath, change in chronic dry cough, bloody emesis, melena, dysuria or confusion. She went to MD office had O2 sats 81%, called EMS to bring her to ED. En Route, EMS stated she had an O2 saturation of 84%. She continued to have nausea and abdominal pain until arriving to the ED.. In the ED, initial vs were: T 97.8 HR 66 BP 142/60 RR 22 O2 Sat: 98%. Patient was given tylenol as needed for pain. Lab work demonstrated WBC of 10.1 with 90.2% neutophils, elevated AST 158 and ALT 86 with T bili of 1.6. Lactate was 2.2. She underwent CT abdomen and pelvis that showed Dilated CBD with possible stone lodged at ampulla. She was evaluated by surgery who felt she may have cholangitis and was admitted for ERCP. During her ED course, her blood pressure started dropping and she recieved 3L IVF without improvement, central subclavian line was placed and she was started on levophed. She was transferred to the ICU for further management and ERCP.. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CKD 2. h/o CHF 3. DM2 4. HTN 5. Lipids 6. psoriasis 7. GERD Past Surgical History: - s/p tissue MVR (endocarditis) - s/p tissue AVR <FAMILY HISTORY> Noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Upon presentation: 97.8 66 142/60 22 98 GEN: A&O, NAD HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist CV: RRR, No M/G/R PULM: Clear to auscultation b/l, No W/R/R ABD: Soft, nondistended, nontender, no rebound or guarding, normoactive bowel sounds, no palbable masses DRE: normal tone, no gross or occult blood Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 11: 00PM GLUCOSE-183* UREA N-29* CREAT-1.4* SODIUM-142 POTASSIUM-5.1 CHLORIDE-108 TOTAL CO2-26 ANION GAP-13 ___ 11: 00PM ALT(SGPT)-95* AST(SGOT)-146* ALK PHOS-76 TOT BILI-2.2* ___ 11: 00PM LIPASE-30 ___ 11: 00PM ALBUMIN-3.8 CALCIUM-8.3* PHOSPHATE-4.0 MAGNESIUM-1.8 ___ 11: 00PM WBC-14.5* RBC-3.21* HGB-9.8* HCT-29.8* MCV-93 MCH-30.4 MCHC-32.8 RDW-13.2 ___ 11: 00PM PLT COUNT-183 ___ 04: 40PM ___ PTT-24.5 ___ Images: CT A/P ___ - 1. Moderate dilation of the common bile duct with mild central intrahepatic biliary dilation with an apparent filling defect in the distal CBD at the level of the ampulla, likely a stone. Just proximal to this filling defect, the distal CBD appears to narrow, and there is mild biliary wall enhancement, likely due to inflammation. Recommend further evaluation with MRCP/ERCP. 2. Hypodense lesions within the right kidney are incompletely evaluated. If MRCP is done, these can be evaluated at that time, otherwise recommend ultrasound evaluation on a nonurgent basis. 3. Diverticulosis, with no evidence of diverticulitis. 4. Cholelithiasis.. EKG: NSR 90, NA/NI, poor r wave progression, no ST changes or TWI <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Multivitamin Cap Oral 1 Capsule(s) Once Daily Aspirin 81 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) Once Daily Flonase 50 mcg/Actuation Nasal Spray Nasal 2 Spray, Suspension(s) Once Daily Combivent 18 mcg-103 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Inhaler Inhalation 2 Aerosol(s) Four times daily Amaryl 4 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) Once Daily Benicar 40 mg Tab Oral 1 Tablet(s) Once Daily Calcium 600 + D(3) 1 Tablet(s) Twice Daily Fish Oil 1,000 mg Cap Oral 1 Capsule(s) Twice Daily O

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Percocet / Amiodarone / Lisinopril <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> pain in her wrists, left hand, hips and face <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old female with PMH prior CVAs ___ no residual deficits), cerebral aneurysm, afib on coumadin, s/p pacemaker, CHF, HTN, HLD, gait instability uses walker, hx of renal cell cancer s/p cryoablation therapy who presented s/p mechanical fall ___. She was caring for her puppy who moved its bowels on the ground. Patient became unhappy and on her way to get her dog outside to complete its bowel movement, she tripped on the rug, fell forward, and hit her face. No LOC. She complains of pain in her wrists, left hand, hips and face. She denies headaches. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> CVA x 2 (___) Cerebral aneurysms, followed by Dr. ___ (Neurology) CHF Tachy/brady syndrome s/p ___ ___, on coumadin RCC ___ Compression fx Paravertebral muscle hematoma ___ (complication of vertebroplasty) OA Depression/anxiety History of UTI Constipation Scoliosis Cervical spondylosis with cord compression ___. Osteoporosis HLD HTN PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: 1. Thumb surgery. 2. Left eye cataract surgery. 3. Status post face lift. 4. Hysterectomy. 5. Tonsillectomy. 6. Rotator cuff surgery in ___. 7. Status post kyphoplasty ___ for treatment of compression fx 8. Left TKR <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father died of a ?stroke. Mother had a myocardial infarction and vaginal cancer. Aunt with unspecified cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 97.6 70 156/78 16 98% RA GEN: A&Ox3, NAD HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist, +ecchymosis and abrasions around nares and lips, no notable loose dentition, mild tenderness to palpation along maxilla b/l. +cervical neck tenderness CV: irreg PULM: diminished vesicular breath sounds, no chest tenderness, no work of breathing ABD: Soft, nondistended, nontender, no rebound or guarding, normoactive bowel sounds, no palpable masses Pelvis: No pelvic pain Ext: RUE: pain with AROM of wrist, LUE: ___ digit tenderness R and L ___: mild discomfort Discharge <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 97.5, 90, 148/86, 18, 100%ra HEENT: Ecchymosis around nose & mouth. Lip laceration. PERRLA. C-Collar on. CV: HR irregular / AF Resp: decreased LS bilaterally, no wheeze, rhonchi, rales. NARD. Abd: soft, NT/ND Ext: Multiple ecchymosis over bilateral extremities. Left hand edema with bruising, left ___ digit phalanx fx, s/p splinting NEURO: alert and oriented x 3, speech clear <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 11: 45AM BLOOD ___ ___ 04: 25AM BLOOD WBC-5.8 RBC-3.28* Hgb-9.3* Hct-29.9* MCV-91 MCH-28.4 MCHC-31.1* RDW-16.1* RDWSD-53.8* Plt ___ ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD WBC-7.0 RBC-3.78* Hgb-10.7* Hct-33.8* MCV-89 MCH-28.3 MCHC-31.7* RDW-15.7* RDWSD-50.8* Plt ___ ___ 04: 25AM BLOOD Glucose-85 UreaN-30* Creat-1.0 Na-135 K-4.3 Cl-100 HCO3-27 AnGap-12 ___ 04: 25AM BLOOD Calcium-8.6 Phos-3.6 Mg-2.1 ___ 04: 25AM BLOOD ___ PTT-42.6* ___ ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD ___ Imaging: OSH CXR - No acute fractures Pelvis XR - No acute process or fxs L hand - ___ digit phalanx fracture R hand - no fractures CT Head - negative for acute intracranial process CTA neck - no vertebral or other vascular injuries CT cspine - mildly displaced fracture through R transverse process ___ CT Max/Mandible/Sinus: 1. Nondisplaced right nasal bone fracture. 2. Partially visualized is a fracture of the right transverse process of C1, better imaged on CT C-spine from outside hospital. 3. Sinus disease, described above. ___ Right hand: No acute fracture is identified. Severe degenerative changes are noted, most severely involving the DIP and PIP joints. Deformity of distal radius is likely due to old fracture. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> - citalopram 20 mg tablet. 1 (One) Tablet(s) by mouth daily - clindamycin 300 mg capsule. 2 capsule(s) by mouth as needed for Prior to procedure - Digitek 125 mcg tablet. tablet(s) by mouth - furosemide 40 mg tablet. tablet(s) by mouth once a day Take additional 40 mg in afternoon - labetalol 300 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day - simvastatin 5 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day - spironolactone 25 mg tablet. 1 Tablet(s) by mouth DAILY - warfarin 2.5 mg tablet. 1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day Medications - OTC - acetaminophen 500 mg tablet. 2 (Two) Tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime as needed for pain - Calcium with Vitamin D 600 mg (1,500 mg)-400 unit tablet. 1 (One) Tablet(s) by mouth twice a day - Zyrtec 10 mg capsule. 1 (One) Capsule(s) by mouth once a day - cyanocobalamin (vit B-12) 500 mcg tablet. 1 (One) Tablet(s) by mouth once a day - Natural Tears (PF) 0.1 %-0.3 % drops in a dropperette. 1 (One) qtt topically both eyes in the AM - lutein 20 mg capsule. 1 (One) Capsule(s) by mouth once a day - melatonin 1 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth QPM - multivitamin tablet. 1 (One) Tablet(s) by mouth once a day - Miralax 17 gram oral powder packet. 1 pkt(s) by mouth daily as needed for constipation <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q8H: PRN pain 2. Acetaminophen-Caff-Butalbital ___ TAB PO Q8H: PRN headache 3. Artificial Tears Preserv. Free ___ DROP BOTH EYES PRN dry eyes 4. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO QID 5. Cetirizine 10 mg PO DAILY 6. Citalopram 20 mg PO QHS 7. Digoxin 0.125 mg PO DAILY 8. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 9. Furosemide 40 mg PO BID 10. Labetalol 300 mg PO BID 11. Lidocaine 5% Patch 1 PTCH TD QAM 12. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 13. Omeprazole 20 mg PO QHS 14. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY: PRN constipation 15. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID: PRN Constipation 16. Simvastatin 5 mg PO QPM 17. Spironolactone 25 mg PO DAILY 18. Warfarin 2.5 mg PO ___ Your INR has been elevated. Please test INR daily and dose warfarin accordingly 19. Warfarin 2.5 mg PO ONCE Duration: 1 Dose <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ ___ Diagnosis: -Mildly displaced fracture through R transverse process C1 -Left hand ___ digit phalanx fracture -Nondisplaced right nasal bone fracture <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ after a fall. You fractured a piece of your ___ cervical spine vertebrae, your left ___ finger, and your nose. You were seen by Neurosurgery, who recommended the hard cervical collar for ___ weeks and outpatient follow-up. The Hand Surgeons saw you for the finger fracture, and splinted it. They would also like to see you in their clinic in 1 week. Physical Therapy and Occupational Therapy worked with you, and recommended you be discharged to rehab to regain your strength. You are now medically cleared for discharge, please note the following discharge instructions: Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the Emergency Department for any of the following: *You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. *New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze. *If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your medications. *You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. *You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a bowel movement. *You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your urine, or experience a discharge. *Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or back. *You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius. *Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you. Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take any new medications as prescribed. Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.

Unfortunately, patient was not able to receive neupogen d/t insurance issues. He is been admitted for further workup of leukopenia and neupogen administration. Of note, he endorsed baseline arthralgias, secondary to severe arthritis. In addition, he had myalgias with perhaps rhinorrhea. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - EtOH and HCV cirrhosis, diuretic refractory ascites currenlty getting paracenteses every 2 weeks, currently being evaluated for liver transplantation - Umbillical hernia - Chronic abdominal pain - Hypertension - GERD - Elevated creatinine - RBBB - Right inguinal hernia - Microscopic hematuria, OSH cystoscopy unremarkable - S/p TACE on ___, RFA on ___, laminectomy in ___ (reoperated for infection) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - Brother died age ___ of HCC, alcohol abuse, - Brother died age ___ of MI <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: General: T 97.6 BP 160/88 HR 85 R 20 SpO2 99%/RA 218 lbs HEENT: sclerae anicteric, PERRL Neck: supple, no JVD Heart: regular, normal S1 & S2 without murmurs appreciated Lungs: clear to auscultation bilaterally Abdomen: well-healing RUQ scar from liver transplant, large abdomen, soft, non-tender, not tympanitic, normal bowel sounds Extremities: warm, well-perfused Skin: diffuse macular rash on all 4 extremities and chest without papules, petechiae or purpura Neurological: face symmetric, moving all extremities well, oriented x4 Discharge <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 97.9 ___ 18 100%/RA Weight: 98.9 kg <- 218 lbs General: Pleasant, resting comfortably, NAD HEENT: sclerae anicteric, NCAT Neck: supple Heart: regular, normal S1 & S2 without murmurs appreciated Lungs: clear to auscultation bilaterally Abdomen: well-healing RUQ scar from liver transplant, large abdomen, soft, non-tender Extremities: warm, well-perfused, no edema. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> contrast dye <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> shortness of breath, dysarthria, dysphagia <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Intubation, Plasmapheresis x5 sessions <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The pt is a ___ gentleman with history of oculobulbar myasthenia ___, on prednisone and recently added on azathioprine, who presents with one day of worsening shortness of breath ___ setting of one month of progressively worsening dysarthria, dysphagia, ptosis, and diplopia. The patient is ___ speaking and is accompanied by his son who provides interpretation. The patient was diagnosed with myasthenia ___ after onset of ocular and bulbar weakness ___ ___ during a trip to ___, and ACh receptor antibodies were positive. He was initially started on prednisone and mestinon, which was stopped a year ago. Patient reports that he had been well controlled on oral prednisone alone for the past year and had been slowly weaned down to 7.5mg daily with plan to stop it by his primary neurologist. However ___ early ___, he had recurrence of his symptoms, namely left greater than right ptosis, intermittent diplopia, and mild difficulty swallowing and speaking, with slurring of his words. He was seen by his neurologist numerous times and ___ the ED once which resulted ___ incremental increase ___ prednisone to 30mg daily (currently) and resumption of mestinon ___ late ___. His symptoms initially improved with each increase, but overall continued to worsen. On ___ he was started on azathioprine (as mycophenolate was rejected by insurance company). Over the past 3 weeks, his symptoms have progressively worsened to the point that he cannot tolerate solid foods and has been limiting himself to soup and water. His ptosis and double vision have become more constant. He is also easily fatigued and has stopped working and ambulating as much. He describes it being harder to get up and walk, which he attributes to a combination of generalized weakness and dyspnea on exertion. His voice is becoming softer and more slurred, per his son, but he has no difficulty comprehending or producing language. His breathing has also been more difficult, and he cannot breathe when laying flat, which has led to insomnia. Over the past 24 hours, he felt that his breathing has become more labored and became very worried, therefore he presented to ___, where he was placed on supplemental oxygen for mild desaturation to ___ and was transferred here for further care. ROS is otherwise significant for intermittent nonbloody diarrhea for the past month attributed to the mestinon which improved with loperamide given by his PCP. He also endorses increased oral secretions, but no cough or sputum, and no fevers, chills, night sweats. He endorses mild frontal headache and visual symptoms as described above. Denies focal weakness apart from what is described above, dizziness, lightheadedness, vertigo, bowel or bladder incontinence. He describes only tongue numbness, but no other sensory loss or paresthesias. Denies chest pain, nausea, vomiting, dysuria, urinary frequency. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Oculobulbar myasthenia ___, +AChR Abs Diabetes mellitus Hypertension Hyperlipidemia BPH <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> HTN, HLD. No family history of neurologic conditions. <PHYSICAL EXAM> - Admission Exam: - Vitals: T 96.7, HR 98, BP 145/78, RR 20, spO2 92% on 4L O2 General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. Appears somewhat tired but breathing comfortably without accessory muscle use. Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP pulses bilaterally. Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. Neurologic: -Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attentive. Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension. Normal prosody. There were no paraphasic errors. Pt was able to name both high and low frequency objects. Able to read without difficulty. Speech is hypophonic and dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: II, III, IV, VI: PERRL 4 to 3mm and brisk. There is ptosis bilaterally, left greater than right. Gaze is dysconjugate, with exodeviation of left pupil. Extraocular movements were full vertically, however he is unable to completely bury his sclera on right adduction, and he has impaired abduction and adduction of the left. He has diplopia ___ all directions of gaze except convergence, with the outer (phantom) image extinguishing on covering the left pupil. Few beats of endlateral gaze nystagmus. VFF to confrontation. Visual acuity ___ OD, ___ OS. Fundoscopic exam revealed no papilledema, exudates, or hemorrhages. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch. VII: Weakness of forehead wrinkling, eye closure, smile, and mouth closure bilaterally. VIII: Hearing intact grossly. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength ___ trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes to the right. -Motor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. No pronator drift bilaterally. Mild action tremor bilaterally. No asterixis noted. No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally. -Gait: Deferred. -=== Discharge Exam: -=== VS Tmax 98.5F, BP 123-136/69-84, HR 77-87, RR 18, 93-96% on RA General - NAD Pulm - No respiratory distress Mental Status - Alert and oriented x3 Cranial nerves - ___ 4 to 2mm briskly, Able to sustain upgaze for greater than 15 seconds without diplopia. You required a short term intubation while you were admitted. You received several sessions of plasmapheresis which helped your symptoms. Your medications were also adjusted ___ order to better control your myasthemia. These changes were made by neuromuscular specialists who were consulted to help with your care. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Weakness Ulcerative Colitis <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Flexible Sigmoidoscopy Laparoscopic Proctocolectomy with End Ileostomy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ w/ ___ medical problems and UC now admitted for symptoms related to ulcerative colitis. She was diagnosed w/ ulcerative colitis approximately 6 months ago when she underwent her first colonoscopy. Since that time, she has been admitted to hospitals three times for symptoms related to her ulcerative three times. All times the steroids improved her symptoms but they are becoming less effective. In the past she was concerned about taking biologics, specifically vedolizumab, due to side effects. On her last admission for diarrhea, she was given abx and discharged w/ plan to take remicaide. However, quant gold was indeterminate with apical scarring on CXR so started on INH and plan for remicaide on hold. At worst, she has 7 bloody BMs/day, fatigue, weakness, abdominal pain, nausea. Currently only ___ BM/day. Does sometimes have incontinence and wears diaper at home. She was readmitted with weakness and abdominal cramping. At home, fell and hit head, transferred to ___. Surgery is consulted to discuss options with her. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> UC, afib, CVA ___ years ago (c/o some L sided 'numbness' but no deficiency in strength or true deficit), HLD, glaucoma PSHx: lap chole <ALLERGIES> NKDA <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> nephew with ___, son died of ___ cancer at age ___, father w/ prostate cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: Vitals: 98.8 130/91 87 20 100% on RA General: no acute distress HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM CV: irregular, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi Abdomen: soft, +BS, diffusely tender to palpation, no rebound or guarding GU: No foley Ext: ___ edema bilaterally Neuro: CNII-XII intact, ___ strength upper/lower extremities, grossly normal sensation DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: ___ 97 18 100%RA GENERAL: Alert, oriented, appears tired but in no acute distress RESP: CTAB CV: Irregular, no r/g/m ABD: Soft, NT ND, lap sites appear c/d/i. ostomy site appeard intact. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: ___ 06: 20PM BLOOD WBC-11.1* RBC-3.35* Hgb-9.4* Hct-31.2* MCV-93 MCH-28.1 MCHC-30.1*# RDW-16.0* RDWSD-53.8* Plt ___ ___ 06: 20PM BLOOD Neuts-69.9 Lymphs-18.5* Monos-10.0 Eos-0.8* Baso-0.5 Im ___ AbsNeut-7.79* AbsLymp-2.06 AbsMono-1.11* AbsEos-0.09 AbsBaso-0.06 ___ 06: 20PM BLOOD Glucose-89 UreaN-13 Creat-0.7 Na-142 K-3.0* Cl-104 HCO3-26 AnGap-15 ___ 10: 20PM BLOOD ALT-17 AST-13 LD(LDH)-212 AlkPhos-63 TotBili-0.5 ___ 10: 20PM BLOOD Albumin-3.0* Iron-53 ___ 10: 20PM BLOOD calTIBC-311 Ferritn-18 TRF-239 PROCEDURE REPORT: ___ FLEXIBLE SIGMOIDOSCOPY: *Findings: Mucosa: Diffuse ulceration and erythema with no bleeding were noted in the rectum. These findings are compatible with ulcerative colitis. Cold forceps biopsies were performed for histology. *Impression: Ulceration and erythema in the rectum compatible with ulcerative colitis (biopsy). Otherwise normal sigmoidoscopy to sigmoid colon. PATHOLOGY: ___ COLONIC BIOPSY: Chronic moderately active colitis; no granulomas or dysplasia are seen. IMAGING: ___ CT A/P IMPRESSION: 1. Circumferential wall thickening and adjacent fat stranding extends from the rectum through the sigmoid and descending colon, with multiple reactive adjacent lymph nodes. Transition to normal colon appears to occur at the splenic flexure. Findings are consistent with the provided history of ulcerative colitis flare. No drainable fluid collection or free intraperitoneal air identified. 2. Vague hypodensities in the left kidney are less conspicuous than the study from ___, but likely reflect chronic scarring and prior renal infarcts. ___ CXR Mild cardiomegaly is a stable. A small bilateral effusions have increased from prior study. There is no pneumothorax. Biapical pleural-parenchymal scarring is noted. The lungs are hyperinflated. There is kyphosis. Rivaroxaban 15 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Amlodipine 5 mg PO DAILY 2. Latanoprost 0.005% Ophth. Soln. 1 DROP BOTH EYES QHS 3. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO BID 4. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN pain RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*90 Tablet Refills: *0 6. Rivaroxaban 15 mg PO DAILY 7. Megestrol Acetate 400 mg PO QDAY appetite stimulant RX *megestrol [Megace] 400 mg/10 mL (40 mg/mL) 10 mL by mouth Daily Refills: *1 8. Isoniazid ___ mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Ulcerative Colitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital after a Laparoscopic Proctocolectomy With End Ileostomy for surgical management of your Ulcerative Colitis. You have recovered from this procedure well and you are now ready to return home. Samples from your colon were taken and this tissue has been sent to the pathology department for analysis. You will receive these pathology results at your follow-up appointment. If there is an urgent need for the surgeon to contact you regarding these results they will contact you before this time. You have tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return home to finish your recovery. Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain medications there is a risk that you will have some constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the office. If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation. You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen which are closed with internal sutures and a skin glue called Dermabond. These are healing well however it is important that you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection including: increasing redness of the incision lines, white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or swelling of the area. Please call the office if you develop any of these symptoms or a fever. You may go to the emergency room if your symptoms are severe. You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with steri-strips (little white adhesive strips) instead of Dermabond, these will fall off over time, please do not remove them. Please no baths or swimming for 6 weeks after surgery unless told otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. ___. You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain medication oxycodone. Please take this medication exactly as prescribed. You may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive a car while taking narcotic pain medication. No heavy lifting greater than 6 lbs for until your first post-operative visit after surgery. Please no strenuous activity until this time unless instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. ___. Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual activities. Good luck!

Transported to ___ for further care. He was noted to be briefly hypotensive to ___ in ED. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Cervical spondylosis w/ mild myelopathy Peripheral neuropathy Hearing loss Prostate CA s/p "surgery" Depression Cirrhosis (by radiographic appearance of liver on CT) Cognition: no history of memory loss per son-in-law L cataract excision <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Noncontributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 97 112/62 64 16 93%/2L Height: 69 in. ___ Weight: 87 kgs. (191.80 lbs) ___ BMI: 28.3 GEN: Overweight older sleeping in bed; opens eyes briefly to name/sternal rub, then falls asleep HEENT: Anicteric sclerae, OP clear without E/E NECK: No LAD/TM, JVP 6 CV: RRR, S1/S2, no m/r/g appreciated RESP: Poorly assessed due to patient positioning; CTAB anteriorly ABD: +BS, S, NT/ND GU: Foley in place EXT: 2+ DPs, no ___ edema SKIN: Extensive confluent ecchymosis of R posterior thigh extending to mid back and to popliteal fossa and into groin; smaller ecchymoses of L posterior shoulder, posterior to R ear <PERTINENT RESULTS> Upon admission ___ 10: 30PM GLUCOSE-203* UREA N-20 CREAT-1.1 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.6 CHLORIDE-103 TOTAL CO2-28 ANION GAP-14 ___ 10: 30PM CK(CPK)-515* ___ 10: 30PM CK-MB-11* MB INDX-2.1 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 10: 30PM WBC-17.3* RBC-3.71* HGB-11.9* HCT-35.2* MCV-95 MCH-32.1* MCHC-33.9 RDW-14.1 ___ 10: 30PM PLT COUNT-187 ___ 10: 30PM ___ PTT-28.1 ___ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ________________________________________________________________ WBC RBC Hgb Hct MCV MCH MCHC RDW Plt Ct ___ 06: 20AM 9.2 2.58* 8.5* 25.5* 99* 32.9* 33.2 15.7* 221 ___ 02: 09AM 11.2* 2.75* 8.9* 26.9* 98 32.4* 33.1 15.6* 184 Source: Line-R forearm #20 angio ___ 05: 59PM 28.3* ___ 02: 05PM 27.4* ___ 01: 29AM 12.6* 2.80* 8.9* 26.3* 94 31.7 33.7 16.3* 158 Source: Line-a-line ___ 09: 46PM 25.5* Source: Line-arterial ___ 03: 03PM 25.8* Source: Line-arterial ___ 01: 16AM 13.9* 2.88* 9.3* 27.0* 94 32.5* 34.6 15.9* 147* Source: Line-___ ___ 08: 44PM 24.8* Source: Line-___ ___ 04: 56PM 25.1* Source: Line-arterial ___ 01: 05PM 27.1* _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ________________________________________________________________ Head CT ___ IMPRESSION: No intracranial hemorrhage. Large subgaleal hematoma along the vertex. CT c-spine ___ IMPRESSION: 1. T1 spinous process fracture. 2. Possible Paget's disease involving C2-C3. 3. Emphysema with 4-mm left apical nodule - F/u in 12 months. CT Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis ___ IMPRESSION: 1. Right buttock hematoma with evidence of active extravasation. Findings were discussed with Dr. ___ at the time of initial review. 2. Right and left adrenal nodules, incompletely characterized. Recommend dedicated MRI to further evaluate. 3. Extensive atherosclerosis with notable coronary artery disease. 4. Diffuse emphysema. 5. Right eighth lateral rib fracture, T1 spinous process fracture. 6. Left renal cyst. 7. Shrunken liver, ? cirrhosis. _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ________________________________________________________________ ___ ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY REPORT ___ ___ MRN: ___ Portable TTE (Complete) Done ___ at 1: 33: 32 ___ FINAL Echocardiographic Measurements Results Measurements Normal Range Left Atrium - Long Axis Dimension: 3.7 cm <= 4.0 cm Left Atrium - Four Chamber Length: 4.9 cm <= 5.2 cm Left Atrium - Peak Pulm Vein S: 0.5 m/s Left Atrium - Peak Pulm Vein D: 0.2 m/s Left Atrium - Peak Pulm Vein A: 0.3 m/s < 0.4 m/s Right Atrium - Four Chamber Length: 4.8 cm <= 5.0 cm Left Ventricle - Ejection Fraction: >= 65% >= 55% Left Ventricle - Peak Inducible LVOT gradient: 26 mm Hg Aorta - Sinus Level: *4.5 cm <= 3.6 cm Aortic Valve - Peak Velocity: 1.3 m/sec <= 2.0 m/sec Aortic Valve - LVOT diam: 2.3 cm Mitral Valve - E Wave: 0.6 m/sec Mitral Valve - A Wave: 0.7 m/sec Mitral Valve - E/A ratio: 0.86 Mitral Valve - E Wave deceleration time: 163 ms 140-250 ms TR Gradient (+ RA = PASP): *28 mm Hg <= 25 mm Hg Findings LEFT ATRIUM: Normal LA size. RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. Normal IVC diameter (<2.1cm) with >55% decrease during respiration (estimated RA pressure (___). LEFT VENTRICLE: Suboptimal technical quality, a focal LV wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall normal LVEF (>55%). No resting LVOT gradient. LVOT gradient increases with Valsalva. RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion. AORTA: Moderately dilated aortic sinus. AORTIC VALVE: Aortic valve not well seen. No AS. Trace AR. MITRAL VALVE: Mitral valve leaflets not well seen. TRICUSPID VALVE: Borderline PA systolic hypertension. PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Pulmonic valve not well seen. PERICARDIUM: There is an anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad, though a loculated anterior pericardial effusion cannot be excluded. GENERAL COMMENTS: Suboptimal image quality - poor echo windows. Suboptimal image quality - poor parasternal views. Suboptimal image quality as the patient was difficult to position. Conclusions The left atrium is normal in size. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). There was no resting left ventricular outflow gradient, but the gradient increased to mild with the Valsalva manuever. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is moderately dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve is not well seen. There is no aortic valve stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are not well seen. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad. IMPRESSION: Normal overall biventricular function. Left ventricle is unusually small and underfilled. Moderately dilated aortic sinus. _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ________________________________________________________________ Chest xray s/p PICC line placment ___ Placement of PICC line via the right brachial vein access with the tip of the catheter in SVC, and the catheter is ready to use. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Gapapentin 600"', ASA 81', fluoxetine 20', tramadol 50"PRN, MVI, urinary med? qHS (not flomax) <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Heparin (Porcine) 5,000 unit/mL Solution Sig: 5,000 Units Injection TID (3 times a day). 2. Tylenol ___ mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every six (6) hours: Give around the clock. 3. Albuterol Sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) Solution for Nebulization Sig: One (1) Neb Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for shortness of breath or wheezing. 4. Ipratropium Bromide 0.02 % Solution Sig: One (1) Neb Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for shortness of breath or wheezing. 5. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 times a day): hold fro SBP <110; HR <60. 6. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablet PO every ___ hours as needed for pain. 7. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day. 8. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO twice a day as needed for constipation. 9. Milk of Magnesia 800 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) ML's PO twice a day as needed for constipation. 10. Vancomycin in Dextrose 1 gram/200 mL Piggyback Sig: One (1) GM Intravenous Q 12H (Every 12 Hours) for 2 weeks. 11. Ceftriaxone in Dextrose,Iso-os 1 gram/50 mL Piggyback Sig: One (1) GM Intravenous Q24H (every 24 hours) for 2 weeks. 12. Insulin Regular Human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1) Dose Injection four times a day as needed for per sliding scale. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> s/p Fall Parietal/occipital subgaleal hematoma Right posterior 7th rib fracture Pneumonia T1 transverse process fracture Right buttock hematoma Acute blood loss anemia Oliguira <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Hemodynamically stable, tolerating a regular diet, pain adequately controlled <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Wear the soft cervical collar for comfort; velcro may be placed in front.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Left leg weakness, disequilibrium, blurry vision, worsened dysphagia, <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> - PEG placement (___) - PEG tube replacement with larger tube (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old man with a history of strokes (x3, last in ___), aortic stenosis s/p TAVR, CAD s/p stents x4, defibrillator, PAD/PVD. His residual deficits from his prior strokes include right leg weakness and dysphagia. He was however ambulatory and ate a regular diet, always taking great care to avoid aspiration. He presented to ___ on ___ with new left leg weakness, disequilibrium, blurry vision, slightly worsened dysphagia, and "feeling lousy". He had been started on Lopressor 12.5mg BID 4 days prior. He did not have lightheadedness or vertigo, but very specifically states he had difficulty coordinating his legs on the ground. He was admitted and slowly improved over the subsequent ___ days. ESR was elevated at 130 and he was given a dose of Solumedrol for potential temporal arteritis. On ___, after lunch he acutely felt worse with increased left leg weakness, blurry vision, and left basilar headache. Code stroke was called. Exam noted right pupil dilation (though unclear if new) and ___ right-sided strength (-- though the patient insists that it was the left side that was worse on ___, not the right). Imaging found subacute stroke in the L lateral medulla. tPA was deferred, a heparin drip was started, and he was transferred to ___. Imaging had also found innumerable small hemorrhages likely due to amyloid angiopathy, but this was not known until after transfer. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - History of Hemorrhagic Cerebrovascular Accident in ___ followed by embolic CVA in ___. Also had TIA in ___. Patient has residual speech and swallowing difficulties along with abnormal gait and right sided numbness - Esophageal Reflux Disease, Dysphagia - Hyperlipidemia - Hypertension - Osteoporosis - Psoriasis - Hearing Loss in left ear(since childhood) - Prior trach and PEG since removed (___) - Aortic stenosis s/p TAVR compatible with 1.5T and 3T - Congestive Heart Failure(chronic, diastolic). NYHA Class III - Peripheral Arterial Disease (bilateral, with claudication) - CAD s/p 4 DES (___) on ASA/Plavix. Also s/p PCI LMCA and LAD ___. atherectomy was utilized to debulk the heavily calcified left anterior descending coronary artery lesion - Bone marrow cancer in childhood (eosinophilic granuloma) equired head and chest radiation along with multiple surgeries including rib removal. - s/p Atherectomy left SFA and Popliteal - s/p Trach and PEG in ___ - s/p Multiple tumor removal from head and chest along with left rib removal as a child <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> -= ADMISSION EXAM -= General: NAD HEENT: NCAT, no oropharyngeal lesions, neck supple. Exophthalmos. ___: RRR, systolic murmur. Pulmonary: CTAB, no crackles or wheezes Abdomen: Soft, NT, +BS, no guarding. Extremities: Warm, no edema Neurologic Examination: - Mental status: Awake, alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attention and calculation intact, able to subtract sevens to 51. Speech is fluent with full sentences, intact repetition, and intact verbal comprehension. Naming intact. No paraphasias. Moderate dysarthria. Normal prosody. Able to register 3 objects and recall ___ at 5 minutes only with cuing. No apraxia. No evidence of hemineglect. No left-right confusion. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. - Cranial Nerves: Anisocoria R 6->3mm / L 4->3mm. VF full to finger wagging. EOMI, no nystagmus. V1-V3 without deficits to light touch bilaterally. No facial movement asymmetry. Hearing diminished to finger rub on left (known hearing problem) . Palate elevation symmetric.
