No FNF deficit as of ___. - Sensation: UEs + ___ to light touch - Gait: Deferred. <PERTINENT RESULTS> - SELECTED LABS - ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD WBC-9.5 RBC-4.17* Hgb-11.3* Hct-35.8* MCV-86 MCH-27.1 MCHC-31.6* RDW-14.0 RDWSD-43.8 Plt ___ ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD Neuts-65.9 ___ Monos-6.6 Eos-2.2 Baso-0.8 Im ___ AbsNeut-6.28* AbsLymp-2.30 AbsMono-0.63 AbsEos-0.21 AbsBaso-0.08 ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD ___ PTT-150* ___ ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD Glucose-123* UreaN-18 Creat-0.8 Na-141 K-4.1 Cl-102 HCO3-27 AnGap-16 ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD ALT-7 AST-14 LD(LDH)-210 AlkPhos-74 TotBili-0.3 ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD TotProt-6.2* Albumin-3.6 Globuln-2.6 Calcium-9.2 Phos-3.0 Mg-2.0 ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.6 eAG-114 ___ 01: 09AM BLOOD CRP-34* ___ 07: 17AM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-4.03* Hgb-11.3* Hct-34.8* MCV-86 MCH-28.0 MCHC-32.5 RDW-13.8 RDWSD-42.8 Plt ___ ___ 07: 17AM BLOOD ___ PTT-37.4* ___ ___ 07: 17AM BLOOD Glucose-156* UreaN-14 Creat-0.8 Na-139 K-3.9 Cl-98 HCO3-29 AnGap-16 ___ 07: 17AM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-3.2 Mg-1.9 Lipids: ___ 126, LDL 140, HDL 59. -= DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES -= - CXR (___) In comparison with the study of ___, the lungs are clear with no evidence of vascular congestion or pleural effusion. The Dobhoff tube has been removed. - Video Swallow (___) Video swallow revealed moderate oral and moderate to severe pharyngeal dysphagia characterized by oral delay, delayed swallow response and significant pharyngeal weakness on L>R and majority of the contrast within the pharyngeal structures. This resulted in silent frank aspiration of nectar thick liquids. Cued cough was not effective in eliminating aspirated material. Further consistencies not tested for safety. At the moment, recommend to continue strict NPO with all nutrition, hydration and medication via non oral means. Prognosis for return to POs in the next week is guarded given history of baseline dysphagia and acute left posterolateral medullary infarct. Would encourage discussion between the medical team and pt/HCP re: long term alternative means of nutrition and hydration. Q4 oral care. Continued SLP intervention focusing on pharyngeal strengthening exercises. We will continue to follow. Please page if questions. - MRI/MRA ___ OSH): Images uploaded to OMR Dr. ___ review: "Acute left posterolateral medullary infarct. Also notable multiple (>10) cortical microbleeds. Repeat MRI ___, no new acute infarct. CTA reveals marked diffuse calcified atherosclerosis. Both vertebral arteries are heavily calcified, and the left either terminates slightly distally to the origin of the ___ or it is occluded at that level. Heavily calcified plaque can be seen in the origin of the left ___ - TTE ___ OSH): LVEF 45-50%, diastolic dysfunction, no ASD/PFO. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. amLODIPine ___ mg PO DAILY 2. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 3. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 2. Heparin 5000 UNIT SC BID 3. Insulin SC Sliding Scale Fingerstick QACHS Insulin SC Sliding Scale using REG Insulin 4. Pantoprazole 40 mg IV Q24H 5. amLODIPine 5 mg PO DAILY 6. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 7. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 8. HELD- Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H This medication was held. Do not restart Pantoprazole until told to resume by treatment team. PO was clogging your PEG tube. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ ___) <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Left Lateral Medullary Infarct <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were hospitalized due to symptoms of new left leg weakness, disequilibrium, blurry vision, slightly worsened dysphagia, and "feeling lousy" resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: - High Cholesterol - Amyloid angiopathy - Coronary artery disease, Peripheral vascular disease We are changing your medications as follows: - START atorvastatin 80mg DAILY - HOLD pantoprazole for now. It clogs your PEG tube. You are receiving the IV version. - CONTINUE amlodipine 5mg DAILY. - CONTINUE aspirin 81mg DAILY. - CONTINUE clopidogrel (Plavix) 75mg DAILY. Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician as listed below. If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms: - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to you - Sudden weakness of one side of the body - Sudden drooping of one side of the face - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body Thank You, Your ___ Neurology Team

ESR was elevated at 130 and he was given a dose of Solumedrol for potential temporal arteritis. On ___, after lunch he acutely felt worse with increased left leg weakness, blurry vision, and left basilar headache. Code stroke was called. The patient also was apparently acutely intoxicated with cocaine on presentation to the ED. The patient had temperatures to 100.0 and given the concern of the patient having AIDS, was started on empiric vancomycin/zosyn for an unclear source. A chest xray was performed and was negative for infiltrate, blood and urine cultures were obtained. It is unclear why such broad spectrum antibiotics were started based on ED documentation as no source was noted. The patient does have a history of ADIs inclucing PCP, ___. and is coinfected with HCV. The ED Was initially planning ED Obs when the patient spiked to 101 in the ED. Per the patient and OSH records, the patient had been receiving care for his pancreatitis since ___. He has suffered from ___ episodes of pancreatitis over the past few years and has previously required TPN for nutrition. He received a total pancreatectomy with auto-islet cell transplantation in ___ at ___. His course was complicated by post-operative intraabdominal abscesses and is now s/p abscess drainage x2, and while on IV antibiotics developed GNR bactermia. The PICC line used to administer the antibiotics were removed and he was transitioned to oral antibiotics. He was discharged home and for the past 3 days ___ was the date of discharge) he has experienced increasing N/V and decreased PO intake. The patient denies bloody or projectile emesis, worsening abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, bloody or melanous stools. His last bowel movement was yesterday. He has not had one today. He denies fevers, chills, rigors, night sweats, or any sick contacts since being home from ___. The patient's nausea peaks in the evening and at its worse is a ___ out of 10. With 8mg of Zofran, he reports his nausea decreasing to a ___. He reports that the nausea isn't associated with eating nor has he noticed it worsen after taking his PO medications. In the ED, initial vital signs were: T 97.2, HR 82 BP 150/80, HR 15, 99% RA. Exam notable for ex-lap incision c/d/i, LLQ and RLQ pain but no rebound or guarding, JP drains from RUQ with serosanginous drainage and muddy brown drainage. Labs were notable for: WBC 10.3, Hg 10.8, platelets 1028, Na 138, K 4.7, Cl 95, Bicarb 32, BUN 10, Cr 1.1. No imaging obtained. Patient was given 1000cc NS and promethazine 6.25 mg. Vitals prior to transfer were: Temp 99.1, HR 77, BP 135/92, RR 18, 100% RA. Upon arrival to the floor, patient reported mild nausea. No abdominal pain. You had a benign abdominal exam without fevers, chills or recent sick contacts making bowel obstruction or infection unlikely. The symptoms started after transitioning to oral antibiotics while in the hospital last week and this was felt to be the most likely cause of your symptoms. After speaking with your surgeon, Dr. ___, the decision was made to stop your flagyl (a common cause of stomach upset) and fluconazole. Your symptoms improved significantly with antiemetics (medications for nausea) and transition to ciprofloxacin only. At discharge, you were tolerating a normal, diabetic diet and able to take in adequate calories. Because of this, you were not felt to need nutritional support with tube feeds or TPN at this time. It is very important that you continue to consume enough calories to maintain your weight and ultimately start to gain back the weight you have lost over the last several months. While you were here, you noted that your pain post-surgery was significantly improved and your oxycontin was decreased from 40mg BID to 30mg BID. We also have provided you with stool softeners to prevent constipation. Please continue to take ciprofloxacin twice daily until you follow-up with Dr. ___ at ___ for drain removal on ___. It was a pleasure taking care of you! Your ___ Care Team

There is a very subtle opacity projecting lateral to the left hilar region. Conceivably, this could be a focus of very early pneumonia. Correlate with clinical exam and level of clinical suspicion. Followup is recommended to document resolution. CT Head ___: 1. No acute intracranial hemorrhage. Please note that MRI is more sensitive in detection of infarcts. 2. Persistent right maxillary sinus opacification with high-density material, likely representing inspissated secretions, unchanged. MRI Head ___: IMPRESSION: New right thalamic /posterior limb internal capsule and right occipital lobe infarcts with evolution of previously seen infarcts from ___. MRA Head ___: IMPRESSION: Limited MRA of the head with flow visualized in the major arteries, but mid basilar region is not seen. This could be artifactually not well visualized but repeat study can be obtained or CTA can be obtained for further assessment if indicated. CXR ___: It is difficult to say whether perihilar opacification below the left hilus is due to consolidation or more likely congested venous confluence of the left atrium. The portions of the lungs not obscured by the large cardiac silhouette are clear. There is no pleural effusion or vascular engorgement. ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD WBC-7.3 RBC-4.21* Hgb-12.4* Hct-35.5* MCV-84 MCH-29.4 MCHC-34.9 RDW-13.4 Plt ___ ___ 06: 20AM BLOOD WBC-7.7 R

Pt was recently admitted 2 week ago with bilateral malignant otitis externa, superinfected basal cell carcinoma nevi, UTI, and acute on chronic renal failure. ___ ear swab grew Pseudomonas (ceftazidime-resistant, meropenem-sensitive), Proteus (meropenem-sensitive), MRSA, and Enterococcus. open pressure wound on back <PERTINENT RESULTS> ON ADMISSION: ___ 06: 15PM WBC-12.3* RBC-3.26* HGB-8.8* HCT-30.9* MCV-95 MCH-27.1 MCHC-28.5* RDW-18.9* ___ 06: 15PM NEUTS-92.5* LYMPHS-4.1* MONOS-2.6 EOS-0.2 BASOS-0.6 ___ 06: 15PM ALBUMIN-2.8* ___ 06: 15PM GLUCOSE-95 UREA N-51* CREAT-2.7* SODIUM-137 POTASSIUM-6.6* CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-20* ANION GAP-19 ___ 06: 26PM LACTATE-1.2 ___ 06: 21PM ___ TEMP-37.3 PO2-31* PCO2-64* PH-7.18* TOTAL CO2-25 BASE XS--6 INTUBATED-NOT INTUBA VENT-SPONTANEOU COMMENTS-O2 DELIVER ___ 06: 32PM PO2-87 PCO2-47* PH-7.27* TOTAL CO2-23 BASE XS--5 ___ 08: 08PM TYPE-ART RATES-16/ TIDAL VOL-500 PEEP-5 O2-100 PO2-432* PCO2-53* PH-7.23* TOTAL CO2-23 BASE XS--5 AADO2-226 REQ O2-46 -ASSIST/CON INTUBATED-INTUBATED ON DISCHARGE: ___ 03: 31AM BLOOD WBC-6.7 RBC-3.00* Hgb-8.2* Hct-26.6* MCV-89 MCH-27.2 MCHC-30.7* RDW-17.8* Plt ___ ___ 03: 31AM BLOOD Glucose-90 UreaN-47* Creat-2.3* Na-139 K-4.0 Cl-100 HCO3-31 AnGap-12 ___ 03: 31AM BLOOD Calcium-8.1* Phos-4.2 Mg-2.4 Microbiology: ___: Urine culture negative ___: Blood culture no growth to date Imaging: ___ CXR: Persistent bibasilar and right upper lobe opacities likely represent pneumonia. ___ CXR: 1) ET tube slightly lower, 5.1 cm above the carina. 2) Asymmetric CHF findings, slightly improved on the right. 3) Left lower lobe collapse and/or consolidation. 4) The possibility of associated pneumonic infiltrates cannot be excluded. ___ CXR: Multifocal consolidations are likely multifocal pneumonia with worsening opacities in the left lower lobe. This could be due to increasing atelectasis or worsening pneumonia. Ophthalmic twice a day for 2 weeks: apply to both ears NOT TO EYES. 3. mupirocin 2 % Ointment Sig: One (1) application Topical twice a day: apply to sores that are not open. 4. fluticasone-salmeterol 250-50 mcg/dose Disk with Device Sig: One (1) puff Inhalation twice a day. 5. tiotropium bromide 18 mcg Capsule, w/Inhalation Device Sig: One (1) Cap Inhalation DAILY (Daily). 6. albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: Two (2) Puff Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for wheezing/SOB. 7. albuterol sulfate 2.5 mg/0.5 mL Solution for Nebulization Sig: 2.5 mg Inhalation three times a day as needed for shortness of breath or wheezing. 8. furosemide 10 mg/mL Solution Sig: Eighty (80) mg Injection BID (2 times a day): by intravenous injection. 9. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable PO DAILY (Daily). 10. metoprolol tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 11. atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 12. dorzolamide 2 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic BID (2 times a day): tio left eye only. 13. tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime). 14. latanoprost 0.005 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic HS (at bedtime): to both eyes. 15. Artificial Tears Drops Sig: One (1) drop Ophthalmic four times a day: to both eyes. 16. citalopram 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day: please take in the morning. 17. trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime). 18. trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) as needed for insomnia. 19. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 20. sevelamer carbonate 800 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID W/MEALS (3 TIMES A DAY WITH MEALS). 21. B complex-vitamin C-folic acid 1 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily). 22. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). 23. Aranesp (polysorbate) 60 mcg/mL Solution Sig: Sixty (60) mcg Injection once every 14 days: next dose ___. 24. ascorbic acid ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 25. ferrous sulfate 325 mg (65 mg iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 26. ondansetron HCl 2 mg/mL Solution Sig: Four (4) mg Intravenous every eight (8) hours as needed for nausea. 27. cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 28. Heparin Flush (10 units/ml) 2 mL IV PRN line flush PICC, heparin dependent: Flush with 10mL Normal Saline followed by Heparin as above daily and PRN per lumen. 29. Sodium Chloride 0.9% Flush 3 mL IV Q8H: PRN line flush Peripheral line: Flush with 3 mL Normal Saline every 8 hours and PRN. 30. bisacodyl 10 mg Suppository Sig: One (1) suppository Rectal once a day as needed for constipation. 31. heparin (porcine) 5,000 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1) mL Injection TID (3 times a day): by subcutaneous injection. 32. Outpatient Lab Work Twice daily electrolyes and once daily renal function until stabilized on diuretic regimen <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Acute on Chronic Systolic Congestive Heart Failure <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or wheelchair. Discharge weight: 94 kg <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking part in your care. You were admitted to the hospital because you were having trouble breathing related to fluid building up in the lungs. To help you breath, you required a breathing tube. You received medication to promote urination of the extra fluid from the body. With the extra fluid removed, you were able to come off of the breathing tube and we were able to send you back to ___. Please make the following changes to your medications: 1. CHANGE lasix to 80mg IV twice daily 2. STOP Heparin IV infusion 3. STOP meropenem 4. STOP sodium bicarb IV infusion 5. STAOP vancomycin 6. STOP albuterol/ipratropium combination inhaler 7. START albuterol meter-dosed inhaler two puffs inhaled by mouth every 6 hours as needed for shortness of breath/wheeze 8. START metoprolol tartrate 25mg by mouth twice daily. 9. START atorvastatin 80mg by mouth once daily 10. START citalopram 40mg by mouth daily 11. START trazodone 100mg by mouth once nightly, and an extra 50mg by mouth once nightly as needed for insomnia. 12. START sevaelamer carbonate 800mg by mouth three times daily with meals 13. START nephrocaps. I cap by mouth daily 14. START docusate sodium 100mg by mouth twice daily 15. START ascorbic acid ___ by mouth twice daily 16. START ferrous sulfate 325mg by mouth daily 17. START cholecalciferol 400units by mouth daily 18. START heparin 5000units by subcutaneous injection three times daily Please continue all other medications as previously prescribed. Please keep all follow-up appointments.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> ORTHOPAEDICS <ALLERGIES> Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Recurrent instability, right revision THR. <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ - Revision R THA <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: Most unfortunately ___ had a third crescendo dislocation of her total hip replacement revision, which I performed for her two months ago. I talked to her daughter today as ___ was then on route to the hospital via ambulance. She has initial history of very significant ___, had a THR ___ years ago and the acetabulum failed to ingrown went vertical. We modified her with a revision acetabulum. Two months ago, utilizing ___ Longevity and trilogy series trabecular metal 56 mm shell with standard liner. Unfortunately, she has had posterior dislocation three times and has been wearing an abductor brace repeatedly comes out in flexion and internal rotation despite the brace. She is very compliant and very thoughtful person and I have no doubt that she has been doing her best to stay within the compliance regulation. In any event, the soft tissues which were limited at the time of the surgery in terms of available residual capsule and piriformis now will be completely torn out, certainly. We in the emergency room were able to easily relocate her with propofol and she was put into a knee brace and the postoperative x-ray shows complete reduction. She does have some evidence of osteolysis posterior to the cup which we have seen on all of her films, I think it relates to the fact that she has a bit of bilobed shape in this 56 mm native acetabulum and we had to bone graft and behind it. Screw fixation appears intact. The femoral side has never been an issue. My concerns in addition to the recurrent dislocation are whether or not she might have an infection. LABORATORY DATA: Her lab work today, white blood count is good at 9.3. She does have shifted 85% neutrophils, but no bands. However, her ESR is a little bit elevated at 27, but she is only two months postop, this is actually the lowest ESR we have seen on her in the three times that has been measured in ___ years. Her CRP is 13.6 and certainly while elevated, it is significantly improved from the 42.0 it was this ___. She has been aspirated this ___ and was culture negative with a low intra-articular WBC count of only 225 back in ___ when we made preparations for revision THR. She has never had symptoms suggestive of infection. Her incision looks fine. However, we are admitting her tonight planning to operate on her in two days with the revision acetabulum. In the morning, we will get a fluoroscopic-guided aspiration of the hip not only for cultures, but also for cell count, differential will be important. We tentatively have her on this or scheduled for two or three days from now, but we will be most interested in seeing whether or not the culture or fluid results show marked abnormality. If so, then the possibility of resection arthroplasty stands. Whether or not we would have to hold off on surgery for a couple days to await final culture results is a possibility. For now, we will make plans towards getting the equipment in for revision THR and if we need to change our course accordingly, we will. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HTN, asthma, h/o breast cancer, raynauds <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Sister also with ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> Well appearing in no acute distress Afebrile with stable vital signs Pain well-controlled Respiratory: CTAB Cardiovascular: RRR Gastrointestinal: NT/ND Genitourinary: Voiding independently Neurologic: Intact with no focal deficits Psychiatric: Pleasant, A&O x3 Musculoskeletal Lower Extremity: * Incision healing well with staples * Scant serosanguinous drainage * Thigh full but soft * No calf tenderness * ___ strength ___ * SILT DP/SP/T/S/S * Toes warm <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 09: 23PM ___ PTT-31.3 ___ ___ 08: 37PM URINE COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 08: 37PM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-7.0 LEUK-NEG ___ 07: 58PM GLUCOSE-99 UREA N-17 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-106 TOTAL CO2-26 ANION GAP-12 ___ 07: 58PM estGFR-Using this ___ 07: 58PM CRP-13.6* ___ 07: 58PM WBC-9.3 RBC-4.43 HGB-12.3 HCT-36.7 MCV-83 MCH-27.8 MCHC-33.5 RDW-13.8 ___ 07: 58PM NEUTS-85.6* LYMPHS-11.1* MONOS-2.4 EOS-0.5 BASOS-0.4 ___ 07: 58PM PLT COUNT-453* ___ 07: 58PM SED RATE-27* <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> atenolol 50 mg QD, naprosyn prn, oxycodone prn, theophylline 200 mg BID, Cal/VitD, MVI <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Capsule(s)* Refills: *2* 2. trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO QHS (once a day (at bedtime)) as needed for Insomnia. 3. multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily). 4. calcium carbonate 200 mg calcium (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable PO TID (3 times a day). 5. cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 6. ferrous sulfate 300 mg (60 mg iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) for 1 months. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 7. atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 8. amitriptyline 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime). 9. theophylline 400 mg Tablet Extended Release Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release PO DAILY (Daily). 10. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain. 11. pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours). 12. enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) 40mg Subcutaneous once a day for 3 weeks: Take for 3 weeks post-operatively to prevent DVTs. Disp: *21 40mg* Refills: *0* 13. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as needed for pain: Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while on narcotics. Disp: *80 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 14. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 3 weeks: Take for 3 weeks after you complete your lovenox course to prevent DVTs. Disp: *42 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Recurrent instability, right revision THR <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five (5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken out by the visiting nurse (___) or rehab facility two weeks after your surgery. 7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment in four (4) weeks. 8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, motrin, etc). 9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for three (3) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). After completing the lovenox, please take Aspirin 325mg TWICE daily for three weeks. ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS. 10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks. 11. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after surgery. 12. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Mobilize frequently Physical Therapy: ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Mobilize frequently Treatments Frequency: WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting nurse or rehab facility in two (2) weeks. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after surgery.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Agitation <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> NA <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with Alzheimer's dementia who was transferred from ___ for agressive behavior over the past two weeks which escalated to hitting a CNA and trying to choke another nurse. He was given 1 mg of ativan and 1 mg of haldol without success at ___. Of note, patient has spent the last 6 months since moving to ___ at various facilities and most recently arrived at ___ 10 days ago. Patient has been declining over the past 6 months but the more aggressive behavior is new. Per son, he has a long history of "not having boundries" and so will wander into other patients rooms and will often undress himself. . In the ED, vitals were 97.3, 83, 156/56, 24, 99% on RA. He got a Head CT which showed no acute changes. He got 10 mg of IM haldol, 10 mg of zyprexa SL, 2 mg of ativan without significant improvement of his agitation. . Upon arrival to the floor, patient is restless but not agitated or aggressive. He is AxO to self only. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abdominal pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HPI: ___ pshx notable for c-sectionx2 with recent unremarkable colonoscopy presenting with intermittent crampy abdominal pain over preceding 5 days associated with nausea. Directed to present to ___ urgent care where CTAP demonstrated transition point in the RLQ, prompting transfer for surgical evaluation. Last flatus morning of presentation. Irregular formed BMs at baseline. No personal or family history of inflammatory bowel disease. Last colonoscopy reportedly ___ and reportedly unremarkable. No prior episodes. At time of consultation, pt AFVSS with soft abdomen, RLQ discomfort on exam without rebound or guarding. WBC 11,000 with concomitant UTI. CTAP with RLQ transition point, and dilated loops of small bowel, with air and stool in the colon. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Past medical history: - diverticulosis - aortic stenosis - aortic insufficiency - hypertension - hyperlipidemia - h/o colonic adenomas - psoriasis - age related osteopenia Past Surgical History: - C-section x2 <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No history of IBD/CRC. Mother: ovarian cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: Temp 98.5 HR 58 BP 100/52 RR 16 O2 98% RA Gen: alert, oriented to self, place and time. Not in any distress. HEENT: moist mucous membranes, no cervical lymphadenopathy Chest: no crackles, bilateral breath sounds present Heart: normal rate and rhythm Abdomen: soft, nondistended, nontender. +BS in all four quadrants. Extremities: without edema, palpable pedal pulses Activity: ad lib, unassisted <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___: 43AM GLUCOSE-140* UREA N-16 CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-130* POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-93* TOTAL CO2-27 ANION GAP-14 ___ 11: 43AM LIPASE-24 ___ 11: 43AM ALT(SGPT)-14 AST(SGOT)-14 ALK PHOS-64 TOT BILI-0.6 ___ 11: 43AM ALBUMIN-4.5 CALCIUM-9.9 PHOSPHATE-3.5 MAGNESIUM-2.0 ___ 11: 43AM WBC-11.3* RBC-4.44 HGB-14.1 HCT-40.1 MCV-90 MCH-31.8 MCHC-35.2 RDW-11.9 RDWSD-39.1 ___ 11: 43AM PLT COUNT-220 ___ 11: 43AM NEUTS-81.8* LYMPHS-13.5* MONOS-4.2* EOS-0.0* BASOS-0.2 IM ___ AbsNeut-9.22* AbsLymp-1.52 AbsMono-0.47 AbsEos-0.00* AbsBaso-0.02 ___ 11: 30AM URINE TYPE-RANDOM COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 11: 30AM URINE BLOOD-SM NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-0.2 PH-6.0 LEUK-TR ___ 11: 30AM URINE ___ BACTERIA-FEW YEAST-NONE ___ TRANS ___ 11: 30AM URINE HYALINE-<1 ___ 11: 30AM URINE MUCOUS-OCC <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 2. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 3. Simvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 4. Lorazepam 0.5 mg PO Q4H: PRN anxiety <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 2. Simvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 3. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 4. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H RX *ciprofloxacin HCl [Cipro] 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Twice a day Disp #*4 Tablet Refills: *0 5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID Take 1 twice a day with plenty of water. RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth Twice a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills: *0 6. Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H Take 1 packet daily. Stop if diarrhea develops. RX *magnesium hydroxide [Milk of Magnesia] 400 mg/5 mL 5 mL by mouth Daily Refills: *3 7. Lorazepam 0.5 mg PO Q4H: PRN anxiety <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Partial small bowel obstruction <DISCHARGE CONDITION> VS: Temp 98.5 HR 58 BP 100/52 RR 16 O2 98% RA Gen: alert, oriented to self, place and time. Not in any distress. HEENT: moist mucous membranes, no cervical lymphadenopathy Chest: no crackles, bilateral breath sounds present Heart: normal rate and rhythm Abdomen: soft, nondistended, nontender. +BS in all four quadrants. Extremities: without edema, palpable pedal pulses Activity: ad lib, unassisted <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: You were admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of small bowel obstruction. Your management included conservative measures such as bowel rest and intravenous fluids, and serial abdominal exams. You did not require antibiotics. You did not require surgery for this condition. You were able to tolerate regular diet and fluids at the time of your discharge. Please follow instructions outlined below to ensure good recovery. ANTIBIOTICS: Please complete the full course of antibiotics as instructed. DO NOT stop taking antibiotics if your symptoms resolve before the end of the prescribed course. Take antibiotics with food to avoid nausea. ACTIVITY: You may resume regular activity. You may climb stairs. You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you otherwise. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You might feel somewhat depressed. You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem unappealing. All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away in a short time. YOUR BOWELS: Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as oxycodone, Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these medicines without a prescription. If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving the bowels, call your primary care doctor and the surgery office to schedule an appointment. Drink plenty of fluids. If you develop diarrhea, stop taking laxatives. If it does not go away, or is severe and you feel ill, please call your surgeon. MEDICATIONS: Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as you did before, unless you have been told differently. If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to take, please call your surgeon.

She states that she was at home cleaning her mediation pillows before going to yoga class when she had ___ sharp/crushing substernal and left sided chest pain. Mild radiation into upper back and possibly slightly down left arm. Denies n/v/d, sob, diaphoresis. Called ___ because she was afraid she was having a heart attack. EMS arrived and gave her ASA 325, nitro SL which helped decrease her pain to ___ but gave her a headache. History of HTN but no other cardiac disease, this has never happened before and she is normally active taking walks and doing yoga with healthy diet. Family cardiac history significant only for early heart disease in paternal uncle. In the ED, initial VS were: 98.2, 90, 130/77, 16, 96% RA Exam unremarkable Labs showed: trop 0.4 then 0.29. CXR: Triangular opacity within the posterior aspect of the right medial lung for which further assessment with contrast-enhanced chest CT is recommended. Received ... ___ 19: 06 IV Metoclopramide 10 mg ___ ___ 19: 21 IV DiphenhydrAMINE 25 mg ___ ___ 22: 04 IV Heparin 3600 UNIT ___ ___ 22: 04 IV Heparin ___ Transfer VS were: 98.0, 62, 143/83, 16, 100% RA Decision was made to admit to medicine for further management. On arrival to the floor, patient reports that she is chest pain free and has no complaints except that she is anxious about the heparin because her husband had a intracranial bleed after receiving heparin in this hospital during cardiac cath (he had a h/o vascular disease and CABG x4). <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HTN exercise induced asthma migraines seasonal allergies glaucoma s/p iridotomy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother passed at ___. ___. ___ 06: 09PM BLOOD WBC-7.3 RBC-4.35 Hgb-12.6 Hct-39.0 MCV-90 MCH-29.0 MCHC-32.3 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-43.7 Plt ___ ___: 57PM BLOOD ___ PTT-45.9* ___ ___ 06: 09PM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-19 Creat-0.7 Na-137 K-4.5 Cl-102 HCO3-24 AnGap-16 ___ 06: 09PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.04* ___ 06: 09PM BLOOD CK-MB-4 INTERVAL LABS - ECGs: ___: Normal sinus rhythm with PACs, normal axis and morphologies, no ST-T abnormalities ___: Atrial fibrillation @ 90, STD in V4-V5, TWI in V4-V6 Left Heart Cath ___ Impression: No angiographically apparent coronary artery disease TTE ___ Conclusions The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. Normal left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size, and regional/global systolic function (biplane LVEF = 65 %). There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. There is no aortic valve stenosis. Mild to moderate (___) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular wall thickness with normal biventricular cavity size and regional/global systolic function. Mild to moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Moderate mitral regurgitation. Mild-moderate aortic regurgitation. ___ CHEST (PA & LAT) FINDINGS: Heart size is normal. The aorta is mildly unfolded. The hilar contours are normal. The pulmonary vasculature is normal. On the lateral view, a well- delineated triangular opacity is noted posteriorly along the right medial lung base, partially obscuring the right posterior hemidiaphragm. Lungs are otherwise clear. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen. There are no acute osseous abnormalities. IMPRESSION: Triangular opacity within the posterior aspect of the right medial lung for which further assessment with contrast-enhanced chest CT is recommended. ___ CTA CHEST IMPRESSION: 1. Right lower lobe pleural-based mass measuring up to 6.4 cm. Differential considerations include primary neoplasm, or less likely an infectious or inflammatory process. 2. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality. 3. Bronchial wall thickening, consistent with small airways disease. ___ CT Abdomen/Pelvis w & w/o contrast IMPRESSION: Stable large mass lower right chest, may represent solitary fibrous tumor of the pleura. There is a 0.6 cm indeterminate lesion left kidney, with central linear thin enhancement, follow-up retroperitoneal ultrasound, or MRI in 6 months recommended. There is 3.4 cm well-circumscribed left adnexal mass, may represent pedunculated fibroid versus ovarian neoplasm. Pelvic ultrasound recommended in further evaluation. ___ PELVIS U.S., TRANSVAGINAL IMPRESSION: 1. Normal ovaries. 2. Three fibroids are identified. The larger 2 fibroids correspond with structures visualized on the prior CT. Please note that on the ultrasound the questionable adnexal structure appears on the right side and on the prior CT of ___ this structure appears on the left side. The significance of this is uncertain. If further clinical evaluation is required a repeat ultrasound could be performed or if further delineation of the fibroid is needed an MRI could be performed. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires futher investigation. 1. Vitamin B Complex w/C 1 TAB PO DAILY 2. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 3. Calcium 600 with Vitamin D3 (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 600 mg(1,500mg) -200 unit oral DAILY 4. Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH DAILY: PRN SOB/cough 5. Propranolol LA 60 mg PO DAILY 6. Sumatriptan Succinate 25 mg PO DAILY: PRN migraine <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID RX *apixaban [Eliquis] 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY RX *aspirin 81 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth dailu Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 3. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth qpm Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 4. Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY RX *lisinopril 2.5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 5. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Moderate Duration: 3 Days RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth q8h: prn Disp #*9 Capsule Refills: *0 6. Propranolol LA 120 mg PO DAILY RX *propranolol [InnoPran XL] 120 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Capsule Refills: *0 7. Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH DAILY: PRN SOB/cough 8. Calcium 600 with Vitamin D3 (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 600 mg(1,500mg) -200 unit oral DAILY 9. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 10. Vitamin B Complex w/C 1 TAB PO DAILY 11. HELD- Sumatriptan Succinate 25 mg PO DAILY: PRN migraine This medication was held. Do not restart Sumatriptan Succinate until you discuss with your doctor <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS -= Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction SECONDARY DIAGNOSES -=== Pleural Mass Atrial Fibrillation <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___ It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___. You were admitted because you had chest pain. You were taken to the cath lab, where luckily they found no residual heart disease. You had an echocardiogram that also showed that your heart is pumping very well. We suggest continuing to take aspirin, propranolol and atorvastatin for now for heart protection. You were also found to have a heart rhythm called "atrial fibrillation." This condition is associated with a risk of strokes. Apixaban, and other blood thinners, can help decrease this risk substantially. Please continue to take your apixaban. Please follow up with your primary care doctor about the results of your pleural biopsy. They will determine from there with what specialty to follow up with for ongoing monitoring and care. It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. We wish you well!

At that visit, she complained of 1 week left sided tremor, difficulty picking things up with her left hand, generalized weakness and difficulty walking down stairs. She was referred to urgent care for infectious workup and was noted to be dehydrated, hyponatremic and positive for UTI. INR was 2.5. She was transferred to ___ where ___ was obtained in the ED which revealed bilateral mixed-density SDH. Neurosurgery was consulted for further evaluation. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Past Medical History small bowel lymphoma dx ___, s/p chemotherapy last completed ___ afib on Coumadin epilepsy hyperlipidemia osteoporis cardiomyopathy, systolic heart failure moderate to severe MR posterior fossa embolic strokes PAST SURGICAL HISTORY HERNIA REPAIR ___ ___'S RIGHT FOREHEAD RIGHT CATARACT REMOVAL GASTRIC RESECTINO OF LARGE CELL LYMPHOMAS LEFT CATARACT REMOVAL LEFT LACUNAR INFARCT GASTRIC LARGE CELL LYMPHOMAS <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother: bone cancer Father: heart disease, PD Brother: cancer (unknown type), smoking Sister: dementia (alive at ___) Maternal grandfather: cirrhosis ___ grandmother: heart attack Children: - daughter with liver transplant (unclear reason) - daughter with lyme disease - son with prostate ca s/p resection - son (deceased) heart disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> On admission: PHYSICAL EXAM: O: T: 97.4 BP: 154/74 HR: 70 R: 18 O2Sats: 97% RA Gen: WD/WN, comfortable, NAD. HEENT: Pupils: EOMs Neck: Supple. Lungs: CTA bilaterally. Cardiac: RRR. S1/S2. Abd: Soft, NT, BS+ Extrem: Warm and well-perfused. Neuro: Mental status: Awake and alert, cooperative with exam, normal affect. Orientation: Oriented to person, place, and date. Recall: ___ objects at 5 minutes. Language: Speech fluent with good comprehension and repetition. Naming intact. No dysarthria or paraphasic errors. Cranial Nerves: I: Not tested II: Pupils equally round and reactive to light, 3 to 2 mm bilaterally. Visual fields are full to confrontation. III, IV, VI: Extraocular movements intact bilaterally without nystagmus. V, VII: Facial strength and sensation intact and symmetric. VIII: Hearing intact to voice. IX, X: Palatal elevation symmetrical. XI: Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius normal bilaterally. XII: Tongue midline without fasciculations. Motor: Normal bulk and tone bilaterally. + tremors to LUE. Strength full power ___ throughout. No pronator drift Sensation: Intact to light touch, proprioception, pinprick and vibration bilaterally. Toes downgoing bilaterally Coordination: normal on finger-nose-finger, rapid alternating movements, heel to shin On discharge: AOx3 (options for year), L pupil 3.5-2, R pupil ___, ___, ___ ___, tremulous left side > right <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ Non contrast Head CT IMPRESSION: 1. Predominantly hypodense mixed-density bilateral acute-on-chronic subdural hematomas with more acute component seen posteriorly bilaterally. No midline shift. ___ Non contrast Head CT IMPRESSION: Similar appearance of bilateral acute on chronic subdural hematomas. No new intracranial hemorrhage. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> BRIMONIDINE - brimonidine 0.15 % eye drops. once a day - (Prescribed by Other Provider) DIGOXIN [DIGOX] - Digox 125 mcg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day - (Prescribed by Other Provider) LATANOPROST - latanoprost 0.005 % eye drops. once a day - (Prescribed by Other Provider) LEVETIRACETAM - levetiracetam 500 mg tablet. 2.5 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day LISINOPRIL - lisinopril 20 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day METOPROLOL SUCCINATE - metoprolol succinate ER 25 mg tablet,extended release 24 hr. 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day - (Prescribed by Other Provider) OMEPRAZOLE - omeprazole 20 mg capsule,delayed release. 1 capsule(s) by mouth once a day SIMVASTATIN - simvastatin 10 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth every evening WARFARIN [___] - ___ 2.5 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Medications - OTC CALCIUM CARBONATE [CALTRATE 600] - Caltrate 600 600 mg (1,500 mg) tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day - (Prescribed by Other Provider) CETIRIZINE - cetirizine 10 mg tablet. 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day STARCH (THICKENING) [THICK-IT] - Thick-It oral powder. ___ powder(s) by mouth with all fluids <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild do not exceed 3gm acetaminophen in 24 hours. 2. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H Duration: 5 Days 3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 4. Heparin 5000 UNIT SC BID 5. Senna 17.2 mg PO HS 6. Brimonidine Tartrate 0.15% Ophth. 1 DROP BOTH EYES DAILY 7. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO DAILY 8. Cetirizine 10 mg PO DAILY 9. Digoxin 0.125 mg PO DAILY 10. Latanoprost 0.005% Ophth. Soln. 1 DROP BOTH EYES QHS 11. LevETIRAcetam 1250 mg PO BID 12. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 13. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 14. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 15. Simvastatin 10 mg PO QPM 16. Vitamin D 800 UNIT PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ for Rehabilitation and Sub-Acute Care) <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Bilateral acute on chronic ___ <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Discharge Instructions Brain Hemorrhage without Surgery Activity -We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment. -You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. ___ try to do too much all at once. -No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. -If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT allowed to drive by law. -No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You should avoid contact sports for 6 months. Medications -Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. - You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is important that you take this medication consistently and on time. -You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication. What You ___ Experience: -You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and remembering new information. -Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. -Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood swings are also common. -Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener. Headaches: -Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain bleed. -Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a headache. -Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed by your doctor. -There are other things that can be done to help with your headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for: -Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision site. -Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit -Nausea and/or vomiting -Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake -Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers -Seizures -Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak -Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience any of the following: -Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg -Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding -Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or coordination -Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Altered Mental Status <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo M with HCV, ___ on recent prednisone taper, Depression, Alcohol abuse recent d/c from de-tox who presented to his PCP ___ with AMS and was reffered to the ED. . . Patient is an ___ abuser, last drink 11 days ago, was d/c from 8 day admission at Ad-Care detox in ___ three days ago. Since then reports weakness, increased sleep and confusion. On ___ he was started on prednisone taper for active chron's and is now on 10mg daily. He continues to have abdominal pain and diarrhea. He is on percoccet and may have had multiple ingestions over the past couple of days but does not recall how many. He has history of admission ___ year ago with similar presentation thought to be ___ to percocet-induced encephalitis. He also admitts to a fall two weeks ago, say he tripped with contusions to his right shin and left elbow with no head trauma. . He saw his PCP Dr ___ morning who was impressed with slow movement, unsteady gait, tremors and reduced cognition and concentration and reffered him to the ED. . In the ED, VS 99.8, 84, 110/61, 16, 98%RA, appeared delerious and unable to answer questions reliably. Neuro exam was non-focal with R hand resting tremor questionable for Asterixis. CT was neg for acute intracranial process. CXR bil atelctasis otherwise non acute, serial labs AST 98 to 124 ALT 53 to 54 T.bili stable at 0.5 INR stable at 1.4 Amonia 85 chem 7 unremarkable, Acetaminophen 60 to 40, Serum tox positive for BZ. Saw liver and Tox who recommended start NAC 21h protocol with LFTs & tylenol level q4h. Advised against flumazenil as may precipitate withdrawal. Got banna bag, Lactulose 30ml and given NAC 150mg/kg over 1 hour, then started second dose of 50mg/kg over 4 hours. Ucx + Bcx were sent. Per report mental status significantly improved over ED stay. . . On the floor patient is poor historian, says he is "appalled" by the state he is in and is anxious to "never drink again". . . Review of sytems: (+) Per HPI (-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, shortness of breath, chest pain or tightness, Denied nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> #. Crohns disease - x ___ years - s/p 2 bowel resections for stricturing disease - iliocolectomy in ___ - history of small bowel obstruction - s/p remecade treatment - recently on steroid taper for chrons: started on ___ got prednisone at 40 mg, then taper 10 mg/week to a maintenance of 10. #. Status post cholecystectomy and appendectomy #. Vagotomy/pyloroplasty #. Hepatitis C: presumed to have acquired in blood transfusion #. Major Depression (pt has outpt psychiatrist, psychologist, and therapist) #. Anxiety #. Resting tremor, unknown etiology #. Rash/Pruritis- previous derm eval with impression either hep ___ cutaneous manifestation or "Neurotic excoriations" . <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father deceased secondary to cirrhosis. Has an aunt with ___ disease. No other family history of IBD. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission: Vitals: T: 98.7 BP: 149/92 P: 80 R: 18 O2: 98RA General: appears tremollous, dischevelled and cachectic Neuro: Patient is Alert, oriented X 3 but slow to come up with answers, minimental ___ (missed three objects and 7 test) but slow, Tone normal. intermitent resting tremor in extremities. Asterexis +. Motor ___. Sensorium preserved. Babinsky normal. DTRs ___ and normal. PERRLA. No CN deficits, No other focal deficit. HEENT: Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD Lungs: CTA, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly Ext: contusion with scabs left elbow and right shin with no evidence of infection or skeletal injury. otherwise ext warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema. . Discharge: Residual mild bil tremor w/o asterexis. A+0X3. Cognition and Concentration much improved. Reading the paper and able to repeat content. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission labs: . ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD WBC-7.8 RBC-4.08* Hgb-14.7 Hct-43.7 MCV-107*# MCH-36.1*# MCHC-33.7 RDW-13.4 Plt ___ ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD Neuts-73.9* Lymphs-16.8* Monos-7.4 Eos-1.4 Baso-0.6 ___ 01: 15PM BLOOD ___ PTT-31.5 ___ ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD Glucose-91 UreaN-13 Creat-0.9 Na-138 K-4.5 Cl-104 HCO3-27 AnGap-12 ___ 03: 40PM BLOOD ALT-58* AST-124* AlkPhos-105 TotBili-0.5 ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD Albumin-3.8 Calcium-9.0 Phos-2.9 Mg-1.8 ___ 03: 40PM BLOOD calTIBC-274 VitB12-1044* Folate-GREATER TH Ferritn-157 TRF-211 ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD Ammonia-85* ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD Lipase-19 ___ 01: 30PM BLOOD TSH-0.13* ___ 01: 06PM BLOOD Lactate-1.0 ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-60* Bnzodzp-POS Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG Acetaminophen levels: ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD Acetmnp-60* ___ 03: 40PM BLOOD Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-44* ___ 08: 58PM BLOOD Acetmnp-14 ___ 01: 21AM BLOOD Acetmnp-6* ___ 01: 30PM BLOOD Acetmnp-NEG Discharge labs: ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD WBC-10.0 RBC-3.80* Hgb-13.9* Hct-40.8 MCV-108* MCH-36.7* MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.3 Plt ___ ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD ___ PTT-29.5 ___ ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-3* Creat-0.7 Na-142 K-3.5 Cl-107 HCO3-26 AnGap-13 ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD ALT-45* AST-82* LD(LDH)-213 AlkPhos-94 TotBili-0.7 ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Calcium-9.0 Phos-2.2* Mg-1.9 . . Microbiology and serologies: HCV VIRAL LOAD (Final ___: 8,210,000 IU/mL. . RAPID PLASMA REAGIN TEST (Final ___: NONREACTIVE. . LYME SEROLOGY (Final ___: NO ANTIBODY TO B. BURGDORFERI DETECTED BY EIA. . HIV Ab: Pending . URINE CULTURE (Final ___: MIXED BACTERIAL FLORA ( >= 3 COLONY TYPES), CONSISTENT WITH SKIN AND/OR GENITAL CONTAMINATION. . ___ 1: 00 pm BLOOD CULTURE - negative at dicharge, final result pending . images: CXR ___: Atelectasis at lung bases bilaterally. . Head CT ___: No acute intracranial process. . ECG ___: Sinus rhythm. Non-specific ST-T wave changes. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Clonidin 0.1mg 1 tab BID Paroxetine 30mg 1 tab QD Trazodone 50mg 1 tab QD MVI-minerals-lutein 400-162-18-300-250mg 1 tab QD Oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ 2 tabs Q6H PRN for pain Prednisone 10mg QD <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. thiamine HCl 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 3. cyanocobalamin (vitamin B-12) 250 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 4. folic acid 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 5. paroxetine HCl Oral 6. multivitamin-minerals-lutein Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Altered Mental Status <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted because of an acute altered mental state which may have been caused by medication, alcohol withdrawal or liver failure. You were treated with supportive measures and are now ready for discharge. . The most important thing that you can do for your health is completely abstain from alcohol. You are strongly urge to enroll in an alcohol abstinence program (i.e. alcoholics anonymous) using the material provided to you by our social worker. . The following changes were made to your medications: - STOP clonidine and trazodone . 1) START thiamine 100 mg Tablet. take one tablet once daily. 2) START folic acid 1 mg Tablet. Take one tablet once daily.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Hypoglycemia Acute on chronic kidney injury <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old male ESRD s/p living unrelated donor transplant ___ c/b IFTA on ___ transplant renal biopsy, HTN, DM who presented to OSH with hypoglycemia after taking two doses of lantus here with acute renal failure and hypoglycemia after accidental extra dose of lantus. Presented to OSH with accidental insulin overdose and altered mental status after taking double dose of long acting insulin. Had run out of Humalog, took 30 U lantus instead at 4pm. Then took 30U qhs lantus at 9pm. He woke up at 3am confused and sweating. Wife called EMS and presenting ___ was 40, s/p 2 amps Dextrose with improvement in mental status. On labs he was found to have ___ with creatinine of 8, up from baseline 5. Last discharge Cr 5.0 in ___, admitted for ___ and had renal biopsy that showed chronic rejection/diabetic glomerulosclerosis (interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy). He was discharged with plan to follow up with renal transplant as outpatient (___) and plan for vein mapping. During that admission his antihypertensives were changed from atenolol and lisinopril to labetolol and nifedipine. He DNKed ___ appointment. He followed up ___ and plan was to connect him with local CKD specialist, no discussion for renal transplant options or potential vein mapping in preparation for dialysis. States he feels well, but thirsty and hungry. But wife was ill over the last 2 weeks with URI. He has been feeling more fatigue than usual. Denies f/c, urinary symptoms, abd/back pain, graft pain, chest pain, SOB, lightheadedness, black or tarry stools, changes in bowel habits, ___, PND, orthopnea. No head ache, vision changes, urinating well (4 large voids since OSH), no chest pain. Presentation overall concerning for poor health literacy and compliance. States he has been compliant with azathioprine, tacrolimus. Denies history of heart failure. Denies OTC advil/aleve. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Diabetes type 2 - Hypertension - GERD - ESRD, unclear etiology, FSGS? s/p LUKT in ___ (baseline Cr 2.4) <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father with history of DM requiring dialysis <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: T 98.7, BP 142 / 82, ___, RR20, PO2 94 Ra GENERAL: NAD HEENT: AT/NC, EOMI, PERRL, anicteric sclera, pink conjunctiva, MMM NECK: supple, no LAD HEART: tachycardic, S1/S2; Left upper extremity: Partially occlusive thrombus seen within the cephalic vein (a superficial vein) at the level of the left antecubital fossa. Diameters of the basilic vein are as described. Patent radial and duplicated brachial arteries, without calcifications. 2. Right upper extremity: Cephalic vein not visualized more centrally than the antecubital fossa. Your ___ Team

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abdominal pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ F presents for eval for RUQ pain, states that she developed the pain early in the morning on ___, initially dull, worsened throughout the day, cannot identify any aggravating or alleviating factors. Reports associated nausea, no vomiting. Otherwise denies other sympotms. Notably, had recent C section on ___, uncomplicated. States that had similar episodes of pain throughout her pregnancy that she attributed to pregnancy that spontaneously resolved. States that pain is improving after coming to ED. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: GERD, migraines PSH: LSC appy, D&C <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T 97.7 HR 73 BP 97/51 RR 18 100 RA GEN: A&O, NAD HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist CV: RRR PULM: No respiratory distress ABD: Soft, nondistended, TTP in RUQ, + ___ Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused Discharge <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 97.8, 79, 92/62, 18, 98%ra GEN: AA&O x 3, NAD, calm, cooperative. HEENT: (-)LAD, mucous membranes moist, trachea midline, EOMI, PERRL. CHEST: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, (-) cyanosis. ABDOMEN: (+) BS x 4 quadrants, soft, mildly tender to palpation incisionally, non-distended. Incisions: clean, dry and intact, dressed and closed with steristrips. EXTREMITIES: Warm, well perfused, pulses palpable, (-) edema <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD WBC-10.3* RBC-4.34 Hgb-10.5* Hct-35.9 MCV-83 MCH-24.2* MCHC-29.2* RDW-17.6* RDWSD-52.7* Plt ___ ___ 12: 35AM BLOOD WBC-12.1* RBC-4.28 Hgb-10.3* Hct-34.6 MCV-81* MCH-24.1* MCHC-29.8* RDW-17.2* RDWSD-50.3* Plt ___ ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-72 UreaN-6 Creat-0.5 Na-139 K-4.4 Cl-101 HCO3-25 AnGap-17 ___ 12: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-7 Creat-0.5 Na-139 K-3.8 Cl-101 HCO3-23 AnGap-19 Imaging: ___ RUQUS IMPRESSION: Cholelithiasis without gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. Findings are not convincing for acute cholecystitis, but in the appropriate clinical setting, early acute cholecystitis may be possible. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> none <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*20 Capsule Refills: *0 3. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*20 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Symptomatic cholelithiasis / cholecystitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. You were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the following instructions. Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the appointment listed below. ACTIVITY: o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and feel you could respond in an emergency. o You may climb stairs. o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you see your surgeon at your next visit. o Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap. o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you can resume tub baths or swimming. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: o You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. o You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your throat during surgery. o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You might feel somewhat depressed. o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem unappealing. o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon. YOUR INCISION: o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay). o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is normal. o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision. o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area. o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told otherwise. o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call your surgeon. o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may resume tub baths or swimming. YOUR BOWELS: o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these medicines without a prescription. o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving the bowels, call your surgeon. PAIN MANAGEMENT: o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more medicine at one time than prescribed. o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your pain gets too severe. o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your surgeon has said its okay. o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of pain medicine. o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises. If you experience any of the following, please contact your surgeon: - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours - pain that is getting worse over time - pain accompanied by fever of more than 101 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain MEDICATIONS: Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as you did before, unless you have been told differently. If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to take, please call your surgeon.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> PSYCHIATRY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> "I've been trying to figure out why I did what I did" <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> No invasive or surgical procedure however a CTA head/neck was done given mechanism of injury which showed atherosclerotic disease but no vascular injury. Patient was successfully extubated on hospital day #2 and diet was advanced. Home medications were resumed. He was followed by the psychiatry consult team and placed on a ___ for continued suicidal ideation and multiple symptoms of depression. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ male with a history of severe major depressive disorder, with at least 3 previous suicide attempts, also with chronic back and leg pain, CAD s/p 5-vessel bypass and 2 stents, ulcerative colitis, who was transferred from an outside hospital after being found unresponsive at home after a suicide attempt via hanging. Per OMR notes, the patient was found by his girlfriend at 6: 30 ___ with a belt around his neck in the basement. Unresponsive. Police were on the scene and immediately started CPR. The pt was resuscitated after approximately 20 minutes and was taken to ___ where he was intubated. He was transferred to the ___ trauma ICU on ___. At ___ a repeat trauma survey and review of OSH images revealed no additional injuries. A CTA head/neck was done given mechanism of injury which showed atherosclerotic disease but no vascular injury. Patient was successfully extubated on hospital day #2 and diet was advanced. Home medications were resumed. He was followed by the psychiatry consult team and placed on a ___ for continued suicidal ideation and multiple symptoms of depression. Patient was then transferred to the floor, where he remained hemodynamically stable, was ambulating and voiding without assistance. On ___ he was medically cleared for psychiatric admission and was transferred to ___ for safety, stabilization, medication management and possibly ECT. On Deac4 admission interview patient states, "I've been thinking a lot about what happened and trying to figure out why I did what I did" referring to his suicide attempt several days ago. He states that since he has been at the hospital he feels well-supported and more comfortable, and denies feeling depressed at this time. He reports that he has been telling jokes and laughing a lot with staff on the medical service but also wonders if he may be doing this to cover up deeper feelings of sadness. He reports that his mood has often fluctuated between high and low. Regarding suicidality, he denies current SI and says that chronic pain plays a large role in these thoughts. He states that his recent attempt was impulsive, and that "I can't say whether I would [attempt suicide] again; here I feel safe but if I were at home that may be a different story." He formerly considered his two grandchildren "to be the reason I am alive" however he saw them the morning before he attempted suicide "and that clearly didn't stop me." He reports that he would alert unit staff if his feelings worsen. Of note, earlier today to the psychiatry consult team, patient endorsed continued SI as well as decreased interest or pleasure in activities, difficulty with sleep and appetite, low motivation, low energy, guilt, feeling like he is a burden on his girlfriend, hopelessness, and helplessness. Patient denies HI. He reports seeing occasional flashes of light out of the corners of his eyes; this is new since the suicide attempt; no hx of migraine and no current headache. Otherwise denies AVH. Also recently has been feeling as if someone is behind him but he turns around and no one is there. Denies paranoia or hypervigilance. Denies current or past symptoms of mania. Patient was oriented to the unit and informed to contact staff with questions or issues. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Chronic back/leg pain CAD (s/p 5-vessel bypass and 2 stents) HTN HLD UC GERD Rheumatoid arthritis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Medical: Mother with CHF ___: Patient reports history of depression in his mother. States his brother died of hepatitis but "he gave up at the end and stopped taking his medications". <PHYSICAL EXAM> 188.2lbs Heart: regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 and S2, no murmurs appreciated Lungs: clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales or rhonchi appreciated Abdomen: non-tender to palpation, normoactive bowel sounds x4, non-distended, no guarding, masses or rebound Extremities: warm and well perfused, no edema in bilateral lower extremities; site of femoral IVs inspected bilaterally - significant bruising on L leg but both insertion sites appear clean without drainage or erythema Neuro: pupils constricted and reactive to direct and near (2mm-1mm); EOMI; muscles of facial expression intact and symmetric bilaterally; shoulder-shrugs symmetric; light touch diffusely intact; strength ___ throughout UE and ___ ___: *station and gait: within normal limits *tone and strength: within normal limits <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___: -CBC: RBC: 3.6 Hgb 10.5 Hct: 32.4 -BMP: Na 140 K 4.5 Cl 101 HCO3 35 BUN: 10 Cr: 0.8 AnGap: 9 Glucose: 112 ALT: 10 AST: 15 AlkP: 36 Tbili: 0.9 Albumin: 3.5 Ca: 9.1 Phos: 4.1 Mg: 2.2 VPA: 61 ___: MOCA - Scored ___ with some discrepancies and adjustment for educational level (Normal greater than or equal to ___. Lowest performance on Memory, Delayed Recall, and Language/Repetition. ___: WBC: 5.1 HGB: 9.8* HCT: 30.1* Plt Count: 138* ___: Na: 142 K: 3.6 Cl: 108 CO2: 26 BUN: 12 Creat: 0.8 Glucose: 103* ___: Ca: 8.3* Mg: 1.9 PO4: 3.5 ___: Benzodiazepine: POS Barbiturate: NEG Opiate: NEG Cocaine: NEG Amphetamine: NEG Methadone: NEG <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. ClonazePAM 1 mg PO QID: PRN anxiety 2. Gabapentin 1200 mg PO TID 3. PredniSONE 5 mg PO DAILY 4. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 5. TraZODone 100 mg PO QHS 6. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) 10 mg PO Q4H: PRN breakthrough pain 8. OxyCODONE SR (OxyconTIN) 40 mg PO Q6H 9. DiCYCLOmine 10 mg PO TID 10. Metoprolol Succinate XL 12.5 mg PO DAILY 11. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 12. Methotrexate 15 mg PO 1X/WEEK (MO) <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 3. ClonazePAM 1 mg PO TID: PRN anxiety 4. DiCYCLOmine 10 mg PO TID 5. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 6. Gabapentin 1200 mg PO TID 7. Methotrexate 15 mg PO 1X/WEEK (MO) 8. Metoprolol Succinate XL 12.5 mg PO DAILY 9. We adjusted your medications, and you are now ready for discharge and continued treatment with ___ services and extensive aftercare (PCP, ___, cognitive neurology, brain injury rehab clinic). -Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - take this discharge paperwork to your appointments. -Please continue all medications as directed. -Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen your medical and psychiatric illnesses. -Do not drive until cleared by your PCP due to potential for danger given head injury and sedating medications and recent changes to your mental status -Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers if you have any concerns. -Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your health care providers. *It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you the best of health.*

The patient returns now with elective treatment of the aneurysm. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> None <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> On discharge: Vital signs normal Alert, oriented x3 CN ___ intact CV RRR Abd S/NT/ND Ext WWP Groin puncture site soft / clean / dry Strength / sensation equal and intact in UEs and ___ Proprioception intact <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD WBC-5.7 RBC-3.67* Hgb-11.0* Hct-32.9* MCV-90 MCH-29.9 MCHC-33.3 RDW-12.8 Plt ___ ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD ___ PTT-25.8 ___ ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-9 Creat-0.7 Na-138 K-4.0 Cl-107 HCO3-24 AnGap-11 ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD Calcium-8.0* Phos-3.3 Mg-2.1 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Omeprazole <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Activity  You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we recommend you take it easy for the next ___ hours to avoid bleeding from your groin.  Heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise should be avoided for ten (10) days. This is to prevent bleeding from your groin.  You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.  Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for five (5) days after your procedure.  You make take a shower. Medications  Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as directed.  You may be instructed by your doctor to take one ___ a day and/or Plavix. If so, do not take any other products that have aspirin in them. If you are unsure of what products contain Aspirin, as your pharmacist or call our office.  You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.  If you take Metformin (Glucophage) you may start it again three (3) days after your procedure. Care of the Puncture Site  You will have a small bandage over the site.  Remove the bandage in 24 hours by soaking it with water and gently peeling it off.  Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully.  You may use a band-aid if you wish. What You ___ Experience:  Mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).  Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines.  Mild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few weeks.  Fatigue is very normal  Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
