Per daughter who is also caregiver, has noticed new drainage from right heel that is malodorous. Patient also complaining of pain surrounding ulceration that has worsened over last 15 days. Denies any fevers or chills. Denies numbness or tingling. Of note patient recently admitted ___ after presenting with nausea, vomiting, hyponatremia, and right foot pain. Was evaluated by vascular surgery and podiatry, determined not to have indication for debridement at that time. Was continued on cipro and doxycycline with podiatry follow-up. On admission also with hyponatremia 116, thought to be secondary to combination of SIADH and secondary adrenal insufficiency with unclear etiology, treated with fluid restriction, salt tabs, and sodium bicarb. ACTH stim test showing low AM cortisol with appropriate rise, MRI pituitary without adenoma. Was discharged on hydrocortisone 10 mg QAM with Endocrine follow-up. ___ the ED, initial VS were: T 97.5, HR 94, BP 113/44, RR 16, O2 98%RA Exam notable for: Not documented Labs notable for: - WBC 11.4 with 72.4% neutrophils, Hb 9.1, HCT 28.7, PLT 562 - Na 135, K 4.5, BUN 20, Cr 0.9, glucose 178 - Lactate 2.7 Imaging: R foot XR: IMPRESSION: No radiographic evidence of osteomyelitis. Consults: Podiatry consulted, with R posterior/lateral heel eschar boggy/fluctuant on exam. With moderate amount of purulent drainage expressed. Culture swab obtained. Not probing deep to the bone. Underwent washout at bedside. Recommending IV antibiotics, vancomycin and possible OR with right foot I&D/debridement ___. Mr. ___ has had a complex course since his transplant, including wash-out for intra-abdominal hemorrhage, ESRD requiring dialysis, recurrent HCV, pneumonia with right empyema, and C. diff colitis. He was most recently discharged from ___ on ___ for his c.diff infection. He was doing well at rehab, and had HD today, which went without incident. After completion, they noted that he was hypotensive to the 80's and febrile to 103, and he was brought to our ED for evaluation. His wife reports his stools are still loose, but are decreased in amount and the character is improved since completing c. diff treatment. History is obtained from the patient's wife and ___, as the patient is a very poor historian and is mostly non-verbal currently <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> recurrent hepatitis C with the suspicion of fibrosing cholestatic hepatitis s/p ERCP on ___ with biliary stent placement HCV; VL on ___ was 32.6 million HCV/ETOH cirrhosis w/ hepatorenal syndrome s/p OLT ___ Intra-abdominal hemorrhage Malnutrition VRE UTI <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mom survived MI age ___, Father died age ___ of alcoholic cirrhosis. One brother died age ___ of ?mesothelioma. Sister had ___ ___ yrs ago. Other four sibs are alive and well. One niece survived ruptured brain aneurism in her ___. No other family h/o liver disease, heart disease, or cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> PE on admission: Vitals: T 99.5, HR 128, BP 89/46, RR 16, O2 100% Gen: sleepy but arousable, oriented x3; sclerae anicteric CV: tachycardic, no appreciable murmur Resp: right-sided crackles and decreased breath sounds at base, dullness to percussion right base; left lung cta Abd: soft, non-tender, moderately distended, +fluid wave; incisions well-healed; - ___ sign Extr: warm, 1+ pulses DRE: no gross blood, guaiac negative PE on discharge: - no vital signs, no resppirtaion, no pulse, no heart sounds, no pupillary reflexes <PERTINENT RESULTS> imaging: ___ Dupplex abdomen 1. Patent portal and hepatic veins and hepatic arteries with normal systolic upstroke. 2. Coarsened liver with echogenic area in the left lobe compatible with a resolving hematoma or complex fluid collection. Simple hepatic cyst also seen. 3. Moderate-to-large amount of ascites. ___ CT abdomen/pelvis 1. Bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis. 2. Dobbhoff tube curled twice, once in the stomach, once in the esophagus. 3. Moderate to extensive ascites. 4. Diffuse colitis, nonspecific in appearance but certainly could be related to patient's known C. diff infection. ___ CXR Large bilateral pleural effusions and right basal atelectasis unchanged acutely. No pneumothorax. A feeding tube and a nasogastric tube ends in the upper stomach. Right jugular line tip projects over the low SVC. Heart is not enlarged. He had an uncomplicated total knee replacement by Dr. ___ on the left side on ___. He noted that he had been having drainage to the incision since that point in time. He denies any fevers or chills and was ambulatory on the knee. On ___, he was noted to be dizzy in the shower and ended up having a syncopal episode. He was taken to ___ where he was found to be hypoglycemic as well as to have significant drainage from his surgical site on the left knee. Labs at that point in time indicated in HPI, he also then developed hypotension overnight in the setting of septic shock. After all over the patient in for an excisional drainage and washout of the left knee on ___, cultures from that operation grew out MSSA, as well as Serratia Marcescens. He was seen by the infectious disease team at ___ where he was most recently on levofloxacin, rifampin, and Ancef. Of note, the patient developed a troponin leak thought to be in the setting of demand ischemia and hypotension, this was trended to ensure troponins stably downtrending (.76 down to .52 on ___. His ECG demonstrated some sub millimeter ST elevations in leads I and II which subsequently resolved. He was recommended to have an outpatient stress test by cardiology in the future. His ___ also resolved and his creatinine normalized. Medicine team there of note did hold his ibresartan and verapamil and had placed him on metoprolol 25 mg twice daily as well as losartan. Dr. ___ that the transfer today for possible explantation of the infected total knee prosthesis, and the patient was transferred in stable condition from ___ to ___ today. He was then transferred to the ___ Orthopedic team and the patient agreed to undergo definitive surgical management via complete resection arthroplasty of the left knee and placement of antibiotic spacer on ___ by Dr. ___ ___ <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Type 2 diabetes Aortic stenosis Hypertension Osteoarthritis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Well appearing in Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC DAILY Duration: 28 Days Start: Today - ___, First Dose: Next Routine Administration Time 5. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q3H: PRN Pain - Moderate 6. Levofloxacin 750 mg PO Q24H 7. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 8. glimepiride 4 mg oral BREAKFAST 9. Januvia (SITagliptin) 100 mg oral BREAKFAST 10. Losartan Potassium 25 mg PO DAILY 11. Oxybutynin 10 mg PO DAILY 12. Tizanidine 4 mg PO TID 13. Triamcinolone Acetonide 0.025% Cream 1 Appl TP PRN itching 14. HELD- Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY This medication was held. Do not restart Furosemide until your follow up appointment with your PCP 15. HELD- irbesartan 150 mg oral BREAKFAST This medication was held. Do not restart irbesartan until your follow up appointment with your PCP 16. HELD- Verapamil 200 mg PO QHS This medication was held. Do not restart Verapamil until your follow up appointment with your PCP ___: Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> infected prosthesis of left knee and septic shock <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by your physician. 8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue Lovenox for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). 9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your Aquacel dressing in place until your follow up with Dr. ___ ___ in ___. It is okay to shower but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound after aqaucel is removed each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Sutures will be removed by your doctor at follow-up appointment. 10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, and wound checks. 11. ACTIVITY: Touch down weight bearing on the operative extremity. Two crutches or walker at all times. Mobilize. No ROM. Knee immobilizer at all times (can come out daily for skin checks). No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. 12. PICC CARE: Per protocol 13. WEEKLY LABS: draw on ___ and send result to ID RNs at: ___ R.N.s at ___. - CBC/DIFF - CHEM 7 - LFTS - ESR/CRP **All questions regarding outpatient parenteral antibiotics should be directed to the ___ R.N.s at ___ or to the on-call ID fellow when the clinic is closed.** Physical Therapy: ___ LLE No range of motion of left knee, in knee immobilizer at all times (can remove for daily skin checks) Assistive device when ambulating Mobilize frequently Treatments Frequency: WOUND CARE: Please keep your Aquacel dressing in place until your follow up with Dr. ___ ___ in ___. It is okay to shower but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. wound checks daily after aquacel removed suture removal and replace with steri-strips (at follow up visit) Lovenox 40mg SC daily Ice and elevate PRN swelling KI on at all times
